people who leave negative reviews saying combat is hard are the type who play skyrim on the easiest difficulty so they can kill enemies with ease, sure it has a complex weapon system but thats what makes it fun because it's realistic and instead of going in swords blazings you have to use strategies and stealth to your advantage.
great game

What this game is not:
This is not Assassin's Creed. The bad guys will not wait their turn and come at you one at a time. They will swarm you and they will EF you up.
This is not Shadow of Mordor. You are neither a trained military person, nor are you skilled at anything at the start. You cannot just run into a group of bad guys, spam the counter button, and kill everything (At least until you have leveled up significantly and have good equipment). The game will beat that fact into you with zero apologies.
This is not Skyrim. If you rush through the intro and then piss off into the world the second the game lets you then you will be wrecked by ANYONE who decides to attack you. Keep following the story quests at least until you learn blocks and parries.
This is not Just Cause. You cannot just run around causing mayhem. (Well, you CAN, but not if you want to get any of the story or really be able to do much of anything in any of the towns)

What this game is:
This is a great time if you're willing to take the time to enjoy it. The game knows that it's not everyone's cup of tea and is 100% unapologetic about that. But if you take the game as it exists it will take you on one hell of a ride.
This is as complex as you're willing to let it be. You can beat the main story in as little as 2 hours and 5 minutes (Per Speedrun.com) or if you want to do all the side quests and DLC and take your time (like me) then you can spend hundreds of hours on a single play through.

Some random advice about the game I wish I had been given before I started playing or that helped me greatly:
Seriously, stick with the main story quest line until you unlock the weapons trainer in Rattay, and then IMMEDIATELY use him and learn blocks and parries and practice so you level up a bit and get a handle on the fighting mechanics. Fighting gets SO much easier after that.
Pick ALL the flowers you have the patience for at the start. There's a couple buffs and skills you can get from picking flowers that are Godsends in the early game. I wandered around Skalitz picking all the flowers and because I did that I left the intro area with a couple level ups, a few buffs, and all the potion material I would need for quite some time.
Bows are your friends in the early game (as long as you have armor for your forearms). You cannot touch anyone other than other nobodies when it comes to fighting at the start, so grab a bow (not a longbow) and some arrows and you can fire while backing away from the adversary. It's super easy to get head-shots doing this so you kill them faster and you end up with an achievement!
I know, it's a medieval game, everyone wants to main a sword, but seriously; go with some form of a bonk-stick. (whether that's a mace, club, warhammer, etc. is up to you) Later in the game you WILL be facing people with serious armor and the bonk-sticks are great for making the bad guys take involuntary permanent naps; whereas you can nail an armored assailant several times with a sword and have little to no impact on their alive-ness.
You can get a dog really early on. I've heard it's of decent use in the early game. I wouldn't know because I wandered off into the world without following any of the quests that activated once I was out of the intro. The dog apparently can get in the way of being a sneaky-boi, so if that's your play-style maybe pass on the dog.
Speaking of dogs: take out any that are with your adversary. They will drain your ability to do jack and leave you helpless, so turn those puppers into pincushions without remorse.
Alchemy: Learn it. Love it. You can make Saviour Schnapps (potions you need to save the game when you aren't close to a bed you own) which usually cost you in the neighborhood of 100 coins. Not a terrible price, but early on you don't want to be blowing all your money on that stuff.
Speaking of blowing money: Loot everything at the start. Any bad guy you kill should be stripped of everything of value early on. As soon as you have a horse you can just transfer stuff to the horse and not have to worry about the weight. Pick a town that will be your base of operations and sell everything you can to the local traders and merchants. Even if they have no money left to give you. They will turn around and sell everything they buy from you that they don't usually carry and then their funds will be higher so you can sell them more stuff then next time around. (It does reportedly take a couple days for this process to happen, I'm never in a town frequently enough to check) By the late game if you are doing this regularly you can have merchants and traders with purses in the 5 digit range, which makes stuff like the "From the Ashes" DLC easier as you will need a decent chunk of change for that.

Anywho, I'm just rambling now, so I'm gonna shuddap.
I think the game is worth the full price, but definitely pick it up if it goes on sale again with a decent discount.
Got some pretty neat stuff in there

A lot of people complain about the combat system but if you simply put 2 hours into the main story youll learn some very important moves and its honestly one of the best combat systems in any game. People forget that henry is not a trained swordsman and thus you must train to become one.

applist.name: Resident Evil Village
applist.detailed_description:
Resident Evil Village Gold Edition


Experience survival horror like never before in the eighth major installment in the storied Resident Evil franchise - Resident Evil Village. The Gold Edition includes:

- Resident Evil: Village game
- Winters' Expansion additional content
- Trauma Pack DLC
- Access to RE:VERSE online game

Note: Resident Evil: Village and the Trauma Pack DLC will become playable upon the release of the Gold Edition on 28/10/2022. The Village of Shadows unlock included in the Trauma Pack allows access to content which is otherwise unlockable through gameplay progress. Details of the service period for RE:VERSE can be found on the official website (https://www.residentevil.com/reverse/). The service period may have already concluded, so please check before purchasing. Access to Re:Verse may become available through other means at a later date.

Set a few years after the horrifying events in the critically acclaimed Resident Evil 7 biohazard, the all-new storyline begins with Ethan Winters and his wife Mia living peacefully in a new location, free from their past nightmares. Just as they are building their new life together, tragedy befalls them once again.

FEATURES
• First-Person Action – Players will assume the role of Ethan Winters and experience every up-close battle and terrifying pursuit through a first-person perspective.
• Familiar Faces and New Foes – Chris Redfield has typically been a hero in the Resident Evil series, but his appearance in Resident Evil Village seemingly shrouds him in sinister motives. A host of new adversaries inhabiting the enigmatic village will relentlessly hunt Ethan and hinder his every move as he attempts to make sense of the new nightmare he finds himself in.
• A Living, Breathing Village – More than just a mysterious backdrop for the horrifying events that unfold in the game, the village is a character in its own right with mysteries for Ethan to uncover and terrors to escape from.


Winters' Expansion


Experience brand-new additional content for the award-winning modern horror masterpiece Resident Evil: Village: Third Person Mode, The Mercenaries Additional Orders and Shadows of Rose.

Hello friends! Firstly, this long-awaited game combines horror and action in a magnificent way, offering gamers an unforgettable experience.

Starting with the graphics, Resident Evil 8: Village presents a visually captivating world. The game's realistic atmosphere, detailed character models, and environmental effects provide an immersive experience that completely engulfs you. The dark and eerie atmosphere of the village further emphasizes the game's horror elements.

In terms of gameplay mechanics, while staying true to the previous games in the Resident Evil series, Resident Evil 8: Village also introduces innovative elements. The series' characteristic features such as weapon inventory management, puzzles, and exploration are present in Village as well. However, the game offers a more fluid gameplay experience, striking a successful balance in terms of pacing. The combat mechanics are highly satisfying, and the enemy designs are truly chilling. The boss battles also provide an exciting and challenging experience.

The story connects intriguingly to the Resident Evil universe and immerses you in a thrilling adventure. Playing as Ethan Winters, who arrives at the village, players encounter a mysterious family and various creatures. As the story progresses, you uncover the deep secrets of the village and face events that heighten the suspense. The voice acting and performances of the main characters are also remarkably well-done.

Another significant aspect of Resident Evil 8: Village is its replayability. The game is packed with various difficulty levels and additional content. Additionally, by exploring different sections of the game, you can delve deeper into the story details. This provides players with a long-lasting experience.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 8: Village is a fantastic game that will satisfy horror and action enthusiasts. It is visually captivating, features smooth gameplay mechanics, and offers a compelling story. Capcom has successfully brought a fresh breath to the series with this new Resident Evil game. If you have an interest in horror games, Resident Evil 8: Village is definitely a must-play.

Get it on sale like I did. Personally I liked RE7 more and felt that the second half of Village is a bit rushed. Excitement kinda plateaus after the dollhouse and never really recovers. The game is also quite railroaded and in my opinion lacked survival horror elements. It was more of an FPS with a thriller story attached.

9.5/10 from me.

A great sequel to Resident Evil 7 Biohazard. The gameplay continues in the same style, with 1st person view making it more personal as with its predecessor. The horror elements still exist, leaning a bit more into action this time. A must-buy if you are an action-horror fun. What's more, with this instalment being more action oriented, there is a plethora of weapon unlocks this time that will give quite the replayability (4 times for me!).

Incredible survival horror game, which is a sequel to Resident Evil 7 and the winter story.

The gameplay as well as the loot system and the dealer are quite innovative and very entertaining and really make you want to loot all the zones. The card, which gives a price as to whether the room has been completely looted or not, is particularly helpful.

The story and the artistic direction are excellent. The game itself is very innovative and provides a real renewal. Although the game is easier than its predecessor, the exploration, zone unlocking, and puzzle systems are excellent. The DLCs are also successful and fun. The bonus shop with the expansions and benefits that can be unlocked and purchased through successes has also been implemented well.

In summary, it's one of the best Resident Evil games for me, especially in terms of gameplay. So I recommend it to anyone looking for an excellent survival horror with enough modernity and around 15-20 hours of gameplay.

I can definitely give the game a buy recommendation.

Assassin's Creed: Origins

Genre
	• OpenWorld/Action

Game length
	• 22 - 60 Hours

Metacritic Score
	• 84

STORY

  -   In 49 BC, Bayek, a Medjay tasked with protecting the Siwa Oasis, is kidnapped by a group of masked men along with his son Khemu and taken to an underground vault in the Temple of Amun.
     They give Bayek a still Piece of Paradise and ask him to use it to open a secret November vault. Khemu helps Bayek escape. Bayek accidentally kills Khemu while dealing with one of the masked men. A year later, in 48 BC, Bayek sends himself into exile to track down five masked men to get his revenge. Having eliminated two targets, Bayek departs for Alexandria to meet with his wife Aya.

🕹️ Gameplay

⚔️ Weapons
◼️ You'll find a variety of swords, spears, shields, and blades, each with their own gameplay and damage output. 

🛗 Side-quests
◼️ The Side quests introduce players to a different cast of characters, each with their own narratives and motivations. The side quests provide you with engaging stories that expand upon the game's lore.
	• Side quests often offer valuable rewards beyond their narrative and gameplay elements. These can include XP, currency and even unique items that enhance your character's abilities.
	
💀 Antagonist 
◼️ Flavius Metellus  is the Roman proconsul of the pronce of Kyrenaika and an ally of Julius Caesar and one of the two main antagonists in Assassin s Creed Origins. He is also the leader of the Order of Ancients And Bayek's Arch-Nemesis.

🔍 Graphics 
🔸 The graphics in Origins looked good but not as Odysseys level, the same with animations. When you compare the animation between the two games, theres a huge difference.

11/10

A good representative of the Assassin's Creed series of games. There is little typical assassin stealth in the game, and parkour has become easier than in previous games. But overall the game is not bad.
I really liked the atmosphere of ancient Egypt. The exploration of the world and the tombs is interesting enough.
A lot of people hate this game. But after playing it, I realized that it is not so bad.
If you manage to get this game at a discount, then I definitely recommend Origins.

This is an amazing action-adventure open world video game. Assassin’s Creed Origins is an impressive game with amazing visuals and a superbly crafted world. The game's detailed environments and rich histories make the experience all the more immersive. The combat is fast-paced and extremely satisfying, and the side missions are varied and enjoyable. Additionally, the game includes customizable gear and skill trees, giving players plenty of options when it comes to customizing their characters. The main story is also engaging and well-written, and the villainous factions are well fleshed out.

Overall, Assassin’s Creed Origins is an excellent game and a great addition to the series. The environments, combat, and customization all feel fresh and provide a great gaming experience. It is a great game for anyone looking for a fun and challenging journey in Ancient Egypt.

[b] I wish some one sent me to the Duat instead of playing this game [/b]

Disappointed I am. Just a run of the mill,revenge story with decent combat system. Ubisoft strikes again with their classic level gating quests and grind for XP system.They knew the grind was so bad that they are selling XP boosters as a part of their micro-transaction system.Shows how scummy the game play mechanism is. The environment looks beautiful ,sadly the open world RPG effect ruined it. So many random question markers on screen filled with not so good rewards for completing them.

The Main characters Bayek of Siwa and Aya were well written and portrayed neatly, shame it all led to mediocre ending.Game might be worth for some who like grinding for XP and ability points, but for the ones who do not have a lot of leisure time, its just not worth it.

[h1]Assassin's Creed Origins: Unveiling the Origins of an Epic Adventure[/h1]

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Assassin's Creed Origins transports players to the stunning and vibrant world of ancient Egypt. The visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulously crafted landscapes, bustling cities, and intricate architectural marvels. From the vast deserts to the lush Nile Delta, every location is brought to life with rich details, realistic lighting, and captivating artistry. The attention to historical accuracy immerses you in the grandeur of ancient Egypt, making it a visual feast for the eyes.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Prepare to embark on a thrilling and immersive adventure in Assassin's Creed Origins. As Bayek, a skilled assassin, you'll navigate a vast open world filled with exploration, combat, and stealth. The gameplay seamlessly blends action, RPG elements, and a deep narrative, offering a dynamic and engaging experience. Whether you're scaling pyramids, engaging in intense combat encounters, or unraveling the mysteries of ancient tombs, the gameplay mechanics are smooth, responsive, and offer a wide range of choices and playstyles.

[h2]Rich and Engrossing Storyline[/h2]
The narrative of Assassin's Creed Origins is an epic tale that takes you deep into the origins of the Assassin Brotherhood. Set against the backdrop of ancient Egypt's political upheaval, personal vendettas, and grand conspiracies, the story is filled with intrigue, emotion, and captivating characters. Bayek's journey is one of revenge, redemption, and the fight for justice, as he uncovers the secrets that shaped the Assassin Order. The well-crafted storytelling and compelling narrative make Assassin's Creed Origins a standout in the series.

[h2]Immersive Sound Design[/h2]
The sound design of Assassin's Creed Origins is masterfully executed, further enhancing the immersive experience. The sweeping orchestral score sets the mood, intensifying the action-packed moments and serene exploration sequences. The ambient sounds of the bustling cities, wildlife, and the bustling streets of ancient Egypt create a living and breathing world. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life with convincing performances that draw you deeper into the narrative.

[h2]Vast and Diverse Open World[/h2]
Assassin's Creed Origins offers a vast and diverse open world that begs to be explored. From the bustling cities of Alexandria and Memphis to the tranquil beauty of Siwa and the mysterious hidden tombs, the world is teeming with secrets, side quests, and historical landmarks. The sheer scale and attention to detail create an immersive experience, allowing you to lose yourself in the rich tapestry of ancient Egypt.

[h2]Abundance of Content and Replayability[/h2]
Assassin's Creed Origins boasts an abundance of content and replayability. Beyond the main storyline, the game offers a wealth of side quests, activities, and collectibles to discover. The intricate web of quests and secrets ensures that there is always something new to experience and uncover. Additionally, the game introduces an engaging leveling system, a vast array of weapons and abilities to unlock, and a dynamic combat system, providing countless hours of gameplay and opportunities for customization and progression.

In summary, Assassin's Creed Origins is a captivating and immersive journey that reveals the origins of the iconic Assassin Brotherhood. With its breathtaking visuals, seamless gameplay, rich storyline, immersive sound design, and vast open world, it stands as a testament to the excellence of the franchise. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, Assassin's Creed Origins is a must-play title that will transport you to the ancient wonders of Egypt and leave you craving for more adventure.

Amazing game one of the best assassin creed games with astonishing graphics and storyline

i would recommend playing it :)
Do 1 main quest and congrats now you gotta bore yourself to death with at least 10 side quests to keep up.

I have really mixed feelings about this game. I accidentally AC Odyssey first instead of this. News flash I liked Odyssey so the experience this game was supposed to make me feel was kind of taken away by that. It is a massive game. Almost too big for my liking. I know Odyssey isn't apart of this game, but I'll try not to compare it too much. Overall it very beautiful game. You do need a decent pc to run it. I have 3070 so I didn't have a problem running it at 1440p ultra settings. If you want a framerate around 60-80fps. I would recommend turning volumetric clouds if you have 3070. That is it. Anything below a 3070 like 3060 you can run at 1440p but you gotta lower the settings. Or you can play 1080p ultra settings no problem on 3060. Anything lower try to see what works best. In terms of overall Assassins Creed feeling, it is very absent in terms of past games. You have a wide array of weapons and you don't even get the assassin blade until you are well into the story. The game completely shys away from stealth. This only you really need to use stealth is when the enemies are slightly overpowered, but even then I almost used a bow 95% of the time. Speaking of weapons if you bought the highest edition you have given legendary weapons at the start. They are very helpful. I played through 75% of the game with the poison shield and sword and the flame bow. The rest of the loot is almost pointless and you never use it. Once you use the weapons you like you almost will never change it, which makes looting the chests and stuff completely pointless. But selling the weapons and scrapping the blue weapons give you the materials and money need to upgrade the weapons you want.

I completed every side quest and marker on the map. However the achievement for that has not popped up which sucks. Unlike past games you cannot see what you have completed which is really frustrating. There are some pretty useless regions with only 2-6 different things in each. 3 of them being deserts, and 2 of them being oceans. They are just bloat for the game to make it look big. Those same areas have barely any synchronization points so you can't fast travel to them. There 75 synchronization points in the game total with the dlc. That should give a decent gauge on big the game. The statues you have to destroy don't give you anything. The papyrus puzzles I did not do because there so many and you mainly go off of clues. The races are the most frustrating pieces of garbage in this entire game. They are not worth playing at all. Besides the races, I have done everything. There are well 170 quests in this entire game. The side quests barely add to the story at all. You can completely skip them if you want, but the game forces you to do them so you level up to move on through the story and the regions. 

Leveling up in this game is an egregious chore. Going from place to place, doing this, doing that. It really sucks the fun out of the game. With Odyssey many of the side quests actually contributed to the main story. 
Speaking of story it is barely there. You have the main plot driver, but as travel around you often forget what the next part of the story you have to do, because you have level up.  I wanted to see what the whole experience would be like if I did just about everything. News flash you don't have to do everything. I bought on this sale for $20 for the whole game and dlc. I have over 70 hours in the game I think the purchase was worth it. If you want a game that will last you a long time the mythology assassins creed games will do the job. Would I recommend you playing all the through without playing other games, absolutely not. Youll get why I call open world exhaustion. Sometimes there is so much in this game that is mostly bloat quests and stuff you often get bored very quickly. Play this game in increments so you have the motivation to actually complete the game. 

For the dlc, the story is actually better than the base game. I like the curse of the pharaohs a lot more. You have different worlds so to speak once you get into the dlc. It is easily my favorite part of the entire game. It actually dives into a lot more history and the mythology of Egypt. Don't buy the dlc at full price. Its about 3-4 hours for each dlc for me completing everything to give you a gauge on how long it will take. I won't say too much more about the dlc as they do take place after the main story. 

The Origin of the Order is actually more fascinating and interesting than origin of the assassins which is kind of sad. That was also one of my favorite parts of the game. The origin of the order is so cool and fascinating I feel most AC fans will enjoy it. I bought all the AC games back in 2019. I finished Odyssey about 2 years ago. I have not played a AC game for quite some time. I recommend playing the mythology games spaced out as again you will get open world exhaustion. The outfits are kind of cool I ended up wearing the same one throughout the game until I completed the constellation quest and collected enough silica from the tombs. The outfit for that is the coolest in the entire game to me. I recommend you do. Quick tip collect as much silica as you can from every tomb and area if you want it. 

Overall this game was okay. I liked Odyssey much more everything is more refined from this game. But I do recommend it for those who like AC or open world games.

TL DR: This is the most ubisoft game of all time. It was fun at some points, Desert world was done well and story was intriguing at some points. BUT THE GRIND IS SO BORING AND THEY LEVEL LOCK QUESTS. The game could have been 15 hours shorter and still would have had the same impact. All around 7/10. 

This is the turning point for the assassins creed franchaise. The change from solely assassination game play with stealth is now an RPG which happens to have a stealth system in it where you can insta-kill unaware soldiers. The focus was shifted into a more combat oriented camp clearing, fast travel point collecting, skill point spending game which is just completely ubisoft. Its comparable with Farcry which does the same thing but with guns. Assassins creed odyssey completely leans into that and is more extreme with it. 

Saying this I really enjoyed some moments. Here are some of the more positive aspects. 
Hunting animals, exploring tombs, running around on my camel exploring areas. It was all fun. Climbing up the pyramids of Giza felt amazing and some of the views of the map are stunning. Especially when most of the view is just desert. Some NPCs are fun to talk to and it is simply satisfying when you assassinate someone. The music when roaming the desert really fits the vibe as well. If it had been just that and it wasnt an RPG it would have been an easy 9/10

After a while however, there is nothing added onto the game. It become repetitive, grinding side quests so that you can do the next story mission. Slowly and ineffectively going through camps which give you just enough EXP to make it feel like you are sort of progressing. After the 20 hour mark I just was thinking of playing other, more engaging games. It just became a chore and I wanted it to be done as fast as possible. Something I never felt when playing something like black flag.

The main reason behind this is the damn level requirements on the mission. Sure, it says "Recommended level" but in reality if you aren't at least within 2 levels of that number you will not be able to realistically beat the missions. You will do 20 damage when you would regularly do 100. This creates a sort of grind that becomes super repetitive. Get mission, talk to NPC, go to encampment, kill people, save hostage, free hostage. They are all a variation of that. For the first few times they are alright but not fun. Even over world enemies become difficult to kill too. 

It is such a shame to see an amazing game be fucked by the forced level requirements. I would still recommend just be prepared for a grind.
the level farm is just horrible

If you've played the Assassin's creed games before, Origins has nothing new to offer. The Open world is amazing and that's about it. There is absolutely nothing else this game does differently and is repetitive. The story line is boring, the characters are forgettable and the mission suck - they've tried to copy what the Witcher does but have failed miserably. 

I don't understand how this series got to where it is right now! If you remember the earlier AC games, there were missions in which we had to fly around Venice and drive tanks! What happened to all that cool stuff? All the missions in this game are boring and you have to do the same thing over and over again. I should have stuck to my resolution of staying off Ubisoft games - they just recycle their sterile games and Origins proves it.  

They need to add a few gamers in the development team as it feels like the developers are not gamers and don't know what a fun game is supposed to be. Picked this up on sale as everyone said there were some changes in Origins but if you like me have been playing AC games for a long time, skip this one and devote your time to something else. I finished it and can safely say that it sucks. If you have the itch to play an AC game, best to go back and play the older ones like AC 2, Brotherhood or Blackflag.
Game crashes more than a drunk driver
play if you don't have a social life bcuz it takes forever

A review I watched lamented that this game "felt as if Assassin's Creed might've lost its soul". Frankly, I'm glad. Of the three AC games I've played, this was by far the best and has been a blast to play. The franchise has reinvented itself as an RPG (with clear influence from The Witcher 3) and it's leagues more immersive and engaging as a result. Ptolemaic Egypt is fascinating and beautiful, Bayek has genuine charisma and wit, and the leveling system and skill trees are sensible and genuinely rewarding. Combat is much more sophisticated than older games with all manner of weapons, special attacks, parries, blocking, dodging, and all sorts of tricks that you'd expect any self-respecting combat savvy medjay to have. The story is a bit haphazard as AC often is, but there's a merciful lack of mentions of Assassins or Templars, as well as very few Abstergo-related scenes (which felt like a blessing coming from Black Flag). The world is huge, pretty, and full of things to do that manage to strike just the right note of not feeling [i]too[/i] tedious while still letting you grind if you want.

A word of warning: I spent an UNGODLY amount of time debugging this game, though I have one of the new Intel GPUs that's a bit more prone to driver problems than more conventional offerings. If you've got problems, you may want to look into using 'dxvk' if you're on AMD/Intel cards, or rolling back your drivers if you're on Nvidia cards. I've crashed the game DOZENS of times simply by diving into water, so buyer beware.

If you can get past the technical and performance problems, this game is a ton of fun and a breath of fresh air from an otherwise soul-crushingly formulaic and monotonous franchise. As crazy as it feels to say, I'm actually looking forward to playing the next one.
nice\
Many things to do and see, the first AC game to "change the formula" and it paid off.

applist.name: Psychonauts 2
applist.detailed_description:
Razputin “Raz” Aquato, trained acrobat and powerful young psychic, has realized his lifelong dream of joining the international psychic espionage organization known as the Psychonauts! But these psychic super spies are in trouble. Their leader hasn't been the same since he was rescued from a kidnapping, and what's worse, there's a mole hiding in headquarters.

Combining quirky missions and mysterious conspiracies, Psychonauts 2 is a platform-adventure game with cinematic style and tons of customizable psychic powers. Psychonauts 2 serves up danger, excitement and laughs in equal measure as players guide Raz on a journey through the minds of friends and foes on a quest to defeat a murderous psychic villain.

  • Experience an imaginative, cinematic story that mixes humor and intrigue, brought to you by legendary game designer Tim Schafer (Grim Fandango, Brütal Legend, Broken Age).
  • Explore unique environments using Raz’s ability to dive into people’s brains to battle their inner demons, unlock hidden memories, and resolve their emotional baggage.
  • Leap acrobatically through the air, traversing tightropes and trapezes in a varied, challenging, and joyful platforming experience.
  • Wield a powerful array of psychic powers to blast, burn and levitate things, or even slow down time itself to solve environmental puzzles and battle strange enemies.

reviews.review:
Psychonauts 2 is a decently fun game, but not without its flaws.

A good word to describe Psychonauts 2 would be "overproduced". The cutscenes, dialogue, and even animations of interacting with the environment can be fun, but often overstay their welcome. To give one example I remember pressing a button to solve a puzzle involved: Animation of approaching the control panel -> Dialogue option to give more button choices -> Dialogue to select a button -> Dialogue to go back to initial menu -> Dialogue to exit the control panel. And if you want to press another button you have to do the entire thing over again. It's just tedious and makes the game seem reluctant to even let the player play it.

Speaking of gameplay, it's decent overall. You unlock a few new powers which are a mix of fun and underwhelming. The levels are creative aesthetically but are largely the same in terms of how they play out [Platforming] -> [Fighting] -> [Platforming] -> [Occasional puzzle] -> [Platforming], which is quite disappointing considering the gameplay variety potential for the premise of every level.

All things considered I had fun with Psychonauts 2, It's a creative game with a fun world and characters. I just wish the developers focused a bit more on the "game" part.

psychonauts ii was the perfect sequel to the original ( and i'm very picky about "part 2"s of anything ) - there were so many cute references to the first game, while still providing a really unique & fun experience to those who have never played psychonaut games.. iii could say this is one of my favorite series of anything, jus because the storylines are SO rich and i feel every side character has their own colorful development. doublefines was defo ahead of their time in 2006, love to see them back in 2021. <3
Okay, thank you Tim Schafer for this lovely follow up to the great game Psychonauts. I had an amazing time and I thank the Double Fine team for the lovely craft and care put into the game.
This is an all around awesome game with great stage design and art style ....Not to mention a well written story to draw you in! 9/10

Idk how they did it but after 16 years of back in forth development nightmare they managed to make a sequel on par with the original game...Maybe even better...

Still mad about the nerf on Psy baloon tho...

9.5/10

After playing the first game, going right into the sequel felt so seamless. 
This has got to be the best plat-former I've played with such a perfected combat system and story. 
The art style is phenomenal, the worlds are so much fun to explore and the characters are so expressive and diverse- its hard to not adore this game xx

The creativity on display is just incredible, and there was never a dull moment looking through different minds, or listening to the slightly cursed lines of dialogue mental creations would spout.
The combat is on the easy side, but I wouldn't say that is a negative. While I had a little trouble finding a button layout for the 8 psychic powers available that let me develop muscle memory, the enemy variety, especially later in the game, makes use of each power in most fights.
The story is pretty light, but I loved watching these characters in cutscenes and by the end I was invested in some of them. When I started playing, I was worried that Raz's voice would get annoying, but instead it steadily grew on me.
The collectathon gameplay loop on paper sounds tedious, but while it's extremely satisfying to get all of the *whatevers*, the game also lets you know early on that you can leave some for later if you can't get to them immediately. There is plenty I still haven't gotten yet, and I doubt I will have 100% this game by the time I move on.
While I have finished the main story (and the 35 minute credit sequence), I have no intention of leaving this game behind just yet. It is just too precious.

A direct sequel to Psychonauts 1. Pretty much better than the first in every single way. The level designs are even weirder/creative but also more streamlined. This does mean overall the game is easier though. I don't really enjoy platformers anymore but this had me gripped from beginning to end.

I am really happy to play this game. Psychonauts 2 has made many improvements compared to the first version. I can say that the gameplay of the game is perfect compared to the first version and that the experience of the world of Psychonauts with today's visual graphics was enjoyable.

The game environments this time seemed wider and more alive and more beautiful، the background music of the game was very enjoyable and had a good variety.

The story of the game has become more serious and deeper, at first glance it may seem like a cool platforming game like other games, but the story of the game is extremely serious. I enjoyed the experience of Psychonauts 2 more than the first version and I recommend it to everyone.

Score 10/10

Really great game. 

I was expecting a regular platformer (Raymond legends types) game but actually this is a very creative and phenomenal looking game.

That Psi-King level was really amazing, mushroom filled visions and overall great level design. This game really outperformed my all expectations.

Good followup game to Psychonauts..
Sometimes little confusing, still a better successor

Excellent game. The voice acting is especially remarkable to me. (especially since I am also a fan of the TV series Invader Zim)

The game itself is not just fun to play, but I also appreciated the humor and storyline.

I am hoping for a sequel or at the very least DLC so that we can continue the story and explore the characters more.

Such an amazing game. Absolutely worthy as a sequel. The graphics are great and so are the soundeffets, music, characters, voice acting, level design, storyline and so on. It is just fun to play and so honest and witty. The writing is brilliant. The right amount of fun and seriousness. There is so much creativity and attention to detail in this game. I can't think of anything to criticize. Maybe the second half where you can't roam around freely anymore and have to do one level after another. Also, I had a hard time following the plot, but that could be just me.
Shut up and take my money! What a fantastic game - stop reading reviews and buy this now!
I didn't think they'd match the first Psychonauts, but they out-did it! I laughed, I cried, I WTF'd... Fantastic game.

I really enjoyed this. I loved Psychonauts and the sequel is an even better and longer adventure. It's still not a super long. I completed it 100% in 35 hrs. I highly recommend this game for anyone that enjoyed the original or enjoys platforms, and quirky, but well written humor and storylines.

applist.name: DayZ
applist.detailed_description:
Join our Discord


About the Game

This is your Story


There are no map markers, daily quests, or scoreboards to help you create your story. There is only Chernarus – 230 square kilometers of post-Soviet country that was struck by an unknown virus, which turned the majority of its population into raging infected.

Your task? To survive the collapse of civilization for as long as you possibly can. Keep in mind that death is permanent in unforgiving Chernarus. All you’ll have when you start over again are the memories of your final mistake.

Meet Others


Up to 60 players are struggling to survive by any means necessary at any given time. Make friends, kill on sight, build a base, or risk being betrayed over a can of tasty beans. Use VOIP to interact with other players however you see fit. Every encounter is meaningful when your life is always on the line. Be wary. Stay alert. Trust no one.

Survive Chernarus


The infected aren’t the only ones you need to worry about – there’s also the wildlife and elements. Evade packs of wolves and frenzied bears, find shelter from the punishing rain, search for light in the darkness of night. You’ll also need to master complex survival mechanics concerning your hunger, thirst, body temperature, and more.

Loot Up


Always make sure your gear is ready. Patch up damaged clothes, craft improvised items, and head out to deceptively dead cities to scavenge for valuable resources. Fix a car and hide it in your secret base under a cover of well-placed traps. Step into contaminated zones if you dare and keep your eyes peeled for precious loot. Don’t forget that you won’t get far without a full hazard suit and gas mask.

Take your Shot


Intense PvP action can break out anywhere at any time, especially in hotspots like abandoned military bases, where heart-pounding firefights are all the rage. Some survivors want your loot, others are simply hunting for sport. Then there are those who are afraid you’ll shoot first. Learn how to fight and know when the time has come to swallow your pride and flee. One bullet can change absolutely everything. Always watch your back.

Install Mods


Head on over to the Steam Workshop and find a customized server that fits. Join an active community of like-minded players and modify your DayZ experience to suit your taste. Browse thousands of fan-made features, maps, and guns – all of which are easily managed directly from the game launcher.
applist.about_the_game:
This is your Story


There are no map markers, daily quests, or scoreboards to help you create your story. There is only Chernarus – 230 square kilometers of post-Soviet country that was struck by an unknown virus, which turned the majority of its population into raging infected.

Your task? To survive the collapse of civilization for as long as you possibly can. Keep in mind that death is permanent in unforgiving Chernarus. All you’ll have when you start over again are the memories of your final mistake.

Meet Others


Up to 60 players are struggling to survive by any means necessary at any given time. Make friends, kill on sight, build a base, or risk being betrayed over a can of tasty beans. Use VOIP to interact with other players however you see fit. Every encounter is meaningful when your life is always on the line. Be wary. Stay alert. Trust no one.

Survive Chernarus


The infected aren’t the only ones you need to worry about – there’s also the wildlife and elements. Evade packs of wolves and frenzied bears, find shelter from the punishing rain, search for light in the darkness of night. You’ll also need to master complex survival mechanics concerning your hunger, thirst, body temperature, and more.

Loot Up


Always make sure your gear is ready. Patch up damaged clothes, craft improvised items, and head out to deceptively dead cities to scavenge for valuable resources. Fix a car and hide it in your secret base under a cover of well-placed traps. Step into contaminated zones if you dare and keep your eyes peeled for precious loot. Don’t forget that you won’t get far without a full hazard suit and gas mask.

Take your Shot


Intense PvP action can break out anywhere at any time, especially in hotspots like abandoned military bases, where heart-pounding firefights are all the rage. Some survivors want your loot, others are simply hunting for sport. Then there are those who are afraid you’ll shoot first. Learn how to fight and know when the time has come to swallow your pride and flee. One bullet can change absolutely everything. Always watch your back.

Install Mods


Head on over to the Steam Workshop and find a customized server that fits. Join an active community of like-minded players and modify your DayZ experience to suit your taste. Browse thousands of fan-made features, maps, and guns – all of which are easily managed directly from the game launcher.
applist.short_description: How long can you survive a post-apocalyptic world? A land overrun with an infected "zombie" population, where you compete with other survivors for limited resources. Will you team up with strangers and stay strong together? Or play as a lone wolf to avoid betrayal? This is DayZ – this is your story.

reviews.review: After a few hours I managed to steal all the food and guns from all the houses in the city, killed 6 people, took their clothes, smoked weed and then i went back home to eat what i found. Then i got bored and hopped on dayz with my kitten and had the best experience of my life. 10/10 recommend it
Hands down one of the best games I have ever played. It gives you a unique survival experience that no other game has came close to replicating. 10/10
2k hours had some fun

Game is about a decade old and the zombies still glitchily bounce around, phase through doors, walls, you and your attacks. Gunshots don't register, suppressed shots pull every zombie with a 20 km radius. Zombie path finding is absurd, you run through the woods, through 15 buildings across a river and over a mountain and the zombie chasing you is on your ass and not even broken a sweat. Loot spawn sucks. You get hungry / die of starvation way too quickly. Trying to constantly repair your gear sucks. Weapons break after 5 swings/shots. Sickness sucks, in the "cold" for 2 seconds? Fatally ill. The new sprain/broken leg system sucks, get hit by one zombie? Broken leg, wince and blurred screen with every step. Oh and good f**king luck finding a vehicle.

Game is just laborious.  After all this time they've made it prettier, it gets good frame rates. But what does it matter when the core game is still ass.
zombies. rain. pain.
You'll need at least an entire day to figure out how to play unmodded. Combat mechanics feel ancient.
If you ask a DayZ player if DayZs gameplay is fun they get mad

Played this game a few years back with a friend. Found it to be a buggy mess and mostly a grind with a frustrating UI. Now, years later, I'm playing it with friends I'm finding it to be a buggy mess with frustrating UI. This feels like a game made by people that hate people who play games. There's very little fun about finding an item only for it to break and be useless after fighting 3 zombies or opening 2 cans of food. 2/10 and that feels generous.
its a trap, don't do it.
very nice i ran 50km to find a gun without mag and only on bullet i run another 50km to find a guy with full gear i got killed then i run another 50 km a very nice game good for your legs
fire game
Can't even find rocks.
Do not trust anyone!
great game
Only good if you play with friends.When u play alone u can play for max 2h and get borred so fast.Overall good game,still best survival game
Played this game ever since the original release (way back when) It has its problems but its like no other survival game out there and it offers a very unique gaming experience <3

I've been playing this game since the first weeks. It was a shame at the time. Most of my friends got disgusted by the bugs poor contents etc BUT with (many, many) years passing, it became stable, with better content and a pretty fair balance in the loot economy, PVE / PVP challenges etc. I still love to play it from time to time, Chernarus is beautiful and whomever loves sandbox games may love this one.
It's been 10 years since the last time I've launched this game. It's still janky AF.
I got to eat a human. YUMMY
it good

applist.name: Killing Floor 2
applist.detailed_description:
Just Updated

Happy Holidays! Just in time for Xmas we're excited to bring you the Polar Distress Update for Killing Floor 2! Details below...


Blood & Bonfires Update

Happy Halloween! The Killing Floor 2 Blood & Bonfires Update is here! Details below...


Tidal Terror Update

The 2022 Killing Floor 2 Summer Update and Event is here! Read all about TIDAL TERROR below...


Chop 'Til You Drop Xmas Update

The Killing Floor 2 Chop 'Til You Drop Xmas Update is here! Details below:


Day Of The Zed Update

The Killing Floor 2: Day Of The Zed Update is here just in time for Halloween! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Interstellar Insanity Update

The Killing Floor 2: Interstellar Insanity Update is here just in time for Summer! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Dystopian Devastation Update

The Killing Floor 2: Dystopian Devastation Update is here just in time for Spring! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Digital Deluxe Edition


KILLING FLOOR 2 Digital Deluxe Edition adds the following to the base game:

  • DJ Scully character, with unique voice pack and set of face/body skins
  • Additional cosmetic items (each with multiple selectable variants):
  • “Scullyphones” headphones for DJ Scully, Mr Foster, Hayato Tanaka and Donovan Neal
  • 3D Glasses for Ana Larive and Hayato Tanaka
  • Bowler Hat for Mr. Foster and Reverend Alberts
  • Tom Banner and the Zweihander
  • Classic Masterson
  • Classic Briar
  • Oisten Jaegerhorn
  • Anton Strasser
  • Killing Floor 2 Soundtrack
  • Killing Floor 2 Digital Artbook

AND a copy of the first Killing Floor!


About the Game

In KILLING FLOOR 2, players descend into continental Europe where the outbreak caused by Horzine Biotech’s failed experiment has quickly spread and gained unstoppable momentum, essentially paralyzing the European Union— Just one month after the events in the original KILLING FLOOR, the specimen clones are everywhere and civilization is in disarray; communications have failed, governments have collapsed, and military forces have been systematically eradicated. The people of Europe know survival and self-preservation too well and lucky survivors have gone into hiding.

Not all have given up hope though... A group of civilians and mercenaries have banded together to combat the outbreak and established privately funded operation bases across Europe. Upon tracking specimen clone outbreaks, players will descend into zed-laden hot zones and exterminate them.

KEY FEATURES:

• Visceral Gore - KILLING FLOOR 2 ramps up the gore with a proprietary, high powered persistent blood system bringing new levels of fidelity to the genre. Players will send entrails, severed limbs, and blood flying as they wade through hordes of enemies. But they need to watch out! If caught, enemies will rip them, and their entire party limb from limb


• 6 player co-op or solo play— A multitude of varied playable characters await for players to choose from as they enter the fray in online co-op mode or solo mode for those willing to brave the horrific specimens alone


• Versus Survival Game Mode - Be the Zed! A 12 player PvP mode where two teams take turns playing Humans vs. Zeds in a pair of short matches. In the first match, one team plays Humans and the other Zeds until the humans all die during a single round or they beat the boss. For the second match the teams switch sides and when the battle is completed both teams receive a score based on their performance and the higher score wins!


• Terrifying Zeds - New enemies and fan favorites from the original game are back with expanded and smarter artificial intelligence, dishing out powerful attacks, working as a group to weaken the player’s party and pushing the challenge level and fear factor to new levels


• Unique Blend Of Weaponry - From modern militaristic assault rifles, brutal improvised makeshift weapons, classic historical guns, and off the wall “Mad Scientist” weapons, KILLING FLOOR 2 has a unique blend of killing tools that will satisfy any gamer


• Expanded Perk System - Perks from the original game have been reimagined with more added to the fold. All perks now progress with meaningful talent choices that amplify different play styles, giving players a progression path that is expansive and full of rewarding milestones


• Brutal Melee Combat - KILLING FLOOR 2 reinvents melee combat completely. Players now have control over the type of melee attacks they can perform, enabling them to deliver bone-breaking crippling attacks to Zeds


• Zed Time - Be the action hero you know you are! Zed Time returns to Killing Floor 2 better than ever, kicking everything into slow motion giving you that precious time you need to destroy the oncoming horde while watching your weapons at work in glorious high framerate

KILLING FLOOR 2 Digital Deluxe Edition adds the following to the base game:
  • DJ Scully character, with unique voice pack and set of face/body skins
  • Additional cosmetic items (each with multiple selectable variants):
  • “Scullyphones” headphones for DJ Scully, Mr Foster, Hayato Tanaka and Donovan Neal
  • 3D Glasses for Ana Larive and Hayato Tanaka
  • Bowler Hat for Mr. Foster and Reverend Alberts
  • Tom Banner and the Zweihander
  • Classic Masterson
  • Classic Briar
  • Oisten Jaegerhorn
  • Anton Strasser
  • Killing Floor 2 Soundtrack
  • Killing Floor 2 Digital Artbook

AND a copy of the first Killing Floor!

applist.name: Going Medieval
applist.detailed_description:
EARLY ACCESS ROADMAP


About the Game

STAKE YOUR CLAIM


In the world of Going Medieval, dark age society is on its knees. At the end of the 14th century, 95% of the global population has perished due to rampant plague.

Eventually, survivors emerge from society’s ashes, and it’s now up to you to help them settle in a dangerous new land reclaimed by nature. Build your people a home, help shape their lives, and protect them from animals, bandits, and other dangers in a lawless post-calamity age.

BUILD YOUR FORTRESS


Design, build and expand your settlement from a small wooden hut into a colossal stone castle. With simple-to-use 3D terrain tools you can create the perfect stronghold, from winding underground caverns to sprawling multi-story forts.

DEFEND YOUR COLONY


This harsh new world is rife with external threats, but you can give your colonists the upper hand in battle by building impenetrable defences and traps. Research, craft and equip weapons and gear so that they can fight back against unrelenting waves of attackers.

PROTECT YOUR VILLAGERS


Your colonists have more than just raids to contend with. They need protection from starvation and the elements, so it’s essential to stock up on supplies and build shelter to keep them fed and warm. Maintain your villagers’ emotional states, as their moods are affected if their needs and wants aren’t met.

SHAPE YOUR STORY


Grow the population of your settlement by helping out strangers in dangerous situations, or by taking in like-minded travellers. Your villagers have personal histories and agendas, and you can get to know them by observing their behaviour and relationships with others.

reviews.review:
This WOULD be a good game - but this is where the Steam review system fails because you can't "rate" the game.  You have to give it a 100% thumbs up or a 100% thumbs down when most opinions should be a 1-10 rating or even a percentile number.  This "social media" crap forces people to give carte blanche  "likes"  to games in a black and white manner - Steam ought to be ashamed of itself for being so sophomoric in its rating system.

I WOULD give this game around a 75% approval.  

But the devs ruined the game with cold snaps.  I hate cold snaps so much that I probably won't ever play this game again unless there is an option to disable them.  

I've been playing computer games since there WERE computer games back in the 70s.  And I can safely say that cold snaps in this game are easily within the top 5 WORST things I've ever seen in a game.  Not because cold snaps are difficult - because there's nothing you can do about them.  Which is why they suck so much. 

Essentially, getting a cold snap means you put the game on maximum speed - then you go do something else for half an hour.  Go have some sex.  Make some food.  Walk the dog.  Go call your mom.  But you won't be playing the game.  Because there's nothing you can do.  

Your settlers will just keel over unconscious the moment they go outside.  You're liable to have almost every last settler lying around outside.  You can easily lose your entire village through this stupidity.  

All you can do is take your hands off your keyboard, off your mouse - and hope the AI doesn't get all of your settlers killed.  Because YOU no longer matter.  The game may as well play itself.  

Until the devs fix the utter stupid trash that are cold snaps, the game isn't really worth playing unless you just like torturing yourself.  I'm not saying that cold snaps are impossible to survive - no you can survive them.  It's just a question of whether its really worth your time.  For me, I'd rather being playing a game that doesn't try to kill your settlers for doing nothing more than leaving their goddamn houses.   

I'm only giving this game a "thumbs up"  because Steam hasn't figured out yet that games are too complicated and subjective to saddle the players with an "all or nothing" review system.  Reviewing a game shouldn't be as banal and vapid as "liking" a kitten video - but apparently Steam thinks that you either LIKE a game 100% or HATE a game 100%.

Long story short: the game is literally medieval Rimworld in 3D with map levels mechanic from Dwarf Fortress. 

Exactly the type of game I was looking for. Game is still in development and getting frequent updates but at the current state it is 100% playable. If you looking for colony builder in medieval setting - this is the game for you. Love it.

First off, I'd like to mention that I've been with GM since near the beginning. I've seen it from the start, and I feel like it's been going in a direction I didn't expect nor buy the game in "early access" for. Second, this is NOT a castle-building game. This is a sim game and is only becoming more and more of one. There aren't any Castle type of structures. You can *build* a Castle, but it won't really look like one. None of that has changed since the beginning; although, they did add ladders somewhat recently, but the main focus has been on quality of life stuff, and more ways to micro-manage processes and your villagers.

    I've waited for long stints hoping the broken stuff would be fixed after the wait, or new things would be added, but it never was. It's been several years, and yes, they've added new things, but the original stuff is still broken. Settler pathing, building, hauling, and anything really is so broken that you can't just get to a point and sit back to watch a masterpiece or job well done. It requires constant over-watch and management, and only more of that has been added with stuff like the "quality of life" update where you have to pay attention to how the settlers feel about each other, themselves, or their work/living space. It's becoming so tedious and micro-managing that it's a chore. It takes so long to get anything substantial done because everything you do is a grind that takes even longer than it should because the AI is so broken. 

    Some problems with this non-strategy game is that the AI is still as broken as ever. They have to work so much on it, that you won't get a lot of new stuff except for every now and then. The AI will build themselves in when building layers of wall so badly that you have to be strategic with how you build whenever you want something fairly thick or more than one story off the ground. I've had settlers get stuck in the corner because they built the walls around it, and they can't travel diagonally like that; thus, you have to constantly oversee and micromanage, adding only a few blueprints at a time. Yeah, you can build some "pretty cool looking-stuff," but your options are disparagingly small. There is also a limit to how high you can go, so if you were wanting to replicate some tall buildings, you either can't, or you'll have to not build it to scale. 

   If you're into sims, you might like this, but like I said, the AI is broken. Furthermore, much of the player-base has gotten sentimental with the animals and everything else, so they want to have item after item for them, or they want to add more ways to micromanage. I really don't know what the devs want in the end, but it does seem like they're going for a full on sim. Either way, it will take a very long time for them to even get to the end of their "road-map" of things that they plan to add as main parts of the game. 

     The combat is another somewhat broken thing. I've heard people complain about settlers not moving when commanded, and that can get them killed. The enemy isn't overpowered at all, but they have "moving trebuchets", that wreck your hard work very easily, and they have no counter. Some of the player base don't want the player to have stuff either because then it would be even easier to cheese combat than it is now, but combat currently is just this really tedious thing where archers are supreme. By the way Foxy Voxel, trebuchets Don't move! Those are catapults. Thank you! 

Bottom-line. If you want a castle-building game that isn't a sim, then don't buy the game. If you like sims, you may like this, but it's currently broken, so I'd recommend waiting or getting it on sale. I kind of wish I could recommend the game because the devs do seem to be working hard on it, but I can't because it's broken, you'll get bored fast, and it's not my cup of tea. I actually regret getting it because it wasn't actually fun.

"Wait, this just looks like a clone of Rimworld! Does having just one more dimension even make it worth the money?" 

yea

[b]Version:[/b] v0.14.15
[b]Score:[/b] 6/10
[b]Value:[/b] Moderate
[b]Recommendation:[/b] Wait for a 50% sale

[h1]Preface[/h1]
Two house keeping items to take care of before getting into the review. First, the "early access" tag is not a valid excuse for the plethora of issues still plaguing the game. The point of the tag is to allow devs with a functional prototype (i.e. a working product in alpha or beta) to generate additional revenue to finish the initial full release of a game. See Baldur's Gate III for a good example of a valid "early access" title.

Second, the roadmap is not a valid excuse for lack of core mechanics. It's rather unfortunate and frustrating the trend developers seem to follow by including their core mechanics in a "roadmap" as a method for enticing players to stick around after making an initial purchase. A roadmap is intended to - as the name suggests - map out planned features that are not critical to the base value and functionality of the game.

The review will be in bullet format to properly express my thoughts without unnecessary fluff text. Keep in mind that as updates are released, aspects of this review may become obsolete and should only be referenced for the current major game version.

[b]This review may be updated following major releases, but no guarantees are made[/b]

[h1]Missing Core Mechanics[/h1]
This section is intended to outline base mechanics which are vital for gameplay in a colony sim that heavily utilizes AI storytelling.
[list]
[*]Flammability (hazards in general)
[*]POIs (i.e. tombs, broken towers, abandoned homes, etc.)
[*]Workshop support
[*]Combat counterplay (trebuchets still don't have a counter, and archers are still overpowered in most scenarios)
[*]Colonist relationships
[*]World Traversal
[*]Imprisonment (necessary for accumulating extra pawns outside of random chance)
[*]Debug mode (critical for fixing game breaking bugs, such as pawns disappearing)
[*]Map configuration
[*]Fluids (think of lakes as an example)
[/list]


[h1]Current Issues[/h1]
Going Medieval still hosts several core issues that make either make the game feel like a grind or infuriating to deal with.
[list]
[*]Job/Priorities - Choosing to mine a tile further away than the one next to them. Hunting is even worse with pawns constantly needing to reacquire their target.
[*]Combat - Pawns have ~0.5s delay between executing commands
[*]Temperature - Multi-story buildings turn into saunas during the summer (noted by devs)
[*]Pathing/Spawning - The game regularly fails to check whether there are valid paths from the edge of the map to the settlement before spawning events
[*]Pathing/Jobs - Pawns will still routinely get stuck in holes if given a blanket mine command
[*]Building/Priority - Pawns will build multi-story buildings in a seemingly random order rather than layer by layer despite sufficient stability (results in longer than average build times)
[*]Building/Construction - Cannon replace already constructed components, the player must first deconstruct and then construct the new/upgraded component
[*]Attributes Tab - Messy UI design that conveys critical information about pawns into a tiny window in one blob
[*]Settings/Configuration - Lack of control over storytelling aspects alongside missing keybind options
[/list]

[h1]Positives[/h1]
Despite the overall critical review, Going Medieval is groundbreaking in other aspects.

[list]
[*]Building System is implemented well and functions without any issues or frustration
[*]Ability to change the aesthetic of already placed components
[*]Seamless connections between build pieces
[*]16 layer build height with half steps to provide easier navigation between layers
[*]6 levels of job priorities that allow for precise pawn management
[*]Complex attributes system - similar to Rimworld - that introduces a level of complexity to gameplay which feels natural
[*]Control over pawns' attire, meals, and drug usage policies
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Going Medieval started off as a clone of RimWorld with the z-levels mod, but lacked most of the features RimWorld has. However, it's both unfair and dishonest to make the claim that Going Medieval is a RimWorld clone as the game has progressed to a point where the two are artistically and functionally different. Some UI elements still exist that are direct rips from RimWorld (namely the job priorities tab), but core features seem to implement entirely unique approaches that are non-existent in base RimWorld.

Despite everything that has been implemented so far, Going Medieval is vastly overpriced for the amount of gameplay it offers with lack of any kind of modding support. After 2 or 3 playthroughs, most scenarios will start to feel repetitive as you repeat much of the same gameplay elements with almost no variation whatsoever. The harsh reality is that the publisher is selling a $15 USD game for $25 USD while hiding behind the "early access" title to shield themselves from proper criticisms.

The only time I can recommend buying this game is if it goes on sale for 50% off, at least until the current roadmap is filled out.

Despite playing for a couple hours and rather enjoying myself, I can't comfortably recommend this game. It's not bad by any means and if you like a relatively calm and slow game, this may be for you. This review is written by someone that played games like Farthest Frontier, Oxygen Not Included and many tower defense games. With an initial look, this game seems perfect for someone like me.

Four things, however, killed the game for me : lack of depht, odd progression, micromanagement hell and bugs. Oh yes, bugs. Now, the last one is to be expected from a game on Early Access, so I'd be fine with starting a new game and trying it all over again (which I did plenty of times in Oxygen Not Included). But the first three were quite impactful.

First, the game is quite simple. You collect some resources, put together a couple buildings and then repeat. And then if the gods are feeling particularly spiteful that day, you may get a looter attack. That's it. Coming from games in which you have to establish gathering and production chains, this feels quite different. Not bad, but it's something to be noted. What more could be added? More variety in attacking forces, more natural events, resource nodes on the map that encourage building further from the initial point, and so on.

Second, the game lacks meaningful progression. In games like these, I feel like the idea of "ages" is a good concept. Make researches that are more meaningful, and that unlock more side researches. Add interesting names to them, and make it so that they actually unlock something new, rather than just making it so that you can craft yourself something that was already available. In short, it feels like the progression of the game just isn't there. You start with few citizens, and that barely changes (and depending on your choices it doesn't, which can be a good thing if you want a small village). You start with pretty much no weapons, and after many researches you can put together the same kind of weapons you get from looters from early days. Even after hunting for years, the same villager misses 90% of their attacks, and so on. The game needs to have more flashy progression. And having to recover "lost knowledge" is awful. I get it, but it's an awful mechanic.

And lastly, micromanagemnt. I understand that making settlers "smart" is hard and subjective. But they feel immensively helpless. Some improvements would be : get the closest material, not ANY available material. Please. There are always going to be many different materials sources, since settlers seem to not care about carrying the materials they just harvested to a centralized warehouse. And also, make hunters smarter. I quit the game after having to every day manually select which animal to hunt. It's painful. Add a system in which they search for prey. It's the bare minimum.

To finalize, the game's idea is wonderful. I don't want to make it seem like this is a bad game. It's lovely and it's something I'll keep an eye on. And I had fun, quite a bit. If the game improves on those aspects, I'll come back, and even change the review. But for now, I don't recommend the game.
Very fun game. heavily recommend it. wish maps could be a little larger and that you could copy and paste buildings. other than that fun game
More like medieval Sims3 than a city builder

This game is great, but there is a few flaws that haven't been ironed out yet. The developers have done a great job of making a game that feels like its own but using ideas from other great games to help make this one unique. Overall if you like a game where you can relax and build or have battles this is the one for you. If you want fast pace action then pass on this. I give this game a solid 7 out of 10.
Fun game.  Building is a lot of fun and so are the battles!

Typical Early Access problem: Good foundation, content bare, absolutely glacial pace of updates.

I played a few hours when I bought it and thought "wow I can't wait for this to get some updates"
Around 18 months passed before I played it again and there's only a few more boxes checked off on the roadmap. It's fun, but so shallow. I'll come back in another 18 months.

It has high potential, but at the moment, many semifinished systems killing the fun in my opinion:
First the good things: the idea of 3d building of a medieval settlement is really nice, and you become proud of your build (and sometimes even beautiful) structures. 
but now the sad part: :-(
the temp. system keeps only warmth in, not coldness. so you have to dig like a mole to the ground to keep your food fresh. But the cellar had to be with dirt walls and twig floor, because of the random set heat isolation factors:
Walls: dirt 0%, wood 60% , clay 93%,stone 70% and stonebricks 75%
Floors: dirt 0% (but pushes rotting), wood 94%, twigs 40%, stone 70% and stonebricks 90% 
Buildingactions: your settlers often fix themselves in a wall or digging all fields arround them and than starve on their created "Pile of idiocracy". I don´t wanna know how often they will burn themselves to ashes, when the feature gets implemented^^
terraforming: there often spawn some resources from digging through vains. and the settlers often dig from above. when the mats are spawning in the hole, and there is no path on the same ground lvl. Now you have to build a ramp or a pathway, to get the stuff away from there, because it blocks the filling of the hole. 
Tasks: the settlers have only a small amount of "task-categories". So "cooking" means foodmaking, butchering, fermentation, smoking. But often your dead animals rots to pieces and you have no food, because high chief Jolanda is running thrugh the whole map to pick up some berries to make wine^^

I was really sad after I realized, how often I had to fix stupid behavior of my settlers. 
But maybe, I just have to high expectations, because of my expierience of (modded) rimworld. I hope. the ultimate castle building/settlement simulator of my dreams will come true, when I test it aggain in a few months. I wish for the developers, which created a cool basement with enormous potential

Needs work and has been in early access too long.

Content bare and has tons of irritating bugs like goats going into the house to eat people food instead of eating the goat food put in their pen.
Fun game, Very good ambient effect, game look so good :D  compare to its very small size space requirement
some minor bugs, biggest thing I'd like to see is an easier to use camera system. great fun overall and will probably be one of my most played games over time.

applist.name: Assassin's Creed® Syndicate
applist.detailed_description:
Gold Edition

The Gold Edition includes the Standard Edition and the Season Pass.


About the Game

London, 1868. In the heart of the Industrial Revolution, lead your underworld organization and grow your influence to fight those who exploit the less privileged in the name of progress:

  • Champion justice
    As Jacob Frye, a young and reckless Assassin, use your skills to help those trampled by the march of progress. From freeing exploited children used as slave labour in factories, to stealing precious assets from enemy boats, you will stop at nothing to bring justice back to London’s streets.

  • Command London’s underworld
    To reclaim London for the people, you will need an army. As a gang leader, strengthen your stronghold and rally rival gang members to your cause, in order to take back the capital from the Templars’ hold.

  • A new dynamic fighting system
    In Assassin’s Creed Syndicate, action is fast-paced and brutal. As a master of combat, combine powerful multi-kills and countermoves to strike your enemies down.

  • A whole new arsenal
    Choose your own way to fight enemies. Take advantage of the Rope Launcher technology to be as stealthy as ever and strike with your Hidden Blade. Or choose the kukri knife and the brass knuckles to get the drop on your enemies.

  • A new age of transportation
    In London, the systemic vehicles offer an ever-changing environment. Drive carriages to chase your target, use your parkour skills to engage in epic fights atop high-speed trains, or make your own way amongst the boats of the River Thames.

  • A vast open world
    Travel the city at the height of the Industrial Revolution and meet iconic historical figures. From Westminster to Whitechapel, you will come across Darwin, Dickens, Queen Victoria… and many more.

  • A sharper focus
    Take aim, engage in combat or launch a grappling hook by keeping your target in sight with Tobii Eye Tracking. The Clean UI lets you focus on the matter at hand while the Extended View and Dynamic Light features increase your immersion, making you dive even deeper into the thrilling adventure in the streets of London.
    Compatible with all Tobii Eye Tracking gaming devices.

    ----
    Additional notes:
    Eye tracking features available with Tobii Eye Tracking.
