reviews.review: Game might be fine... no idea because can't get the uPlay service to run. Went through the rigmarole of creating an account, but the launcher bombs out every time. Unhelpful error messages - apparently it can't connect, but there's no problem with anything else on my PC connecting. There are loads of posts online about having this issue with a raft of different people suggesting different solutions, which seem to work for some and not others and range up to completely reinstalling your OS. Not worth the effort. Uninstalled.

One of the first novelties in Assassin's Creed: Syndicate is precisely the duo of protagonists, Jacob and Evie Frye. Brother and sister are introduced to us as already initiated into the ranks of the Assassins, thus sparing tedious prologues and investing precious time in characterization that is all in all well done, and, above all, functional in context. Although undoubtedly stereotypical - impulsive and restless he, more thoughtful and pragmatic she - the two embody very well the two souls of the proposed gameplay, and above all they live a relationship based on an entertaining chemistry of constant bickering and contrasts. The plot pits them against an insane and idealistic Templar, who is convinced that he can turn London into a "paradise" by settling internal turmoil with violence and exploiting the flourishing of industry to subjugate the souls. The atmosphere is fascinating, and in its own way (fanta)historically convincing, although the chain of events leading up to the finale has no particular twists. What works more than anything else is the characterization of the individual characters, which also goes to include historical figures of the period, including Dickens, Darwin, Marx, and Queen Victoria. Although the latter's are only unlocked once the story is completed, this quartet of characters (reproduced with particular verve and a touch of humor) will ensure a good overall number of "memories" to be experienced parallel to the nine sequences of the main campaign, providing a nice cross-section of London at the height of industrialization. So if the validity of the glimpse was already confirmed from the first appearances of the game, what is striking is the excellent characterization work done on the historical moment, narrated on the streets of a city that at the time really represented "the center of the world." The gangs, the cultural, technological and political restlessness, the unstoppable expansionism. An industrious empire but also full of contrasts, between the first technological marvels and the brutality of the slums. The good reproduction is complemented by a thorough level design work, offering interesting paths to exploit through traditional parkour: as for the latter, compared to Unity there is an improvement in the fluidity of the animations and in the recognition of the controls, with a latching on to the handholds that still generates some headaches in some frantic moments, but it rediscovers itself to be more accurate.
The two separate buttons for ascent and descent, to which moreover we have become accustomed by now, return, flanked by a brand new feature, namely the grappling hook. The latter can be used either to rise in a matter of seconds or to stretch a rope between two points so that it can be used to move quickly from one building to another. Although it makes the task easier when it comes to escaping from enemy alerts, the tool proves to be a lot of fun to use during the action, and it alternates very naturally with the

AC Syndicate is almost 8 years old this year, but it's still a great game. The performance and graphics on PC is really good. This game is one of the classics in the ac universe. I would definitely recommend playing it even now.

This is one of the best assassins creed games.
The fact that you can change beetween Evie and Jacob makes the game idea relly unique
Cool as cucumber, great as kebab
I like AC, and this is that... unlike some games called AC.

Aslında güzel oyun. Sadece parkur mekanikleri biraz düstursuz. Klasik bir Ubisoft oyunu, işleyiş aynı. Görevler açıkçası çok zevkli, hızlıdan Jacob ile güzel bir oyun tadı aldım. Aşırı yapmacık ve zorlama Evie ile saçma diyalogları baysa da, katlanılabilir bir oyun.

Syndicate betrays more traditional AC elements than it is loyal to. Jacob and Evie are already assassins when we meet them, so it’s not an origin story like Black Flag or Unity. Even so, their immaturity is reminiscent of those very games. 

The game allows you to play as both Jacob and Evie, to alternate between them outside and during some missions. I like that they aren’t just the same character gameplay wise, Jacob specialises in combat, while Evie in stealth, but Jacob is annoying. Unfortunately, for some reason, the game wants you to play as Jacob more and towards the end, most main missions are played as him. Evie deserves more screen time. The romance between Evie and Henry would have been acceptable if not for its lazy writing.

Syndicate’s Victorian London matches Unity’s Revolutionary Paris in attention to detail. However, unlike Paris, London’s tone is less on inequality between classes and more on how it was just a horrible place to live in in general. The city is monotonous enough that this message is successfully conveyed, yet has enough depth to make it interesting. The sky is polluted with smoke from factories in which children work and crime is rampant, yet through enough exploration, you’ll find people playing cricket, kids playing football, and couples taking photos. The game manages to draw a city so depressing and lifeless yet so immersive and full of life, and it looks incredible. Its size can be intimidating though, I found myself fast travelling a lot compared to in Unity.

However, London is not fit for parkour. Its buildings are too far apart and its streets are too wide. Without the rope launcher, which doesn’t even work right half the time, it would be impossible to traverse through usual AC means. At the same time, the rope launcher also takes away from the parkour experience. Other than that, parkour is further simplified and doesn’t have the same charm as its predecessor. Carriages give life to the city, and are nice to ride recreationally, but not very functional in chases and carriage-fights. 

I have mixed feelings about the combat. It looks amazing; the violent successive punches, cuts, stabs and revolver shots as well as the brass knuckles, cane-swords and kukri fit perfectly with the setting of Victorian London. My problem with it is there seems to be no rhythm to it. I don’t know how long it’s going to take to kill an enemy, or how many hits it takes to deal damage to an enemy. Other than that, I didn’t have a problem with the levelling system or the skill tree. Stealth is improved. The kidnapping mechanic is fun, albeit unrealistic.

My biggest gripe is how the game doesn't take itself seriously. What could be important and emotionally heavy scenes are often interrupted by bad jokes, both in the historical setting and modern-day. There’s little emotional connection between the twins and the story, the missions, or the city and that reduces the gravity of the story the game is trying to tell. We know that their father was an assassin operating in London, but all the game does with his character is use him as argument fuel between the twins, and the game completely forgot about George, whose orders the twins defy in the first place to end up in London. The game just doesn’t feel like a main AC game.

Syndicate isn’t a bad game, but is definitely the worst AC game I’ve played so far. 

5/10

Turn V-Sync on

This game is a choice between a well-paced story or a compelling story. Doing all open world activities first, then doing the story kept me more engaged in the story but the pacing completely fell apart. The game does not do enough to guide players through tasks.

Regardless, the story is strong, despite the modern-era stuff, and the gameplay is pretty solid too. It took a while to get used to having 2 characters, but once you get the hang of it, the extra character really helps add variety into otherwise well-worn gameplay systems.

applist.name: Resident Evil 7 Biohazard
applist.detailed_description:
Demo now available!


About the Game

Resident Evil 7 biohazard is the next major entry in the renowned Resident Evil series and sets a new course for the franchise as it leverages its roots and opens the door to a truly terrifying horror experience. A dramatic new shift for the series to first person view in a photorealistic style powered by Capcom’s new RE Engine, Resident Evil 7 delivers an unprecedented level of immersion that brings the thrilling horror up close and personal.

Set in modern day rural America and taking place after the dramatic events of Resident Evil® 6, players experience the terror directly from the first person perspective. Resident Evil 7 embodies the series’ signature gameplay elements of exploration and tense atmosphere that first coined “survival horror” some twenty years ago; meanwhile, a complete refresh of gameplay systems simultaneously propels the survival horror experience to the next level.

reviews.review:
[h1][b]"Resident Evil 7: A Heart-Pounding Nightmare That Keeps Me Hooked... I am still playing!"[/b][/h1]

[b]Resident Evil 7 isn't just a game; it's an adrenaline-fueled descent into sheer horror that consumes my every waking moment. From the second I stepped foot into the dilapidated Baker estate, I knew I was in for an experience unlike any other. Gripped by fear and curiosity, I embarked on a journey that continues to haunt my dreams and captivate my gaming soul... and yes, I am still playing.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2974281419
[b]The atmosphere in Resident Evil 7 is nothing short of masterful. The developers have artfully crafted a world that oozes with a palpable sense of dread. Every creaking floorboard, flickering light, and distant moan sends shivers down my spine. The game's first-person perspective immerses me in a waking nightmare, with each corner I turn and every door I open becoming a nerve-wracking gamble. The attention to detail is astounding, making every nook and cranny feel both fascinating and terrifying.[/b]

[b]As I traverse the twisted corridors of the Baker estate, the gameplay mechanics keep me on the edge of my seat. The limited resources and strategic decision-making elevate the tension to unprecedented heights. Every bullet counts, every herb found is a lifeline, and every puzzle solved brings a sigh of relief. The combat mechanics strike a perfect balance between vulnerability and empowerment, as I desperately fight for survival against the grotesque creatures that lurk in the shadows. It's a heart-pounding dance between life and death that never fails to get my adrenaline pumping.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2135401408
[b]Resident Evil 7's narrative is a captivating nightmare that gradually unravels with each blood-soaked discovery. The tale of the Baker family and the mysterious infection that plagues them is a chilling descent into madness and desperation. The game's slow-burning suspense and shocking plot twists keep me constantly engaged, desperate to uncover the truth while dreading what awaits me around the next corner. The hauntingly atmospheric audio design and chilling performances by the voice actors further enhance the immersive experience, making me feel like I'm living the nightmare alongside the characters.[/b]

[b]But what truly sets Resident Evil 7 apart is its commitment to reinventing the franchise while staying true to its roots. The shift to a first-person perspective breathes new life into the series, giving it a fresh and intimate perspective. It's a bold departure that pays off in spades, reinvigorating the Resident Evil formula and delivering a game that's equal parts homage and innovation.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2133912249
[b]It's worth mentioning that I am still playing Resident Evil 7 because of its outstanding replayability. The game offers multiple difficulty levels, unlockable secrets, and alternative paths to explore. Each playthrough feels distinct, offering new challenges and surprises, ensuring that even after the initial fear subsides, I keep coming back for more. It's a testament to the game's quality and the developers' commitment to delivering a truly immersive and lasting experience.[/b]

[b][i]Resident Evil 7 is a harrowing journey into the depths of terror, an experience that grips me tightly and refuses to let go. Its atmospheric brilliance, intense gameplay, and captivating narrative make it a must-play for any horror enthusiast. So join me in the darkness, if you dare, and let Resident Evil 7 consume your soul. Believe me, you'll be playing it long after the lights go out.[/i][/b]

[h1] Review[/h1] 
A lot of people felt that Resident Evil lost its touch. Especially with 5-6 and somewhat 4. For me each game in the mainline franchise felt so completely different, maybe aside 1 and 2, from each other that its hard to say you have to specifically do it like that. While I loved 6 and every mainline Resident Evil game so far in general: This game is a right step into the correct direction for such a game. There aren’t many high quality, bestselling proper horror games out there that aren’t walking simulators.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Capcom took a few core elements of what the main franchise mainly consists of and what people might want or wanted to see in a modern horror game. So, the game is set this time not in a mansion but a relatively large countryside house, together with a guest house and an old structure and then some. It’s a really impressive and most of all; credible place I found myself lost in quickly.

Additionally, they took the franchises puzzle nature and adapted it. I always like this, combining and using items at the correct spot or finding a key that opens up new places or shortcuts. Especially if the game makes you feel smart or gives you an endorphin rush when you find an item you need to proceed further.
Combining the place and the puzzles makes for a relatively twisted horror house scenario, with weird switches, keys and traps around. There are items to find and craft into items you currently want and need or secrets to find in every corner. Exploration is very fun, although after some time a bit tedious due to the main characters relatively low movement speed coupled together with the amount of backtracking. Which isn’t bad but the amount was slightly too much.

The games switch towards a first person perspective is a welcome one, not that I prefer any perspective over the other. I just like variety. Combat itself is fun due to the very strong enemies and very weak main character. You can also block do reduce a lot of incoming damage. Enemy variety is rather mediocre, there are in total 4 enemy types and a couple of different bosses or bossfights which are the highlight for me in this game. There are more unique bossfights than regular enemies. 

In general, the game is highly enjoyable and entertained me from start to finish. There is an infamous section on the boat, mostly because it gives you a relatively weak weapon to fight off enemies and it becomes way much more linear and combat focused compared to the beginning of the game. And the game has the perfect length. A first playthrough will take you from 7-10 hours, a second or third less than 3-5 hours. I especially like how on the unlockable madhouse difficulty not only collectible coins are replaced, but also different items are there to find. An annoying factor is that you cannot skip cutscenes.

[u]Story[/u]
Initially It has absolutely nothing to do with Resident Evil. I feared that it might be a complete reboot, completely disregarding the franchise earlier games but the ending connects it towards it while also hinting for a new game.

The basic idea is that the main characters girlfriend disappeared and he gets an anonymous letter where to find here. When being at the place it turns into a 90s horror flick, hillbilly mad people with somewhat inhumane powers. 

There is also two endings but only one is canon as the non canon one just absolutely makes no sense whatsoever.

[u]Sound[/u]
I always respect it if someone translates and dubs games in a lot of different languages. Capcom always did this and I always appreciate it. Additionally, the soundtrack is barely noticeable. Most of the time you have only environmental sounds. Even the save room theme is barely noticeable. But i liked that they didn't use a mute main protagonist which i don't really like, especially nice that Ethan is a likeable guy.

[u]Graphics[/u]
The game is overly reliant on various filter. These fit to the game especially in the baker property although I can understand why people might dislike the vignette effect that is ramped so much in this game that it became an artstyle choice almost. Atleast the colours aren’t completely undersaturated which is something I absolutely dislike. What I really love are the various small animations the game does when you use an object like cutting the chain or healing.

Character models are rather uncanny which is basically the only type of game where that makes sense to have. Additionally, the game can be tweaked a lot, making it look very great but can also run on any potato. I only disliked the general art direction of the enemies, just black humanoid blops.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
Game does everything right a horror game should do. A neat setting where the main character actually feels dread and is constantly under suspense. Graphics and style choice are great and the game runs really good. Combat is fun and especially the exploration and interconnectivity of the whole baker property is something I really love. Crafting is also a neat and welcome addition. Although I’m not really a fan of the common enemy type opposed to the really awesome boss battles. Also, during the very lategame the game turns rather linear and is more action focused.

8/10 Great game

RE7 is one of the best RE games so far. 
Personally, I did not find it scary. The characters played their part so well, and it felt extremely on point. 
I loved the main story, as well as every single DLC. It felt so good to have a DLC / mode for every character and made it so different, unique and complete. I think Capcom really did a great job with RE7! 

I didn't like how Chris Redfield looked in this game, visually, since it's different from the rest of the games, but it didn't bother me that much since he's a special character which will always be loved and appreciated.

Overall it took me 35h to 100% the game, but despite that, I will still come back to play it some more! Have fun and good luck!

P.S: O'Brian finally released his novel and the Bakers had it in their house. That was so nice to see!

applist.name: Sands of Salzaar
applist.detailed_description:
Feedback Submission

After the DLC version update, we noticed there may be some unexpected bugs happened in this version If you encounter any issue, you can give us feedback throught the collectionhttps://store.steampowered.com/news/app/1094520/view/5131322422014534228 & discord(https://discord.gg/xdindie). , it would be a big help for us to address issues, Thank you!


Discord: https://discord.gg/xdindie
Bug report form: https://forms.gle/uodXNj9Uz6fHEisn9


About the Game

After the DLC version update, we noticed there may be some unexpected bugs happened in this version If you encounter any issue, you can give us feedback throught the collectionhttps://store.steampowered.com/news/app/1094520/view/5131322422014534228 & discord(https://discord.gg/xdindie). , it would be a big help for us to address issues, Thank you!

Into the Desert…

This is a fantastical tale of an exotic land. The Old Empire has fallen, leaving rival tribes to fight for control of the great desert. Little do they know of the seeds of darkness which grow in the shadows with each passing day...

Sands of Salzaar is an open-world strategy-action RPG set across a sprawling desert. Build up and manage your forces from a single unit to a mighty army, then lead them into massive battles against your foes. How you progress is up to you: customize your hero with a wide variety of skills and talents, choose which factions to side with, and plan your strategies carefully to establish yourself as whoever you aspire to be - a lone wolf, a wealthy trader, a city lord, or a war schemer.

V1.0 Game Features

Epic War & Strategy
Customize your abilities to become a martial arts master, powerful archmage, and more. Recruit and train your force with new features like command skills and a fresh system to upgrade units. Lead them into waves of real-time sieges and skirmishes to win.



Explore a Dynamic Open World
Roam across a giant map to encounter various characters, take on quests, enter deadly dungeons for boss fights and loot, amass gold from trading and build up your own cities…Every playthrough makes you stronger and offers new adventures that reflect the decisions you make.



Alliance or Hostility?
Declare war, or make peace and team up with rival factions utilizing diplomacy tactics. V1.0 introduces more diversity to social relationships and tribal affairs across the land, adding AI rebellions, tribal titles and a new Favor system between NPCs.



What’s More in 1.0 Launch
Discover the free-to-explore Sandbox mode, brand-new UI experiences, reworkings of character skills and arms units across the board, more dynamic social relations and Tavern Brawling, magical jewel packs, additional side quests and more!

applist.name: Killer Frequency
applist.detailed_description:
The year is 1987, and as the clock strikes midnight in small-town Gallows Creek, USA, former big city radio DJ Forrest Nash is live on air in what will turn out to be the graveyard shift of a lifetime...

In this horror comedy, you must solve puzzles to save callers from being hunted down by a mysterious killer. Where every call is life and death, can you save the inhabitants of Gallows Creek?

Unique 1st person narrative:

Step into the shoes of a late-night radio talk-show host – new in town and fallen from grace. The Police Chief is dead… so the townsfolk turn to you for help, as apparently you, Forest Nash are the only person in town who can run a phone line.

Real-time decisions and puzzle solving:

Use branching dialogues to interact with a variety of eccentric small-town personalities including potential victims and suspects. Explore your surroundings, gather clues, make decisions, solve satisfying riddles, and try to help each of your callers survive the night.

Retro Slasher setting:

Jump back in time to 1987 with this slasher inspired puzzler – explore an authentically detailed radio station and interact with dozens of physics-based objects straight from a bygone era, including a working cassette and record player. With a fully voiced cast and a killer original soundtrack of 80's inspired tunes from rock classics to synthwave!

reviews.review:
Step 1: Buy the game
Step 2: Buy a case of beer
Step 3: Play the game, drink some beer, groove to the music, get sucked into the story.
Step 4: Great way to spend a Friday night.

If you are a fan of Firewatch, The Suicide of Rachel Foster, or any narrative game you can lose yourself in for an evening... Pick this up. Best $20 bucks I've spent on Steam in a long time. Playtime for me (an inquisitive player) was 6.2 hours.

I'm an actual IRL Radio Personality that has worked in small/medium/large markets with 3 decades of experience. (And I'll say I recommend this game, it's a blast)

I'll focus on the small market because holy moly this hit really close to home.

Few of the misses: Small town late night show wouldn't have a 2 person crew, it'd be the DJ only to save $$$. Also, knowing "about 35 listeners" would be pretty rare, didn't seem like they had competition so odds are they wouldn't be paying for the analytics with no local competition... but this is nitpicking no big deals.

Wondering where a few folks got their phones to call in, especially in the Maize Maze.  

I've had businesses just like Ponty... and have taken some of the weirdest phone calls so this was spot on.

I'm happy there wasn't a specific state this was located in, I had Ohio/Illinois/Indiana vibes but those call letters would've started with a W instead of a K. (East v West of Mississippi...weird fun fact for y'all)

There's a few other bits I'd nitpick but it's a video game, and a fun one at that. Fun story, great horror references. The puzzles are a hoot...also I'm amazed how well a video game actually uses real First Aid information and not the usual flubbing that games do. Lot of love went into this game.

The fact you can save/lose everybody is fantastic, love that it is not just a hard game over, and thank you save states! 

Only a few timer/quick moments really helps as well, and jumpscares are at a minimum! Love it. 

Is my type up of this all over the place? Yes. Should I re-do it? Probably. Am I going to? Nah.

Just pick the game up. It's great.

Fun game, great execution of the idea. My only complaint is that the sound board never played a factor in any puzzles or sequences, Its funny to play crickets over a bad joke but unless your streaming to a audience It was a wasted feature. 
Really enjoyed the puzzles as if you werent paying attention you could easily fail. Completed in one sitting and got the best results first try.
this game is to die for. JUST LIKE PONTYS PIZZA THE BEST AND ONLY PIZZA PLACE IN GALLOWS CREEK!!

-Game takes about several hours to beat, less if you know what you're doing. 
-Atmosphere is great, characters are *alright*, and most puzzles are somewhat challenging, if only sometimes due to poor explanations.
-Main complaint is that some parts of the game drag in what feels like unnecessary time padding, and the lack of variation. Deaths of most characters don't have an affect on much of the game, and there's only two endings which aren't exactly hard to get each and generally feel like a letdown.

Fun game, just not sure if it's worth the $25 price tag.

Dont let this fly under your radar, they nailed the aesthetics, voice acting, story and interaction. 

[spoiler] The police has to drive for 4 hours, and it took me around 4 hours to finish the game, which is very nicely timed storytelling, but theres no time limit [/spoiler]

Having played only one play through so far, I have to recommend this game to anyone who loves 80s vibes, serial killers and the ability to hit keys on a soundboard at inappropriate times. Not only is it very immersive as a puzzle game, it hits all the sweet spots of horror without being too much. There's a very intricate mystery to solve, plenty of important choices - with sometimes startling consequences - and a really good chill to go up your spine. At the same time there's a lot of levity in the form of playing tunes, hoarding everything you can pick up at your desk and using a sound board to amuse yourself. 

The dialogue choices, along with the important puzzle choices, dictate tone and results in the game that feel true to their weight. You can be under pressure sometimes but nothing's too hard to solve. Just... make sure to examine your clues thoroughly so you don't end up answering a quiz with only half the data. Speaking from experience. #sorryscott

I'll be playing through at least 2+ more times for achievements, so the replay value is already astonishing. It took me about 6-7 hours for one play through and so that's the one thing I have to say about this game: it isn't short, and you don't feel short changed. It seems to have a lot to go through and is well worth the price!

Beautiful game, got Forrest Dash on my second run. Saw my fav youtuber play this before it came out and I fell IN LOVE. I love the concept, the art style, and the voice acting. Best purchase ive made. 

I LOVE ROLLER RICKY AND MAX!!!!

As an autistic person who's special interest is slashers, I was ecstatic to see that the people who made this game put a lot of love and effort into creating a narrative that feels like a genuine and loving homage to the horror genre. I truly loved this game and I cannot wait to replay it (which I will be doing immediately). Thank you guys so much for this absolutely beautiful game.

Oh, he died... so, do you have any siblings?

It's great so far
great voice acting, interesting calls and spooky atmosphere
Game is fun, story is good, the requirements aren't too much. My one nitpick is the fact that the characters only take a minute to mourn the loss of a person

Puzzles were a little too linear for most of them, and the resolution wasn't particularly satisfying, but I would recommend if you enjoy narrative walking sims. It oversells the investigation aspect a little bit, only one puzzle makes real use of the things like the cork board and assorted information. 

As a side note, make sure you come down to PONTY'S PIZZA WITH THEIR FRESH NEW DEALS TOMORROW

In this game you play as Forrest Nash who moved to the small town of Gallows Creek after he left his job in Chicago. In a bizarre turn of events it turns out an old town legend known as "the whistling man" has began to kill again 20 years after his disappearance. The first victim is the towns sheriff, so her assistant needs to drive to the closest town for help. Sense all of the members of the police station are gone for the night you need to fill in for 911 and take in calls of desperate victims in need of help.

 It feels really fun playing as Forrest who's just trying to adapt to his new job and save callers from the town. All of the puzzles are unique and fun in there own way. I really enjoy the graphics as well, its like if borderlands was a horror franchise. The music to this game is outstanding and by far the best part of the whole game. It really feels like music that was made in the 80's. The dialogue is witty and fun, although a few jokes did fall flat for me. The game is decently scary thorough the whole game. When your not trying to save callers who are desperate for help, your exploring more creepy areas in the old radio station. The game is pretty long (taking me 5.2 hours to beat) and super small at only 2 gigabytes required for the whole game. I would give this game an 8.5/10 and if your looking for an entry to the horror franchise I absolutely 100% recommend this game. But if your a horror veteran looking for something extra spooky that will make you cry yourself to sleep, I would recommend something else. But if your looking to have a great time than this game is an excellent choice.

This is a FANTASTIC story, and subsequently a fantastic game! If you love the vibe you get from the screenshots or game play you've seen, you're gonna love the game, I guarantee it. This game has an engaging plot with equally engaging mechanics. The concept of being a DJ on a late night show is so novel, and incredibly entertaining. I'm only left wishing there was more! It fits perfectly with the 80's slasher horror genre, this game is truly retro aesthetic heaven. I encountered only one small glitch, my tape player stopped accepting ad tapes, which was quickly remedied by a setting called 'Reset All Objects', seemingly integrated for a scenario just like mine. So to same the game was extremely well optimized and bug free is an understatement. All the tracks you could play were bangers! Just as you'd expect from a game so centered around music. Do your best to avoid spoilers before playing, as the story is a mystery and I often found myself having the most fun trying to piece together the mystery while I collected documents or searched around the station, it really puts you into the game. Lastly, I wholeheartedly recommend playing as much as you can in uninterrupted sessions, so you can immerse yourself the story, and feel like you're actually on the job. With all that said, if you're on the fence, get this game! One of my all-time favorites and my personal winner for horror game of the year so far! Thank you Team 17 for an amazing title!

Got a comedic timing wherein I cutoff an asshole politician and was asked to play an ad...
and the ad i put was coincidentally from the same asshole politician. 
I immediately stopped it and sighed.

I am laughing myself numb with making clown sound effects on the soundboard while people are calling in that they are dying.
I am also their only hope
Welcome to my world

Great voice acting. They really sold it. Once you get into the dj flow you really can make your show sound smooth too. its cool.I wish the faders wouldn't sometimes get stuck and the story is definitely one that has been told before but its the right mix of uneasiness and dramatic flair. 7.5/10
why the whistling man kinda...👀
I love radio dramas and 80s slashers. This game is that. Great voice acting, memorable characters, and an excellent and exciting plot. Best 20 bucks I've spent in awhile, would highly recommend.

Honestly one of the most enjoyable games to come out this year. Excellent sense in terms of fear ambiance; soundtrack is spectacular, plot is exciting so far (and scary)!!! Cannot wait to see how this game continues. <3

applist.name: Assassin's Creed Valhalla
applist.detailed_description:
Comparison Grid


Complete edition



Includes the base game, the season pass, the Ultimate Cosmetics Pack, and the Dawn of Ragnarök Expansion!

In Assassin’s Creed® Valhalla, you are Eivor, a fierce Viking warrior raised on tales of battle and glory. Explore a mysterious and beautiful open world set against the brutal backdrop of England’s Dark Ages.

- Season pass content includes: Wrath of the Druids and The Siege of Paris expansions.
- Ultimate Pack features the Berserker Bundle (Gear Set, Settlement Pack, and Longship Pack).
- Dawn of Ragnarök Expansion: Embrace your destiny as the Norse god Odin and complete your saga.

Includes Forgotten Saga, a FREE new rogue-lite game mode for all Assassin's Creed Valhalla players.


Ragnarok Edition



Includes the game and the epic Dawn of Ragnarök expansion!

In Assassin’s Creed® Valhalla, you are Eivor, a fierce Viking warrior raised on tales of battle and glory. Explore a mysterious and beautiful open world set against the brutal backdrop of England’s Dark Ages.

In Assassin’s Creed Valhalla: Dawn of Ragnarök, the most ambitious expansion in franchise history, Eivor must embrace their destiny as Odin, the Norse god of Battle and Wisdom. Unleash new divine powers as you embark on a desperate quest through a breathtaking world. Complete a legendary Viking saga and save your son in the face of the gods’ doom.

Includes Forgotten Saga, a FREE new rogue-lite game mode for all Assassin's Creed Valhalla players


Deluxe Edition



Includes the game and Ultimate Pack, which contains the Berserker Gear Pack, Berserker Settlement Pack, Berserker Longship Pack, and more!

Strike fear into the hearts of your enemies with the Ultimate Pack cosmetic items, including:
- The Berserker Gear Pack: the Bearded Axe, a new Raven skin, the ferocious Hati Wolf Mount, and more.
- The Berserker Longship Pack: a majestic Longship with a unique figurehead and sails.
- The Berserker Settlement Pack: new ways to customize your settlement in England.
- A Set of Runes to sharpen weapons or improve gear.

Includes the Forgotten Saga, a FREE new rogue-lite game mode for all Assassin's Creed® Valhalla players.


About the Game



Become Eivor, a legendary Viking raider on a quest for glory.

- Lead epic Viking raids against Saxon troops and fortresses.
- Relive the visceral fighting style of the Vikings as you dual-wield powerful weapons.
- Challenge yourself with the most varied collection of enemies ever in Assassin's Creed.
- Shape the growth of your character and your clan's settlement with every choice you make.
- Explore a Dark Age open world, from the harsh shores of Norway to the beautiful kingdoms of England.

Includes the Forgotten Saga, a FREE new rogue-lite game mode for all Assassin's Creed® Valhalla players.

reviews.review: man i am not sure how long left to finish the game but i get bored it's just the same missions over and over but different location and characters

This one feels like an oversimplified version of Origins and Odyssey. Almost everything - gameplay, story, NPCs, riddles, collectibles, side missions, you name it - are a step back from previous titles. Also, this is the first openworld game I know which will punish you for exploring. Game wants you to follow the story and not to take a step in any other direction. And as a bonus - there are still crashes and game breaking bugs presents.
Where are the achievements?

After 220 hours , just to see if there was any change to the modern day Assassins creed story-line and i was quite impressed by it. On the other hand , the Vikings story-line is boring after a few hours. Anyway , it's recommended for the people who likes to grind for fun , other than that it is not worth it. Let's just hope for the best from 'Mirage'.

Better combat and perk system than Odyssey, and the removal of naval warfare is a positive for me. That said the gear system is VASTLY worse in this game IMO. Worth on sale. 

Edit: I didn't realize this game had gotten such poor feedback. Seems to be trendy to hate on AC games, sure it's quite expensive and similar to previous titles. But it delivers a TON of content with a decent story and introducing many new systems. Playing on the highest difficulty the combat has actually been fairly challenging with many different types of fights and unique enemies. If you liked Odyssey and Origins, chances are you will like this game as well. I am not one to stick up for Ubisoft, but it's a bit silly to see so many people jumping on the hate-bandwagon.

I would HIGHLY recommend completing the main game before doing any of the dlc. The reason for this is that some items (noden's arc, excaliber, thor's armor and hammer) are only obtained near end game or AFTER end game in the case of thor's hammer. And then there is nothing left to do. there is no new game plus. no new quests. So it's kind of better to wait to do the dlc so you can actually enjoy the ISU artifacts.
A very very very mid game

Disappointingly unengaging and lacking in inspiration. The world feels empty and lifeless. The story is so drawn out and basic. Don't get me started on all the historic and social inaccuracies. 

This seemingly endless "experience" demanded a staggering 80 hours of my time, yet it could have easily been condensed by 40-50 hours, making me feel like I wasted less of my life.

For what fun there is, it isn't worth the price tag. If you are a fan of the AC games, get this on a huge discount only.

It would be tempting to give Valhalla a less than favorable review. Over the years the countless sequels in the franchise, and following in the footsteps of such epic masterpieces as Origins and Odyssey has certainly numbed our senses. It might feel mediocre until you actually try any other of the less polished competitors to realize how masterly crafted it is. Surprisingly the main reason it feels so bland is because almost everything is in it's place, within a seamless world, with excellent story arcs, surprise cameos, plausible and clever plot twists smooth and a lot more.

It has it's issues - random freezes here and there, some effort/reward discrepancies, minor inconveniences but the positives, especially if you can take it as a standalone product and not just another brick in the series are truly overwhelming.
no achivements, no good rating

[h1]A Viking Odyssey Unfolds: My Enduring Journey with Assassin's Creed Valhalla[/h1]

Rating: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5)

[b]As the epic tale of Assassin's Creed Valhalla continues to unravel, I find myself captivated by the Norse world that unfolds before me. Even after spending countless hours immersed in this Viking adventure, my enthusiasm for the game remains unwavering.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2946302920

[b]From the moment I stepped foot into the vast open world of Valhalla, I was instantly swept away by its breathtaking landscapes and attention to detail. The lush forests, towering mountains, and shimmering lakes create a backdrop that feels both familiar and mysterious, inviting exploration at every turn.[/b]

[b]The heart and soul of Valhalla lies in its engrossing storyline. Eivor's journey, filled with triumphs, tragedies, and complex character relationships, has kept me eagerly anticipating each new chapter. The game masterfully weaves historical events and mythology, allowing me to delve into the rich tapestry of Norse culture while engaging in the age-old battle between the Assassins and Templars.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2954771704

[b]Combat in Valhalla is a visceral experience. The weighty swings of Eivor's axe and the precise strikes of the hidden blade deliver a satisfying sense of power. Whether I choose to face my foes head-on or take a more stealthy approach, the combat mechanics are fluid and gratifying. The addition of raids and epic battles adds a grand scale to the Viking conquest, making each clash a thrilling spectacle.[/b]

[b]One aspect that truly sets Valhalla apart is the attention given to side quests and activities. From hunting legendary beasts to engaging in captivating mini-games, there is always something new to discover. The depth of the world-building shines through these diversions, making me feel like an integral part of the Viking society and forging lasting connections with the game's characters.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2969869917

[b]The commitment of the development team to post-launch support is commendable. Regular updates and expansions bring fresh content, ensuring that my journey never stagnates. The passion for the game and its community is palpable, making Valhalla an evolving experience that continues to surprise and delight.[/b]

[b]Even though I am still playing Assassin's Creed Valhalla, I can confidently say that it has become a timeless adventure for me. Its compelling narrative, immersive world, satisfying combat, and ongoing support make it a true masterpiece in the Assassin's Creed series. Skål to Ubisoft for crafting a game that continues to hold me captive, and I eagerly await the next chapter in this extraordinary Viking saga.[/b]

Let me preface that I have enjoyed this game. Not as much as Odyssey but still.

However, I do not support Ubisoft's Practices of not including features that should be included from the start (Achievements where?). This carries on with the Lack of Mirage from the start. Or Origins which I played on Ubisoft+, wanted to buy here only to refund it because the savegames are not cross-compatible ^^ 

If you fix these issues Ubisoft, this review will change. But until then, it will be a no.
charging 140$ for the "complete edition" of a game that isnt complete

I have played every AC they ever made. I had to wait until Valhalla came out on steam to play it, and it was well worth the wait. While the story-line is a little less fluid than AC Odyssey I found it enriching and the content outpaces any other AC game by at least 20 hours. I have thoroughly enjoyed the game, and the final DLC "The Last Chapter" is a great way to complete the game (after doing absolutely everything possible in all other DLCs and Main story-line). I honestly wish there were more DLCs on the way but I know I came to the game quite late. Looking forward to AC Mirage in Oct '23!

Although I certainly enjoyed the 60 hours that I played, this game just has no life to it. Odyssey was a game that involved a long grind I had 100 hours!), but in that game you would enjoy the grind since the characters and atmosphere were vibrant with rich stories behind them, which you do not get in the gloomy hell of Valhalla, The lifeless characters and atmosphere prevent you from feeling motivated to finish the game. In the end, it is a good game at the start, but as a whole repetitive and eventually: boring.

This game was interesting at first. The combat was difficult, the tactics of Odyssey don't work the same, and the story was compelling enough. There was a point early on where your actions while roaming seemed to have consequences, so I was hopeful. But as it went on... combat became universally easy. Before midgame, I was already unstoppable. I never needed to eat rations anymore. The puzzles were just "Find the oil jar and carry it to the breakable wall" or "Shoot the breakable part of the wall just under the roof and climb through" over and over, for supplies I haven't needed ever because they become literally free in bulk for some ungodly reason or silver for settlement decorations. Whoop-de-doo. The fishing takes forever for minimal rewards, Orlog was a decent time-killer, but not very helpful, flyting was actually cool, but ultimately a small part of the game. Even the DLC stuff only seemed to give you cosmetics or weapons and armor that were worse than what you already had.
But what I hated was the lack of any actual choices. They'd always present seemingly important decisions, and as soon as you think it through and make a decision, the game would make it painfully obvious that the choice didn't matter. Solve a mystery and identify a traitor? Doesn't matter, Eivor will [spoiler]explain that that's the guy in private and then stand back as he monologues and kills everyone with the wine you literally just said was poisoned[/spoiler]. Who should you bribe to end the war? Doesn't matter, your companion will [spoiler]murder the hostage and start the war back up immediately[/spoiler]. Dialogue option 1, 2, or 3? Doesn't matter, if you choose 1 or 2, Eivor will just say 3 afterwards anyway. There's five supposedly big choices that affect the end of the game Witcher 3-style, but the impact is basically just [spoiler]whether your brother likes you or not post-game[/spoiler]. I got this on sale, but it was way too monotonous and disappointing to play again.

I loved Assassin's Creed games in the past. But this will be the first Assassin's Creed game that I have played and not completely finished. Ubisoft outdid themselves this time and in a bad way. 

I am starting to believe that artists and location designers are the only people left at Ubisoft that still actually know how to do their stuff. Everything else feels raw, unfinished, boring or downright bad. I'll try to summarize the key points, starting with the things that are sort of done well:

1) Locations. AC has always been a visual "image of an era" and Valhalla is no exception. Nordic winter vistas, fjords, nithing cursed sites, decaying Roman ruins with straw huts around them, druid forests, frankish villages - they are all visually interesting to look at and take screenshots of. And this is probably the only thing that I really have no issues with.

2) Music. It's nice, with some quite memorable tracks, like Hrafnsmál - The Words Of The Raven. And it's an immense pain that in actual game the music has been MURDERED with compression. And actually that goes to the sound quality overall - everything is super quiet and compressed it makes you wonder what those 150GB that the game takes are actually for if they can't fit 30-40 songs in good quality in there.

3) Graphics. LOD quality leaves a lot to be desired and textures are weirdly inconsistent. For example, you can have a super detailed Eivor face right next to the 2005 texture quality level shirt that looks like it barely has normalmaps. Snow and snowy dirt barely have proper detail on them as well, especially in Norway. This makes for a very jarring experience when you can't stop noticing the badly done stuff. Again, what are 150GB of game size for if good textures aren't part of it, apparently?

TAA in Valhalla is absolutely atrocious, it murders every bit of detail unless you play at 4K or such. I had played at max settings at 1440p and my game was a blurry mess at native resolution. Valhalla can look decent... nice, even - especially in some cities or unique locations, BUT - you have to jump through some hoops to get it to look better. I had to force my resolution scale to 180% and enforce Nvidia Sharpening and Texture pop filters (5 and 10% respectively) to make it look better.

4) Story. It's alright, but feels a lot like an afterthought for an already selected location for the game. I can't shake this feeling even in DLCs and their respective stories. None of the characters are memorable, they flash through your eyes in a caleidoscope of territory pledge quests, about an hour screen time each maybe. When Ubisoft tries to do emotional moments in story, it just doesn't hit because you can't care less for them. If you wanted to roleplay tough viking that actually paints English shores red with blood, to reave and plunder properly - tough luck, you'll still get punished for killing monks and "civilians". And of course main and side stories are spoiled with quota NPCs like black vikings, gay Lunden reeves and so on and so forth. Beating a dead horse at this point but I had to mention it.

5) General gameplay, combat and gear/loot system. Everything I had loathed in Origins and Odyssey is even worse here. Don't believe anyone who told you this game is going to be shorter - it's far from that. At the time of writing this review I am 178 hours in and I still have Ireland, Asgard and multiple roguelite modes left to finish. Activities are littered across the map like cat poop. Every treasure chest, every stone cairn and fly agaric mushroom is now a simple puzzle, but they are repeated so many times it becomes annoying to an extreme. Parkour or physics based puzzles are especially frustrating because they are very clunky and buggy and controls have even worse responsiveness than Odyssey.

I expected at least decent quests and I am super disappointed. Outside of two dozen main-ish questlines, there are only "world events" that are super short, super simple and are often downright nonsensical and/or cringe. Yes, I am talking about a lady farting from consuming viper eggs in Ledecestre, for example. This is horrible and Ubisoft should be ashamed of even putting it in, it's not even a comedic relief.

Combat is a step up from Odyssey, in my opinion, but again, very buggy and woven with white threads - you will find your limbs and weapons awkwardly teleporting to your enemies more often than you'd like to see, which is pretty bad for a combat system that is trying to be flashy. Finisher animations are very few so you'll be forced to see the only one available per weapon again and again and again... and again. 

The game is also laughably easy on normal difficulty and frustratingly bad with HP bar sponge enemies at anything higher than normal. Abilities are literally useless and act as "press X to do slightly more damage". The only actually useful active ability is an explosive arrow to destroy weak walls and save yourself some time from searching for an oil jar.

Gear and builds - all collectable weapons are unique now, so no loot nightmare from Odyssey but that barely matters because of what I wrote above. You'll either smite everything away by simply looking at it at a normal difficulty or will waste 5 minutes per enemy chipping at him without any enjoyment. 

6) Technical state of the game. It crashes. A lot. No, A LOT. Usually it happens because the game calls some unexisting function in Ubisoft Connect launcher, can't find it and closes itself completely. Your mileage may vary, but Valhalla is super crashy, be warned. 

All that is spiced up with a traditional for Ubi at this point microtransaction store in a singleplayer game, XP and silver boosters and literal heaps of armor softlocked behind premium currency instead of being available as quest rewards or something. Plus the news about the new AC Mirage flying past Steam again reinforce me in my thought that supporting them was a bad decision and I should refrain from buying their products - it's indeed a product because I can't call it a game nor can I recommend anyone to waste time on it. 

Ubisoft is incapable to learn and improve, it seems. Don't buy this game.

Well hello this is my first review so be kind:) 
i will break down the game into a list of the things i find great with the game and the negatives of the game here we go!

positives (great things)
-if you like the Norse mythology lore and brutal combat there is no shying away from that here.
-combat is smooth ability's are similar if not close to the same layout as odyssey so i found it familiar and comfortable to get used to the control's in this ac quickly.
-story is what you would expect from a viking story line some of the characters are very remember able and off there rocker some are just bland but i will touch up on that later in the negatives. 
- your bird companion is helpful and not over powered like the origins and odyssey makes game a little more challenging in my opinion and enjoyed this version of the bird eagle raven etc call it what you will.
-customisation is very well done in this game tattoos ship cosmetics hair raven cosmetics so forth and so on for all weapons and armour as well.
- Mini game such as Orlog and flyting are extremely fun in this ac creed game and i hope they bring back more games similar to Orlog or flyting in future ac games.
-side quest in ac Valhalla or a mixture of bland OK and well done i would say the side quests here are slightly less on par with odyssey and better then origins how ever i may be bi-est as i am very much into viking lore and history and personally i would say i prefer Valhalla side quests over ac odyssey.
--Negatives 
oh boy here we go everyone's favourite  part :) now let us begin

applist.name: Assassin’s Creed® IV Black Flag™
applist.detailed_description:
Gold Edition

Extra Content included in Assassin's Creed® IV Black Flag™ Gold Edition:

  • Assassin’s Creed® IV Black Flag™ Season Pass: Gives you all-in-one access to a new 3+ hour single-player story featuring Adewale, an ex-slave turned Assassin, the exclusive Kraken Ship Pack, plus multiplayer characters and much more!
  • Captain Kenway's Legacy Pack: Golden Scimitars and Multiplayer Treasure Hunter Costume
  • The Trove of Mystery Pack: Iron Wheel & Astrolabe Relic
  • Pirates Bounty Pack: German Rapiers & Compass Relic
  • Sacrificed Secrets Pack: Dark and dangerous treasure-hunting mission on Sacrifice Island; Unlock Captain Drake's Dual Swords and Pistols, Picture, Title, and Relics
  • Hidden Mystery Pack: Adventurous treasure-hunting mission on Mystery Island; Unlock Stede Bonnet's Ship, Costumes and other MP items
  • Black Island Pack: Dark and dangerous treasure-hunting mission on Black Island; Unlock the Deadly Black Ship and Captain Morgan's Silver Flintlock Pistols, Costume, Picture, and Title
  • Aveline Pack: 60 minutes of additional gameplay featuring Aveline de Grandpré from Assassin's Creed III Liberation; Unlockable Aveline ship figurehead


About the Game

The year is 1715. Pirates rule the Caribbean and have established their own lawless Republic where corruption, greediness and cruelty are commonplace.

Among these outlaws is a brash young captain named Edward Kenway. His fight for glory has earned him the respect of legends like Blackbeard, but also drawn him into the ancient war between Assassins and Templars, a war that may destroy everything the pirates have built.

Welcome to the Golden Age of Piracy.

Key Features



  • A BRASH REBEL ASSASSIN Become Edward Kenway, a charismatic yet brutal pirate captain, trained by Assassins. Edward can effortlessly switch between the Hidden Blade of the Assassin’s Order and all new weaponry including four flintlock pistols and dual cutlass swords.

  • EXPLORE AN OPEN WORLD FILLED WITH OPPORTUNITIES Discover the largest and most diverse Assassin’s Creed world ever created. From Kingston to Nassau, explore over 75 unique locations where you can live the life of a pirate including:
    • Loot underwater shipwrecks
    • Assassinate Templars in blossoming cities
    • Hunt for rare animals in untamed jungles
    • Search for treasure in lost ruins
    • Escape to hidden coves

  • BECOME THE MOST FEARED PIRATE IN THE CARIBBEAN Command your ship, the Jackdaw, and strike fear in all who see her. Plunder and pillage to upgrade the Jackdaw with ammunition and equipment needed to fight off enemy ships. The ship’s improvements are critical to Edward’s progression through the game. Attack and seamlessly board massive galleons, recruit sailors to join your crew and embark on an epic and infamous adventure.

  • EXPERIENCE THE GRITTY REALITY BEHIND THE PIRATE FANTASY Stand amongst legendary names such as Blackbeard, Calico Jack and Benjamin Hornigold, as you establish a lawless Republic in the Bahamas and relive the truly explosive events that defined the Golden Age of Piracy.

  • THE BEST ASSASSIN’S CREED MULTIPLAYER EXPERIENCE TO DATE Put your assassination skills to test and embark on an online journey throughout the Caribbean. Discover a brand new set of pirate characters, and explore exotic and colourful locations. Additionally, create your own game experience with the new Game Lab feature – craft your own multiplayer mode by choosing abilities, rules and bonuses. Play and share your newly created mode with your friends.

subs.option_text: Assassin's Creed Black Flag - Gold Edition - $39.99 $11.99

reviews.review: I bought this game on release back in 2013 and have completed it 100% on Switch, 360, Xbox One, PS3, PS4, and now am working on the PC version. It's one of those games I could never tired of, and I'm not a fan of pirate based games. If you haven't played this game, then please do! It's really good!

[code]Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag’s unique focus on naval combat really sets it apart from previous entries in the franchise. However, a lot of technical problems really ruin what would otherwise be quite an enjoyable pirate experience[/code]

After naval combat was introduced in [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] (the best part of the entire game for many), Ubisoft made the right decision for once and doubled down on the entire thing in the sequel: [i]Black Flag[/i]. With the appropriate setting, pirates in the Caribbean of course, [i]Black Flag[/i] had a lot of potential to be a great game even for those who are not a fan of the typical [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] formula.

And even though I played through all mainline [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] up until that point, I actually found the first few hours of [i]Black Flag[/i] surprisingly refreshing. In the beginning, it’s really fun to sail the Caribbean Sea with your own pirate ship, discovering new locations and engaging with other enemy ships in combat to steal their cargo. You then turn your cargo into ship upgrades, which allow you to take on even bigger challenges (read: bigger ships) for bigger rewards.

During these times, [i]Black Flag[/i] feels less like an [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] games and more like an entertaining-albeit-simple pirate spectacle. Naval combat isn’t very complex, and your ship upgrades will play a bigger part in surviving a battle than your reaction skills at the end, but it’s simple fun the first few times and a great visual spectacle. This goes especially for ship battles fought during heavy tropical storms, with big waves, heavy rain and a lot of thunder & lightning making for incredible memorable battle experiences.

However, as the game goes on and especially during story missions, the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] elements become more prevalent. You’ll spend more time on land than on water, visiting locations that unfortunately all look pretty similar to each other - even those not part of the Caribbean Sea. Once you’re on land, you also got the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i]-mix of assassinating certain targets, tailing people, collecting various side stuff and climbing towers to unveil the map. Little has changed here, making it a typical case of “you’ll like it if you liked it before and you’ll dislike it if you disliked it before”.

In fact, even though naval combat plays such a big role in [i]Black Flag[/i], at the end, I was surprised just how many of the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] strengths & weaknesses make a return: There’s a huge amount of content – but much of it feels like busy work or copy-pasted. Gameplay systems are easy to understand & use – but they lack depth & variety and thus get tiresome in the long run. And while the main story does have its moments, many characters remain underdeveloped, and the pacing is off. I do have to admit that I liked the Abstergo-elements of the story this time around, even if the ending was unsatisfyingly abrupt.

In the end, what was a fun pirate game in the beginning turned more into a usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] game along the way. We even got ship tailing missions, which is just going too far. But while the usual [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] mix might have its fair share of problems, it’s undeniable that it also has its charm and there’s nothing quite like it even to this day.

That said, I will have to spend the rest of the review detailing the numerous (!) technical problems I encountered while playing [i]Black Flag[/i]. These are also the main reason why I’m giving [i]Black Flag[/i] a negative review, as they’re heavily diminishing what would otherwise be an enjoyable pirate [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] experience. I have no idea if these problems are restricted to the Steam/PC version of the game, but if you want to play the game, you might be better off doing so on console.

The first issues I encountered concern the graphical settings of the game. For some reason, [i]Black Flag[/i] simply refused to offer a 1440p 60hz option for my main monitor. It did offer all other resolutions at 60hz, but not 1440p for some reason. If I changed this via the settings .ini file, the game simply ignored those changes. If I tried using other monitors, the 1440p 60hz option suddenly reappeared. It’s quite an odd problem I wasn’t able to solve (had to use a different resolution) and have never experienced with any other game before (even Cyberpunk 2077).

The next issue concerns game content. I originally bought the game back in 2019, first the standard edition and then the season pass afterwards. However, when I started [i]Black Flag[/i] for the first time just a few days ago and activated my key, I found out that I wasn’t able to access my season pass content. Everything I paid for didn’t show up, instead I just received ads for buying said content, adding insult to injury. I’ve spent the past few days contacting Ubisoft support about the issue, but so far, it has yet to be solved as well.

Then came what’s probably the biggest gripe I have concerning [i]Black Flag[/i] – after about 15h of playtime, I opened up the game only to find out that my save was suddenly corrupted. Even Ubisoft Connect with its cloud saves couldn’t help me out (it simply replaced my functioning save with the corrupt one). I have no idea what could’ve caused this, as the game never crashed on me or was forcefully exited, neither was the save data tempered with. I started the game normally only to discover I lost 15h (!) of playtime, with no way to get it back. Everything I did was gone. I highly recommend manually backing up your saves (Steam Cloud doesn’t work for this game), if you still fancy a playthrough of [i]Black Flag[/i] on Steam.

Lastly, there were some game breaking bugs I encountered while playing [i]Black Flag[/i]. I’m not talking about minor bugs like this [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eb77v45Soqc]classic[/url] (which I also experienced) but actual gamebreakers that require a reload if you want to finish a mission. For example, one time my player character spawned inside (!) my pirate ship, with no way to experience the wooden prison. This would be somewhat entertaining if the checkpoints in [i]Black Flag[/i] weren’t so bad sometimes – especially during tailing missions you might lose quite a lot of time. 

Maybe I just had bad luck with all of these technical problems happening at once (not counting the many minor bugs like glitching NPCs, etc.) but especially losing a 15h save really turned my playthrough of [i]Black Flag[/i] into an experience I can’t really recommend – even if the underlying game would be recommendation-worthy otherwise. Considering [i]Black Flag[/i] is also available on modern consoles, these might be safer picks if you want to avoid some of these technical problems.

This is a great game. Easily one of the best, if not the best, AC games they’ve made.

Truly immersive brilliance. Despite its shortcomings in being capped at 60 FPS (typical console-port laziness) and the entirely unnecessary, detractive and tedious modern 'developer' side-narrative jarringly infused in the story - [i]Black Flag[/i] finds itself the flagship and flag bearer of a genre, time period and landscape that is sorely needed in greater supply.

applist.name: Dying Light 2 Stay Human
applist.detailed_description:
Just Updated



It’s high time to get brutal and pack a greater punch! The most recent patch includes multiple updates to the combat system, along with improvements and fixes that will bring you more gore, blood and guts. Your enemies will have a hard time staying whole after an encounter, especially if you have access to your favorite weapon, thanks to the improved blueprint mastery. Speaking of killer style, you can now alter your clothing while keeping your lethal stats with the new transmog system.


Deluxe Edition



The Deluxe Edition contains:

  • Dying Light 2 Stay Human: Bloody Ties - the first official story DLC
  • Exclusive weapon charms
  • "Legendary" outfit
  • "Legendary" renewable weapons
  • "Legendary" paraglider skin
  • Wallpapers ready to print
  • Digital comic
  • Digital Artbook
  • Digital Soundtrack


Ultimate Edition



The Ultimate Edition contains:

  • Deluxe Edition
  • 2h Night XP Boost
  • Crafting items
  • Expansion pass with 2 extra stories that will be available in the months after the release


POST-LAUNCH ROAD MAP



It’s been a great first year, but the best of Dying Light 2 Stay Human is still ahead of us. Prepare for the next phase of our post-launch support that guarantees major content updates, events, rewards, Chapters, DLC, and much more. The following is only the tip of the iceberg regarding what awaits you.


About the Game

Over twenty years ago in Harran, we fought the virus—and lost. Now, we’re losing again. The City, one of the last large human settlements, is torn by conflict. Civilization has fallen back into the Dark Ages. And yet, we still have hope.

You are a wanderer with the power to change the fate of The City. But your exceptional abilities come at a price. Haunted by memories you cannot decipher, you set out to learn the truth… and find yourself in a combat zone. Hone your skills, as to defeat your enemies and make allies, you’ll need both fists and wits. Unravel the dark secrets behind the wielders of power, choose sides and decide your destiny. But wherever your actions take you, there's one thing you can never forget—stay human.

VAST OPEN WORLD

Participate in the life of a city engulfed in a new dark era. Discover different paths and hidden passages, as you explore its multiple levels and locations.

CREATIVE & BRUTAL COMBAT

Take advantage of your parkour skills to tip the scales of even the most brutal encounter. Clever thinking, traps and creative weapons will be your best friends.

DAY AND NIGHT CYCLE

Wait for night to venture into dark hideouts of the Infected. Sunlight keeps them at bay, but once it’s gone, monsters begin the hunt, leaving their lairs free to explore.

CHOICES & CONSEQUENCES

Shape the future of The City with your actions and watch how it changes. Determine the balance of power by making choices in a growing conflict and forge your own experience.

2-4 PLAYER CO-OP GAMEPLAY

Play in up to four-player co-op. Host your own games or join others and see how their choices have played out differently than yours.
