highlighted.name: On the Trail of the Enemy

reviews.review:
Dear Techland

OK, this is coming from a Dying Light series veteran.
FInally got a gaming rig and steam 2ish years ago, so all my old DL1 stuff is on my PS4.

DL2 is overall a phenomenal game, hands down the best parkour EVER. (and yes I have played Mirror's Edge 1 and 2) The amount of control and diff parkour moves that are in this to figure out as you play is unmatched.

This is ultimately what i look for in gaming.  Just give me one massive openworld to explore and freerun around as i please.  Give me a very deep and adjustable skilltree, perks and abilities to upgrade to keep the dopamine hits coming.  I want awesome gearsets, skins, outfits, TRANSMOG!! (thank u finally) and legend levels to keep the end game going for the long haulers.  Most of these things have been provided, but definitely not all.  We'll get into that.

OH, you guys need to make a Gear-set Tab under the Equipped Gear in the Inventory Page.
Would be nice to be able to switch from my Medic build to my Archer build with 1 click.  
Same for Weapons.  If i switch to my Archer build, then i would also like to be able to swap my current weapon Load-out for bow, crossbow, guns, etc. (in one click)

AND HOLY $h!t!  let me put the stamina bar directly below the health bar.  i want it on the screen just not right in my damn face.  
OK...that's out

As dead as the streets are meant to be.  the public space rooftops need to be frickin' poppin'.
Namely the city square itself...The Fish-Eye.  I want to see other NPC Night-runners and or Couriers gliding onto that damn rooftop on their para-gliders, and walk into the bar or just anywhere on the roof (mix it up) and even let me walk up to them and they can give me side quests or something, like info on a rare blueprint, again (mix it up).  Imagine seeing other NPCs gliding around the city, going about their business.  Maybe interacting with some.
(Talk about giving the city a pulse.) 

BTW, what happened with having all sorts of different guilds around the map.  Having them hand out missions and whatnot.  this needs to be looked into.

At night, the people should be locked up in their homes or safe zones...like terrified...like insanely terrified.  However, once that sun comes up, the people should immediately become calm again, opening the windows, doors, etc. (on the rooftops obviously) putting laundry on the clothes lines, baking bread, kids playing, people chatting in their corners, guys chopping firewood, give it a pulse, ya know.

Basically, the Survivors have accepted life on the roofs and that the undead rule the streets below.  Lets embrace that more.  I want to see NPCs freerunning around town on the rooftops.  Parkour is no longer an activity of fitness and expression.  It is the evolution of how we as humans must survive in that world.  Not saying every Survivor member should be a master tracer, but i should be seeing other NPCs out there freerunning.

It should LITERALLY feel like a night and day difference.  Not just the actual light and darkness.  The people need to reflect this better, the pulse and tone of the city needs to reflect this far better.  Day must be lively and bustling with people carrying on however they would in the "Modern Dark Ages".  Night...night should be absolutely terrifying.  I should be hearing NPC mothers telling their children to "hush" and "stay away from the windows!" from inside their homes on the rooftops, while I'm running around outside.  I should be hearing the utter horror in their voices as they say "daddy will be back soon kids, don't worry"  You guys do keep improving the game.  I just reaaalllllly need these things I've mentioned to be added.  I love this game, well the DL Series in general and i want to keep having fun with it.

I'll close with this...may write again
I know I've found a good game when i can beat the entire game, finish every Main Mission, Side Quest, Bounty Hunt, Random Encounter, World Event, ALL OF IT!
and yet, I can still find a game within a game.  When i can run around an awesome openworld with nothing holding me back, having everything the game has to offer...i can make my OWN quests, my OWN adventures.  I find myself getting lost in making my OWN fun.  not waiting for devs to give me the next list of check-boxes to check-off.  (not that you shouldn't be giving us content) I just know that i have found a good game, when i can make my own in the meantime. 
 
Please don't give up on this game.
There is definitely something special here.

quik recap_ i know forgot to mention a few of these but check'em out anyway.

1. Gear-Set Tab / Weapon Load-out Tab

2. Guild Factions - give side quests, hidden Blueprint locations, rare gear/weps, outfits, skins, etc

3. Blacksmiths need to have a Workbench...for disassembling, crafting, upgrading, modding, re-rolling, etc.  (side note, let us disassemble gear, not just weps.)

4. Re-Modding / Re-Rolling Gear/Wep Specs - Mods should be able to be swapped WHENEVER ON WHATEVER (at workbenches only, of course) and mods should stack.  
e.g.  2 Slit Mods should double the crit chance for bleed. (It allows for more options in modding)  and let us re-roll stats on our gear and weps.

5. Pulse or Survival Sense - OK, this one can be controversial, but...You shouldn't start out with this ability, right away AND it should have to be leveled-up.  like lv.1 would be pulse common loot only.  lv.2 could be pulse common loot and rare items.  lv.3 pulses loot, rarities and walkers, lv.4 pulses all enemies.  I mean...however, just shouldn't start the damn game off, being able to pulse everything in the game right off the bat.  Absolute suspense killer.

6. Base Building - doesn't have to be Sons of the Forest or Rust, just have scattered places that we can fix-up/upgrade to add bed, stash, FT>>>, personal workbench, etc.  like the secret Korek Charm Dev Room.  
Let us fix-up a flat or pad.  have like 2 or 3 per district or something. 

7. FULL HUD CUSTOMIZATION - Guys, no HUD...MEANS NO HUD...not the Chase sequence level 1-4, not the Enemy Awareness Meters that circle the damn screen when they're about to see me, no HUD...NO HUD MEANS NO HUD...Immersion guys, immersion.
I don't need or want it, let the player choose how they want to experience their play-through.
Every single individual HUD option should be able to be FULLY customized.

8. FULL CONTROLLER CUSTOMIZATION...FULL...EVERY BUTTON...EVEN CIRCUMSTANTIAL (assassins creed can do it, so can you)  The M&K / Controller is the medium between us and fantasy world you're providing. It's important that feels perfect for the player.

Dying Light 1 was better hands down. The nights were actually scary,  Why take guns out of the game? This one I played 95 hours and was on the verge of completing it when i was patched OUT of the game.  Now it only crashes on load.  Was told my motherboard was no longer compatible.  Of course no refund because i played too long.  THANKS TECHLAND JERKS
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Dave, can you tell me a bit more about this issue with motherboard? What's the model? 

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review: give me 6 hours to beat dying light 2... and i will spend the first 4 figuring out why the game runs at 5 fps

Why the hell is the tutorial over an hour long? I really don't think you need an hour long tutorial for a game released in 2022. 

The gameplay is alright but gets dull after a couple of hours. There is no real danger at all, it takes a year for the chase level to increase for volatiles to chase you and you could just stick to rooftops the whole time and you'll never die. Even if you get swarmed, as long as your have the regeneration booster and some other ones, you could literally face tank everything and kill everything.
I feel like the gear system needs more work, the stats seem so minuscule that it doesn't make a difference. The only thing that does make a difference is your weapon. 
The skill tree also needs work, it doesn't seem to have enough impact nor really influence how you play. Especially when you get to the end of the health skill tree, it's an attack skill that you have to attack from above on an unaware enemy which doesn't happen often.
They have all of these places of interest like the recent Assassin's Creed games and it's just incredibly annoying with all the markers and it takes the fun out of randomly exploring.
The looting system is a huge pain, why do I need to hold down a button to loot every zombie but when they despawn, I can just press it once instead to loot the bag?
The enemies are not challenging at all, there is almost no variety between the zombies, humans, or bosses. 
I can make grenades and bombs but ammo and guns aren't a thing in this world?


The parkour is alright but also gets a bit dull after a while. Throughout the story, they give you these puzzles where you basically just look for yellow marks to climb. There are several story missions which you just have to spend several minutes climbing something and it's super annoying. There are also windmills which you have to climb to activate them as well as climbing around in underground metro stations for fast travel points. There are puzzles where you have to connect power sources with a power cable and basically you just look around and connect them, not challenging at all, just tedious and boring.
Later on, they have a bigger map and introduce paragliders, grappling hook, and fast travel which makes parkour obsolete. I just end up paragliding everywhere.

The story is just garbage. The ending is terrible. Your choices don't mean too much in the end, the world isn't impacted in a huge way. Thank god you can skip lines of dialogue for the cutscenes, you can just start speed reading everything. I seriously don't like any of the characters at all, even Aiden is a boring MC. 
I have played some of the side quests but most of them are also boring. There was a quest where you had to do a time trial of parkouring THREE TIMES. 

The co-op is fine and I like how they allow a player to TP all the players to an event however, no progression transfers over so if you want to play alone and you weren't the host, you have to redo everything.

Great Game much improved after the patch's, it still has its flaws but still a decent sequel. Still like the original and dlc more tho, esp its zombie vs human ratio, DL2 focus's abit too much on the human side in some parts for my liking for a Zombie game.

Talking of flaws, choose to let x "live" and y die because y was so damn obnoxious to the point I had to skip y's dialog in many many places. I would have wanted to choose to let y live because it was logical but the way y's personality was written ugh i'd be tempted to save a hamster's life over y's life.

Dying Light 2 is great but very floaty and inconsistent in how it portrays decline of civilization. If youre looking for dying light one in a new engine youd be close to getting it but my grievances are
-floaty
-grapple isnt the same as from dl1
-no weapon repair
-easier nights 
-majority of quests are fetch quests with lack of insentive other than reward

despite all of this i still recommend this as after going back to dl1. I miss the buggy and grappling hook and the lack of guns and other mechanics makes it feel like a downgrade however i can still see the remnants of the former game shine through in the dlc where it pays homage (albeit kinda lazy and cheesy). If you like any of 
-zombie survival with mainly physical weapons
-parkour
-a good selection of weapon mods 
-crafting weapons (similar to dl1 but not as great)
-hang glider (which imo is really great)
-dark zones where you can find higher level zombies during the day but at night its easier as the high level zombies roam the streets
-Chases now make the zombies feel like a controlled faction who can work together
-Choices that kind of matter to story progression 
and more i cannot think of in my sleep addled state. some of these positives may seem negative and they are since dying light 2 is not the game that dl1 was but as its own game its a parkour focused zombie survival game that has a handful of unique npcs that make you wish to meet them outside the safe zone and kill them to take their stuff but that wouldnt matter since some enemy weapons do not drop and the spear can only be thrown by you but enemies can use it as a weapon. Rant over. Game fine but not the best it can be. 7/10 if dl1 was a 10/10
Have Fun
Trash game, crashes a lot, not optimized well, more like talking simulator 2, way too boring compared to Dying light 1, just god awful in general
This game crashes and freezes way too much. Had to give up nearly 30 hours in because the game literally would crash loading me in

reviews.review:
Dying light 1. 150 hours

Dyinglight 2. 50 hours 

dont have to say more do i.

TL;DR The story was mid, the endings are mid, Aiden as a character sucks, the quests have no likeable characters, the parkour did not feel that great, night time was basically day, combat was decent.

Play Dying Light 1 instead.

Dying Light 1's motto was "Good Night, Good Luck", which sets the expectation that night time will be dangerous and stayed relevant for basically the whole game.

Dying Light 2's motto "Stay Human" becomes irrelevant outside of the first few hours and any story points after that was not impactful. The mechanic of managing your time in dark areas becomes useless after the first subway mission since you get flooded with uv/time restoring items, and even when the bar 0s out you only take damage over time before completely turning (death). After that mission I never had to pay attention to it again.

In my opinion, the only real good point about this game was the combat. The way weapons and blueprints are upgraded/modded, having i-frames while dodging, and the overall hack-and-slash experience was decent. Too bad drop kicking anything other than volatiles and goons is basically meta as it one shots, while max-modded weapons inconsistently do so. Also, the devs are periodically pushing out events that gives players things to do after beating the story so the game is very much still alive.

Unfortunately, the story is the weakest part of this game and is what makes me not want to replay this game in either New Game+ or a new save. Your actions that shape the world do not matter outside of 2 or 3 important story decisions leading to character conflicts/deaths, but the city itself barely changes. In a Dying 2 Know interview uploaded by IGN, Aiden was described as a rich, deep character, but none of that is reflected in the story. 

Aiden is a glorified errand boy who replies to every request with a "ugh fine I'll do it" and is pushed around the whole time. Every transition from a cutscene or dialogue into a fight is through Aiden getting punched in the face every single time. Pilgrims are supposed to be people who go through hardships and danger every day in the wilderness and we later learn Aiden is supposed to be stronger than others, yet all we see is him being a pushover at every encounter.
There is also a situation later where a companion is injured, but both Aiden and them, 2 seasoned survivors, somehow do not have any bandages/medical supplies and do not think to get some from a warehouse full of it basically next door. A lame plot device to have Aiden continue the mission solo.

The "twist" at the end of the story also feels forced with barely any build up to it and basically gaslights the player's entire experience up until now, followed by an extremely lackluster final boss. Instead of Aiden being sucker punched to transition into the fight, we the player do.

The final boss has something like 3 attacks, 2 of which are easily dodgeable AOEs and basic melee swings. They also run away at set situations to force some parkour gameplay, but in my playthrough I shot them with a pk crossbow after they jumped and they teleported back to the first area stuck in T-pose for a minute while I sandbagged. I had to use melee on my range build so that I didn't accidentally cheese the boss fight.

After the final mission, it reverts back to before that ever happens and you don't get to feel the consequences of your actions. You also don't have the option to do the mission again and can only continue playing sandbox or do new game +.

According to the roadmap, the June 2023 update supposedly addresses issues of the parkour feeling janky and enhances the night, but below are my experiences those before the update.

The parkour was floaty and I felt like I constantly had issues with snapping ledge grabs, even with ledge grab assist off. If you didn't play with that off, trying to climb down any hole or ledge is a nightmare with Aiden constantly re-grabbing the ledge when you drop or jump. It also snaps onto ledges when you don't want it to, and doesn't snap sometimes when you want it to such as climbing up a lipped edge.

In the early game, trying jump up a ledge at max jump height (with the hold spacebar for higher jump perk), it was inconsistent whether you would actually grab the ledge or not. I've had to do the same jump 3-4 times before Aiden would actually grab onto the ledge. There are Agility perks you can get later that resolve this issue, but the original issue was not due to Aiden being inexperienced or weakened like Dying Light 1's early game parkour, but simply things not working when they should.

Even later on when you do unlock every agility perk, there are issues with some activating when you don't want it to such as jumping from pole to pole (atop the hospital), but the character wall runs instead of grabbing onto the pole. Some input based actions like Slide also don't work half the time - could be user error though.

Doing things at night felt no different than the day. Every night was a full moon and flashlights had infinite battery, so it ended up being a darker "day". You also don't see co-op partner flashlights, which was a strange change.

Volatiles were extremely rare, only appearing when you go into dark zones during the day or by causing a level 4 chase which you have to intentionally trigger. If you do run into any, they are usually alone and camped around a flare so you are never in danger of being ambushed by one, and even if you do they are pretty weak. Unless you get swarmed, it was never difficult to get around during the night. Aside from 2-3 fast infected spawning from holes occasionally while you travel and the streets being flooded with slow infected and howlers, nothing really changed.

Also, why do we even have to mash a button every time we want to open small containers like baskets and low tier chests?
Dying light 2. Stay Broken
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Snork, that was a bit snorky *badum tss*

But seriously, would you mind sharing a bit more about these issues you've been having with the game? I might be able to help or at least forward your feedback to the rest of the team.

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review: I decided to finally get dying light 2 a year after it's release. I decided to finally give it a try. I heard this game got a lot of criticism with it's story. I do somewhat agree I was really confused with it's approach and how it delivered a lot of the characters, choices, and outcomes. but I think when compared to the first dying light it isn't as bad as people say it is. I think the story is supposed to put you in this whole situation knowing nothing in a zombie disaster. Years after the whole thing happened you step into it knowing absolutely nothing. I think that's what the developers wanted for the player anyways. Later in the story I began to sort of look at the whole game differently. Dying light 2 almost feels like it's supposed to be some society put into medieval times. A place named villedor with survivors wearing chainmail, cloth sewn together, and leather vests wielding weapons. It's definitely different from the first game where it's based during the beginning of the outbreak when you play as kyle knowing everything while in this game aiden you know nothing only your goal. definitely am going to have to give it a second playthrough to try and understand more. But the gameplay and the combat is the most satisfying and fun I've had in a while. parkour is very nice too and an improvement. I hope this game gets more flavor as the time goes.

They sold out to Epic. Epic wont let you play with Steam because it needs it's datamining hooks into your account. Just generates an unhelpful error.

The developers and publishers should make playing this game easier, not make you hate the product that so many people worked hard on. 

I am up for playing yet another mid level zombie game. But it's a shame the players arent prioritized. I'd be playing right now with a friend if that was the case.

The people who worked on this game should want to do better. So do better
An extremely disappointing sequel that removes what the first game did best, and innovates on it poorly

reviews.review:
Turd sandwich of a game
Immersion non existent
Combat system a joke
Night time easy, just a timer whoa
Night time chase is just gta stars
Oh you want a refund nope it's 2 hours of tutorial so you can't get your money back

Dying light is a dead game I regret buying it, it's a game worth about 15 dollars don't pay anymore for it 

TRAAAAAASSSSSHHHHHHHHHHHH

Whatever you do, don't get this game if you liked the first one.

I bought it because my sons and I had a really good time playing the first one together in co-op multiplayer and we were all looking forward to more fun with this one.

However, after just 2 hours of trying this out, I realized that this game was very broken.  

Let's start with the movement and parkour.

Gone is any real sense of rapid movement.  You just sort of shuffle along as your 'run' but when you make a jump, while leisurely shuffling along, you make 25 foot jumps with room to spare.  

Then there are the plot devices and other mechanics de-tuning.  
When you swing your baseball bat at your foes, it swings in slow motion, almost as if it's deciding on whether or not it will hit the target.  
Then there are the totally predictable plot devices.like the abundance of infected overruns almost from the very beginning of the game. Like where the companion NPC is fiddling with picking a lock of a door all the while the infected are trying to overrun the location.  
Then there's the broken elevator gag, where the NPC jumps down while warning you about how unstable the elevator is.  But of course he gets off with no problem.  You however, are not so lucky.  you jump down and instead of immediately getting off the 'unstable' elevator, you stand there and wait the full 10-15 seconds till it very predictable falls, taking you with it.

And it was after that second very cliche'd and overused plot situation, that I decided I had had enough, and opted for s refund.

So don't waste your rime if you like likd the first one.

Dying Lite 2: Da Not-So-Brightenin' - like a broken leg dat won't heal. Parkour's slower than a snoozin' sloth on Ambien. Story's as excitin' as watchin' grass grow. Controls are sticky as molasses, tripin' ovr every ledge. Plot's bland as a soggy cracker, characters as shallow as a kiddie pool. Dialogue sounds like monkeys on typewriters. It's painful, mate. Dying Lite 2's a letdown. Save ur cash, buy marbles instead. More fun guaranteed. Trust me, u'll thank me l8r.

What is this? The story writing... The voice acting... The fighting mechanics... The parcour mechanics... Holy shit! I almost never write a review on any game, but this... This is pure garbage. I picked this up at 50% off and I still feel ripped off!
Mia.

applist.name: Gunfire Reborn
applist.detailed_description:
About This Game:

  • Gunfire Reborn is an adventure level-based game featuring FPS, roguelite, and RPG elements. Players can control unique heroes—each with different abilities—as they adventure through procedurally-generated levels and pick up randomly-dropped weapons. You can play Gunfire Reborn alone or cooperatively with up to three other players (4-player co-op).
  • Every level is random; each new restart is a brand-new experience. You will meet different heroes and experience new weapons, items, checkpoints, and unique combat rhythms throughout the game.

    Game Features:


    • FPS+Roguelite+RPG combined gameplay, construct diverse Build through death cycle for different experience


    • Elaborate, yet randomized stage experience


    • Over 100 different items and various weapons


    • Many heroes and multiple game plus with different game mechanism


    • Unique art style


    • Co-op level-based adventure

reviews.review:
TLDR down below.

Best shooter roguelike out there.

Has everything a modern roguelike should have: 

- Multiple characters that feel unique:
 Every character has multiple styles of play. You can focus on one of their 2 special abilities or on abilities that improve your weapons. But this is not required, you can use a bit of all 3 styles and still feel strong. Most characters gravitate to certain kinds of weapons with which they will probably do best. All characters have 3 trees of 6 power ups that you can pick from after you finish a stage.

- a lot of different weapons to get:
There are over 50 weapons divided into 8 classes. Most weapons feel unique and have their own gimmick. You can carry up to 2 weapons making certain combo's is possible. A downside with such a big selection is of course that some weapons feel like weaker versions of others. Also each weapon being pretty unique means that some will not be suited to your style at all. 

- Permanent upgrades:
There is permanent progression between runs you can upgrade with a currency you get by playing. I know this goes against the definition of roguelike but all modern rogues have this feature. The devs can make harder/more fun encounters that feel unfair but get less unfair the more you invest in this system which ultimately makes the game better since they can push the boundaries the game. You can also go for an extra challenge by not/ partially investing in this to make it harder for yourself.

- Difficulty settings:

There are 4 difficulties to play in. You are locked to normal at the start but unlock higher difficulties by beating the hardest difficulty you currently have. The 4th difficulty is the most unique, it features unique upgrades you can buy with the same currency used for the permanent upgrades (this means that currency is not useless when you unlocked the whole prema upgrades tree which is nice) which will change the way you play in a major way and is so much fun! The game never feels to unfair, you can win the game with any combination of weapons/power ups as long as you can keep dodging!

- Many upgrades
During the run you encounter these power ups called occult scrolls, they can straight up boost your damage/survivability or change the way you play. Some boost you in a big way but will also restrict you in a way, there is a lot of different 'builds' you can aim to go for.

- 4 worlds to go through, with their own enemies to fight.
The enemies are cool, there is ranged and melee enemies. Some have unique mechanics that are not super hard to play around. Of course this gets harder when it's accompanied by other enemies. Enemies get harder in the later worlds, it's not uncommon to almost get oneshot there. The bosses of these areas are also very good. Huge monsters in their own arena with alot of different attacks that have to be dealt with, and somewhere in between you are supposed to actually kill them.

- Active devs
The game still gets regular patches and updates, there is still a roadmap for their future content like in the beta. They have added new characters, bosses, a new world and a new game mode since beta. There is still more to come as well. When you encounter bugs in game there is a feedback option which you can access during your run and explain the bug. And you actually get listened to, every bug I have reported over the years has been fixed in a reasonable time frame, almost always in the next patch.

- Good pricing
This game is 100% worth getting at full price. It is more then reasonable if you see the huge amount of content here that puts AAA games to shame. There has been 1 DLC so far which included 2 characters. So far it is the only content that is gated behind a DLC, their new game mode that could have been a DLC in itself was added completely free. If you are looking for a game like this I would just buy it now!

- Multiplayer
The game supports multiplayer, there is a matchmaker to play with random people as well. I cannot comment on the quality of that since I never did that. I have only played multi with 1 friend and it was fun, every player gets their own weapon and scroll drops so nobody can 'steal' your upgrades like in Risk of Rain 2. If you don't need your drops you can press a button to make them visible for your allies so they can pick it up. You can help each other get to their preffered build faster but you can't get 'griefed' by people that steal your drops. I feel this is the best way to create a multiplayer experience in a co-op game. The new game mode can also be played with friends. 

TLDR:
if you like this genre, you should definitely buy this. Big worlds, al lot of characters, weapons and power ups. Different difficulties for everyone, a multiplayer that is done extremely well for a co-op game. The devs should feel very proud of what they accomplished with this game. I look forward to the bright future of this game!

The game has this big "one more run" feel that every good roguelike should have.

If I have to put a number on it it's a 9,5/10 for me. I hope this review helped any people with doubts to make a good decision!
Your honour, it was funky monkey Friday. I had to go ape.
Great core gameplay loop with tons of replayabilitiy. Devs stick to their roadmap and deliver on time with reasonably priced dlcs for extra characters + weapons

Meh, I want to like this game more but it's got a lot of problems for me personally. It's not bad, I enjoy it and play it with friends or on my own occasionally but everytime I do nowadays I just end up irked over one thing or another. I could probably recommend it if you like this sort of thing, but I'd like to list out my problems as someone that's played both a lot of shooters and roguelikes/lites.

Although I'll start with the good, the gunplay and weapon designs are incredible and a ton of fun to mess with, reincarnation is incredible too, the wacky builds you can pull off at that point are a ton of fun. That's really the main positive here, and if that's good enough for you you'll probably love this. It's great for more casual play.

The problems start with the enemies, its not necessarily their attack patterns, their hp, or anything like that. They're well balanced, but for a few reasons they don't *feel* satisfying to fight. The way they move around is kind of awkward, rigid, and janky, its not smooth at all and feels random and just frustrating enough to lower the feel of combat for me. Its not bullshit or anything, but it makes it harder to enjoy the great gunplay and with enough playtime it became harder and harder for me to overlook.

The game has a lot of content, side modes and such that might seem like nice mixups at first but it all ends up being kinda mediocre and I just end up playing reincarnation instead. Spirtual Assault is still a complete mess, its not a bullet sponge hell-hole anymore but its just soooo boring and really highlights the unsatisfying enemy design. It needs to seriously be cut down and better paced, it goes on way too long for how mindless and spammy it is. The final boss for it is designed okay move-wise but is still annoyingly tanky and unfun to fight as a result.

The further you go into the game progression wise the more of a problem the stat system becomes.  It's much better to stick with one weapon early on with good affixes and pump all the money into it. Unless you're playing a character like the dog there's little reason to ever switch between two weapons, ammo is plenty and its way too costly to invest into two weapons when you can just funnel everything into one broken one. 

This isn't inherently a problem necessarily but then it leads to runs becoming samey, you're just waiting until you get an OP combination and then just spamming that weapon at enemies, it leaves the combat loop lacking depth, the only skill thats really rewarded as a result is the ability to dodge enemies. There's no major tactics here, most characters except like, the monkey, have a clearly defined weapon type/s they're good with, so thats what you go for. 

You want shotguns/melee, you play the bird, you want smgs/assault rfiles play the bunny, fire weapons? the fox. I wish the characters were more open-ended in their design, would be much more interesting for builds.

Overall its not a bad game, just a shallow one. Don't go into this one expecting any major complexity or depth. You shoot the bad guys, dodge occasionally, and build around whatever rng has given you. It's a passable way to spend the time, but there's both roguelites and shooters out there that offer way more depth and engaging gameplay than this if thats what you're looking for.
10/10 coop game. Just buy it and don't look back. Joy to be had is similar to Risk of Rain 2, but imagine FPS.
Animals on drugs with access to guns and more, now this is what I call a real zoo
I lost two friends over this video game.
Cats and guns? My game. MEOWWW Borderlands style graphics, what more do you want??
this might be the best game ive ever played.

In my humble opinion, Gunfire Reborn is one of if not the best roguelike games I have played. Yes it may make you a furry, but that's just the price you have to pay to play a one of kind game like this o7
brick best weapon, when funny star things collect, it become GOLD BRICKKK!!!!!!
funfire Beborn ; multiplayer is dead.

Gunfire Reborn is easily the most polished, feature-rich, and addictive roguelite FPS on the market. The roguelike/roguelite genre as a whole has had a slow journey into the FPS genre-hybrid, and among all of its competitors I would consider Gunfire Reborn to be essentially peerless at the moment. Don't let the whimsical, cartoonish artstyle put you off of an amazingly gratifying instanced looter-shooter experience-- even back in early access this game managed to squeeze roughly 50 hours of playtime out of me, and now that the game is in its finished 1.0 state and is being updated with small character/weapon DLCs, its calling me back for EVEN MORE runs.

The core gameplay in this game is PHENOMENAL. Well paced, deeply satisfying, and deceptively complex. Each weapon you happen upon during a run is amazingly unique and intricate-- and beyond that, each weapon drop comes with an additional set of modifiers to add to its unique characteristics. Gunfire Reborn's weapon roster spans a delightful range of forms & figures; including hefty rocket launchers, nimble SMGs, 'Iron Man' style laser gloves, flaming kunai, and much more. The game's arsenal has something for every mood and every playstyle, which is absolutely crucial to the gameplay loop of any roguelite.
Something else integral to a roguelite's depth is power-ups, or modifiers. Throughout each of its stages, Gunfire Reborn will present the player with heaps of augments to specialize your build. Building a run based on fire damage? Start boosting your elemental DOT! Relying heavily on grenade spam? Increase your grenade's damage or carrying capacity! Feeling sluggish? Why not invest heavily in movement upgrades? This build diversity helps Gunfire Reborn to succeed not just as a first person shooter, but also as a bonafide roguelite.
The level design is fantastic as well in this game! Each zone feels memorable and diverse, as well as being loaded with uniquely challenging enemies. Complete with secret zones, shop/upgrade NPCs, as well as a variety of level bosses, progressing through a run of Gunfire Reborn is a satisfyingly impactful and atmospheric experience, in no small part due to the actual locales it will have you fight your way through.
Speaking of fighting: The enemies you will be pitted against during your run are wonderfully imaginative and (for the most part) always a joy to fight. The game's cartoon style, while perhaps off-putting to some, lends itself to some fantastic enemy designs. Possessed terracotta soldiers, teleporting bird snipers, fireball casting lizard sorcerers, umbrella shaped yokai, giant rocket lobsters-- its all here, and waiting to swiftly end your run. Enemies are also occasionally given special shield/armour bars, which are weak to specific elemental damage types, further deepening the combat/character building experience. Fans of the 'Borderlands' franchise should feel right at home with this elemental weakness/resistance system. At the best of times, Gunfire Reborn's enemy variety serves to give it a frantic, almost "boomer shooter"-esque quality-- and one I find to be sorely lacking among other roguelite FPS games. 
The art direction is very colourful and engaging, and paints a picture of a chaotic, vibrant fantasy world. While the animations aren't necessarily in the same league as the work of modern triple A titles, enemy movement, reload animations, boss attacks, etc... are all very fluid and expressive. Gunfire Reborn might not be a gritty, hardcore take on the FPS genre, it isn't trying to be, and benefits on the whole from its stylization.
Sound design in this game is... mostly pretty good. Gunshots feel impactful, minor FX and embellishments are solid, dealing/receiving damage feels responsive, and the character voice lines are... alright. Gunfire Reborn may not have the same immersive soundscapes as something like CoD or Battlefield, but its eccentric sound design works well within its cartoon artstyle.

Overall, Gunfire Reborn is a deeply mechanically satisfying and nicely polished FPS roguelite, and currently stands out as the absolute best of its hybrid genre. (Not that there's a TON of competition at the moment.) The game is still being updated with free content as well as paid DLCs at the time of writing this review, so its only getting more dense with features as time goes on. Gunfire Reborn is absolutely the type of game that will have you glued to your chair at 3am, promising yourself that THIS run will TOTALLY be LAST ONE of the night. (It won't.) I love this game deeply, and if you're a fan of roguelikes/roguelites and/or FPS games, there's a solid chance that YOU will too.

applist.name: Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen
applist.detailed_description:
Set in a huge open world, Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen presents a rewarding action combat experience. Players embark on an epic adventure in a rich, living world with three AI companions, known as Pawns. These partners fight independently, demonstrating prowess and ability that they have developed based on traits learned from each player. PC users can share these Pawns online and reap rewards of treasure, tips and strategy hints for taking down the terrifying enemies. Pawns can also be borrowed when specific skills are needed to complete various challenging quests.

Features

  • Dynamic combat experience – Cut off the four heads of a Hydra, climb atop griffins and fight airborne, or defeat dragons and other creatures by finding out their weaknesses.
  • Tons of content – Includes all previously released DLCs, pre-order bonuses, retailer-exclusives, and the Dark Arisen expansion content. Features the highly praised combat experience and rich customization, plus a huge underground realm to explore with terrifying monsters.
  • Customization options galore – Nine different vocations for players to choose from with a variety of skill options for each, armor that can be upgraded and enhanced, plus Pawn companions that can be trained to fit your desired combat style.
  • Stunning visuals – Beautiful high res graphics with increased fidelity.
  • Full Steam platform support – Includes Steam Achievements, Steam Cloud Save, Trading Cards, Leaderboards, Big Picture Mode support
  • Expanded controller support – In addition to supporting the traditional keyboard and mouse control scheme, the game natively supports Xbox 360, Xbox One, Steam Controller, and other DirectInput-based game pads such as the DualShock controller.
  • New Achievements - 9 brand new Achievements for both new and returning Dragon’s Dogma fans! Get ready to delve deep into Bitterblack Isle…

reviews.review: That Dragon's Dogma 2 trailer was sexy. Time to play the game
They're masterworks all, you can't go wrong!

Easily among the best adventure games of all time, despite its few flaws.

Absolutely great action combat that goes out of its way to really fulfill the immersive fantasy. When you play a big hulking warrior swinging a massive sword, you feel like it. When you play an athletic scoundrel archer you really feel like it. When you play a fragile mage trying to cast difficult, complex and devastating spells, you really get the reward of feeling like it.

The dramatic gothic-romance of grim fantasy oozes from every pore. From desperately surviving your first encounters with goblins to heroically climbing upon a giant monster to stab it repeatedly while clinging for dear life all the way to the truly most-epic dragon fight in video  game history ... and beyond. I can think of only a few games which manage to give skeletons crawling from dusty ancient tombs the very real chill of horror and fear that they deserve. Alien nightmares erupt around you deep within the forgotten bowels of a mysterious dungeon giving an immediate sense of urgent confusion and the very real knowledge that sometimes the wise course of action is to flee from an overwhelming foe - if you can.

NPCs are a little bit perfunctory in some cases. This is not an RPG. The characters in the world are there to serve a purpose, not to develop a relationship with or to demonstrate their own personality. Some of them are far more interesting and charming than others, of course, but in the end dialogue in this game (although there's plenty enough of it) is not a major focus of development. Ironically, the soulless pawns that travel with you have the most to say about... everything. Their comments are helpful, insightful, informative or even just encouraging and supportive. Sadly, the "romance" system is not really for the purpose of romance, it's for the sake of an important plot point later in the game - one which was handled very... abstractly.

The bad? Well. They're more like complaints, really. The user interface is an archaic and clumsy mess. The game was created with limited controllers in mind, and this makes navigating menus for either inventory management or equipment comparison into a dreadfully tedious chore compounded by how harshly limited your carry capacity is (though this is necessary for gameplay balance reasons). At some point it will feel like you have plenty of options in terms of equipment to compare between, but often it will feel like there just isn't anything you really want to wear (an important consideration since dressing up your pawn is a major motive for exploration, and the camera is over the shoulder so you want to look good for your own sake even from behind). Overall, the itemization is a bit too limited and most equipment just isn't very different from any of the rest (though the few things that do stand out will become your favorites... and you'll never unequip it for the rest of the game...).

The most serious complaint, however, is that the world is ... a bit sparse. Which makes it feel a lot smaller than it actually is. This is difficult to really explain, though, because for the first forty hours you play, you'll discover some random new dungeon or weird little secret and it'll feel amazing - and it will be amazing. Eventually though, you'll realize that for every new little dungeon you discover, you've passed by three blank alleys in Gran Soren with absolutely nothing in them. You can wander around and constantly ask "why isn't there anything here?" for hours and hours and hours while exploring. There's nothing behind the cathedral. It's just a big open space where nothing ever happens. There's no point to the huge empty plateau, you only go there for one minor quest and it takes like ten minutes to run across it. Some games from a similar era of game development like the Elder Scrolls managed to pack way more content into worlds of comparable size. It doesn't need to all be on the "overland" map (where the drama of traveling to suddenly have to desperately fend off a bandit ambush is a major part of what makes this a grim low-fantasy epic story). But it'd be nice if Gran Soren were actually a city and not just three merchants with a five minute walk to get to the castle where The Quests are handed out.

Even so, any sequel could surely rake in mountains of cash if it were accomplished with even comparable quality.

This one still manages to very fairly earn its place among the greats. If you like Skyrim, for example, you absolutely owe it to yourself to play Dragon's Dogma.

applist.name: Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor - Martyr
applist.detailed_description:
Sororitas Class DLC out now!

https://store.steampowered.com/app/2138210


About the Game

A STORY-DRIVEN SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN

Far from the guiding light of the God-Emperor, torn apart by the foul tempests that distort reality, the Caligari Sector is slowly rotting away from the inside, tainted by the Chaos Gods. Purge the unclean with the most powerful agents of the Imperium!


Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor – Martyr is grim action-RPG set in the violent 41st millennium, when the galaxy is at constant war. Become a mighty Inquisitor and carry out the Emperor’s will. Choose one of the multiple classes and take part in brutal combat encounters: embark on a huge variety of missions with your fellow agents and fight through the single-player story campaign set on a haunted fortress-monastery which hides a terrible secret from the past of the Inquisition.

THE NEXT MILESTONE IN THE EVOLUTION OF ARPGS


The first Action-RPG set in the grim future of the 41st Millennium takes the genre to its next level: an open-world sandbox game with a persistent universe with a huge variety of missions, tactical, brutal combat encounters in destructible environments and a storyline influenced by the community of players. Use the cover system for tactical advantage, perform executions in epic boss battles and become a Protector of any solar systems with your glorious actions!

INQUISITORS: SECRET AGENTS AND SPECIALISTS


Forge your own playstyle with different character classes and specializations: hold your ground with the Crusader Inquisitor while enemies close in on you, bring in your finesse and cunning with the Death Cult Assassin background, or use the unspeakable powers of the Warp with the Primaris Psyker background. Choose from three specializations for each classes that fit your playstyle.

TRAVERSE A WHOLE GALACTIC SECTOR


Explore the Star Map of the vast Caligari Sector, travel in different subsectors and explore an immense amount of solar systems, visit a growing number of unique points of interests: investigate on different planets with distinctive terrain conditions, fight your way through corridors of infested Void Stations, abandoned Star Forts and other diverse environments!

FIGHT THE CORRUPTION TOGETHER


You can go solo as a lonely Inquisitor, but you can also assemble a team of your friends! Play missions in co-operative mode with up to 4 team members, blast away your foes together claiming great rewards, and form Cabals to gather your close allies! Inquisitorial Cabals are groups of Inquisitors working together. Cabals can progress just like characters do, and being a member can often grant special missions. The Inquisition has a lot of different factions with different agendas, and Cabals sometimes clash with each other in the shadows.

IMPROVE YOUR WEAPONS, CRAFT MISSIONS AND TWEAK YOUR SKILLS


Looking for a specific loot or reward? Use Uther’s Tarot to set the conditions of your next mission, collect Blueprints and use Crafting to improve your equipment, and use the Inoculator to fine-tune your different skills. Choose your loadout to your advantage for each mission!

A LIVING, EXPANDING WORLD

Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor – Martyr is an ever-growing, long-lasting experience. Expansions and regular free updates will introduce new enemy factions, new terrain settings, new missions and mission types, new story-driven investigations and new gameplay features.
Chapters are big, free updates that will introduce longer story arcs in which players can shape the persistent world of the Caligari sector with their actions. Global Events and Chapters ensure new challenges – there’s always something new to explore or to collect!

reviews.review: Its pretty upsetting to buy the 'complete' edition, then the first thing you see when loading up the game (It crashes often mind you) is a class locked behind a DLC. Like, why are you saying this is a 'complete' edition when it really isn't. I cant be too mad because I got it on sale when it was hugely discounted, but still... dont say complete edition and expect people to be ok when you lock stuff behind a payed DLC.
Game is unplayable because it's always online and I am disconected mid missions. Can't even play solo.

First thing I will say this game has no business being Online-Only.
It's a massive restriction that's annoying and limits the potential of the game.

The game is good I recommend you get it on sale.
However most of the negatives you see from other reviews about the game are 90% true and real.

I personally love playing the game when listening to an Album/Podcast in the background.
The Graphics, Story and Gameplay is pretty well-done, even though the level design could be improved on.

The Game is absolutely god-aweful at explaining how the systems works.
I spent most of the time reading the in-game Journal to even understand what most of the things mean or do.
All the 'tutorial' and 'hints' are useless, they never tell you anything important.

Only when I was 40+ Hours in did I find out my 'Sororitas' can turn into an 'Embodied Saint' for a period of time because the game never tells you.
I had to find out about the 'Tarot Card' system from a YouTube video about the game.

So most of the charm about the will definitely be missed for new players like myself.
Buy the game on sale it's really fun but will be difficult and a bit repetitive later on.

Purchased the "Complete Edition" and the very first thing that pops up when I launch the game is an advertisement for a DLC I don't have. I really don't like it when companies aren't truthful in their advertising.

Aside from some occasional control issues when Items clutter the battle field during a fight and the game prioritizes looking at them instead of moving, or fighting, or pretty much doing anything other than staring at the floor and taking the beating, its pretty fun.

90 percent of the time the game is like firing a howitzer into a koi pond, but then again, sometimes its just nice to be fishing.

Ultimately, If its on sale and you're looking for some mindless mayhem with a coat of Warhammer paint on it, Inquisitor is worth the look.
At least its not a Blizzard game.

A quick overview of the game's post-release evolution. When this game released, it felt very sluggish  - moving, engaging, looting all felt slow. The devs did a massive overhaul of combat, increasing movement speed, combat moves and cooldowns, and there are simple loot filter and auto-pickup options (neither of which need to be enabled. They are off by default). This level of attention after the release of the game, when other devs might have moved on, is remarkable to me. They took a game that was Not Bad and made it into something very memorable to me.

After that overhaul, seasons with unique season mechanics began. These have unique mechanics that cause enemies and/or anomalies to appear in normal missions and interacting with these give you progress toward season-specific boss missions. The season will also have a new type of affix that can now appear on weapons (such as one affix that allows you to release lightning on hit or being hit while other affixes combine to make it chain longer or do more damage, etc). There are also the equivalent of runewords (psalm-code doctrines) and the components can be removed at any time and leave both the item and components intact for use in other gear.

The sound is good, especially the fighting sounds of guns, melee, fire, explosions and more. There's nothing like jump packing into a mob that explodes as you use a las cannon or flamer to melt the survivors. The story is fine though nothing to write home about. Leveling is steady even at higher levels, making the tarot cards that give extra XP feel like viable options.

There are a couple options for endgame. You can continue regular missions (of which there are 10 types) that you can do to earn gear and reputation in the respective systems (of which there are 20). Acquiring reputation unlocks additional systems and, more importantly, tarot cards. Tarot cards are the difficulty + reward multipliers for any endgame map. A card will specify the type of negative and positive it will give you - I.E. melee enemies get a random damage or defensive buff but you have a chance to double the end-of-mission rewards. Some tarot cards also raise the area level until it is many above your own, allowing the game to continue scaling after level 100.

There are also random intel missions which are short quest chains with a reward at the end and it provides you 2-3 mission types to choose from at each step.

The main endgame option is Void Crusades. There are 9 different ones, each with its own static map creating a web that connects the nodes. You can path through the web differently depending on if you want the maximum reward chests at the end or if you want to save the nodes that raise the difficulty of all remaining levels so that you have an easier run overall.

I haven't touched on many things like the solid crafting/rerolling system (you can modify all but one class of item as many times as you want) or character classes (3 base classes with 3 specializations each in Inquisitor, the WH40K:Inquisitor - Prophecy stand-alone game has another campaign and character with it that can also be used in this game, and the Sororitas DLC that came out recently is a 5th class (class only, no new campaign/missions).

I've played this game on and off for years. I never bought into the random negativity in the discussion board. I just get on for a few weeks at a time and have fun purging heretics, xenos, and daemons.

Fun game. The first 4 hours seemed like minutes.
Positive key points:
- A lot of mission and item variety.
- The game runs smoothly.
- The story is surprisingly good if you are into Warhammer 40K.
- The graphics and design are great.
- Mission duration is on average between 10-25m depndending on the difficulty.
- The game crashed once in 35 hours and on the menu, so I'm pretty happy with that.
- Average - good items start poping up early, so the game scales nice.
- The difficulty selection in the missions and how it's described is a great advantage.

Negative key points:
- The start is a bit complex (no interactive tutorial, just reading text).
- There are a few bugs in gameplay that need refinement:
    - Playing the tech adept, you're contructs(support npc's) get stuck behind items or stay inactive while you are fighting, once in a while.
    - The switch between weapon sets is not very fluid.
    - Enemies can thrown behind walls after a knockdown, which then become untargetable until they come out.

Still a very enjoyable game that I can only recommend, wether you like Warhammer or not.

I unfortunately ultimately can't recommend the game, even though it has a lot going for it. Leveling up, going through the campaign, playing all of the classes, are all fun to do. I love the Warhammer 40k setting, but the game really falls apart at endgame.

To put it into perspective, this is the first season I participated in and the first time I fully completed the campaign. After putting in 160 hrs into this season, I still haven't had the one piece of armour with the enchant I need on it to finish my basic build. The make matters worse, it is of a rarity type that you aren't able to reroll the enchant in hopes of getting to one you need. The chances of finding a specific type of armour with the exact enchant you need is astronomical. 

  I also have not yet been able to complete the last seasonal goal of upgrading a tarot card to level 3. The reason for this is that if you upgrade your tarot cards when you can, as a player would naturally do, you have just added weeks, months, or even years to your grind without knowing it. The only way you can avoid that is to stumble upon a new player tips guide or forum post somewhere before you make that mistake. It also means that when I unlock a new type of tarot card from gaining reputation in a star system, I'm not happy about it, but get angry because they just instantly added another week to the grind. I ended up adding weeks of extra RNG to my tarot card upgrading before I found out how the system works. 

I can say I will not participate in endgame again, as the amount of RNG and grind is unreal. It rivals any mobile game, but in mobile games at least people have the option to pay to speed up their progress and not spend months or years grinding it out. Whoever runs the maths on this stuff is so out of touch with reality.

I change this review to negative after many days of playing. 

The game uses some server system that is not Peer-to-peer, and is susceptible to how busy it is. 
Sometimes, a server can not be found so you can not play coop.
Sometimes, a server is found but it is very laggy (ping over 300)
Sometimes, a server randomly STOPS!

Me and a buddy lost our Void Crusade (a rogue-lite game mode with good rewards at the end). We had the final boss in the final mission at 30% and we got KICKED with the message 'server shut down'.


There is no more support for this game, so see this review as a caution: you may lose progress in multiplayer randomly.

applist.name: POSTAL: Brain Damaged
applist.detailed_description:
MORE UPCOMING HYPERSTRANGENESS - CHECK OUT REDNECK GOLF VS ZOMBIES!

https://store.steampowered.com/app/2330380/NecroGolf/


About the Game

Get ready to experience POSTAL from a brand-new perspective!

This boomer-shooter spin-off of the fan-beloved Running With Scissors’ franchise will take you further down the rabbit hole than any previous game of the series. You’re not in Paradise anymore, and things are about to get weird, as POSTAL: Brain Damaged happens within the twisted psyche of the POSTAL DUDE, himself! Yes, a whole new, retro-modern, action-oriented, skill-based approach to POSTAL. "Did HYPERSTRANGE pull it off" - you might ask. Oh, yes. It seems we did:



Wild setting? Even wilder gameplay! While staying true to POSTAL’S trademark tone and humor the game plays very different to all the previous titles in the series. What you get is fast, challenging, and full of varied, meticulously designed enemies and environments. If you’re surfing the tidal wave of throwback shooters or enjoyed the latest installment of that game where you single-handily take on the forces of Hell invading Earth, you will feel right at home (even more so if your home smells really bad).

Make sure your body is ready to:
  • Explore an all-new, hand-crafted world full of surprises
  • Experience the challenging, fast-paced gameplay with quake-like movement and outrageous level design
  • Take a trip through the rich, twisted, ever-changing environments of POSTAL DUDE’S deranged mind
  • Shoot a variety of insane guns at some of the freakiest enemies to ever grace computer screens
  • Follow the all-original story line making the POSTAL-VERSE continuity even more effed-up than it was
  • Hear Corey Cruise returning as the POSTAL DUDE, with guest appearances from other fan-beloved voices
  • Enjoy the POSTAL series trademark dark, crude humor and glorification of fantasy violence

It’s a mad game for the mad times, kids! From the studio that brought you ELDERBORN and Blood West, comes the first-person shooter you didn't know you need in your life - POSTAL: Brain Damaged.

BUY, BUY, BUY! DON'T GET JUST ONE, GET TWO! YOU KNOW YOU WANT TO!

applist.name: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege
applist.detailed_description:
Edition Comparison


Deluxe Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Deluxe Edition includes the full game and 16 operators from Years 1 and 2.


Operator Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Operator Edition includes the full game and all 46 operators from Years 1–7.


Ultimate Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Ultimate Edition includes the full game, all 46 operators from Years 1–7, and more.


Technical Test Server



This is the Technical Test Server client for Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege. This platform will be used to test new features in a controlled environment that allows the development team to iterate without impacting the live game.

o Please note :
- The T.T.S. client is built off of several different builds at various stages of development, and may not represent the overall quality of the game.
- Features seen on the T.T.S. might never make it in the final game: various components are still in conceptual stages and might be discarded throughout the development process. Certain ideas that were postponed or cancelled might also be found in the T.T.S. as a result.
- You need to own a version of the game (Standard, Gold, Complete or Starter Edition) to unlock this product
- The TTS will only function during specific timeframes.


About the Game

“One of the best first-person shooters ever made. 10\10” – GameSpot

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege is an elite, realistic, tactical team-based shooter where superior planning and execution triumph. It features 5v5 attack vs. defense gameplay and intense close-quarters combat in destructible environments.


Engage in a brand-new style of assault using an unrivaled level of destruction and gadgetry.
On defense, coordinate with your team to transform your environments into strongholds. Trap, fortify and create defensive systems to prevent being breached by the enemy.
On attack, lead your team through narrow corridors, barricaded doorways and reinforced walls. Combine tactical maps, observation drones, rappelling and more to plan, attack and defuse every situation.


Choose from dozens of highly trained, Special Forces operators from around the world. Deploy the latest technology to track enemy movement. Shatter walls to open new lines of fire. Breach ceilings and floors to create new access points. Employ every weapon and gadget from your deadly arsenal to locate, manipulate and destroy your enemies and the environment around them.


Experience new strategies and tactics as Rainbow Six Siege evolves over time. Change the rules of Siege with every update that includes new operators, weapons, gadgets and maps. Evolve alongside the ever-changing landscape with your friends and become the most experienced and dangerous operators out there.


Compete against others from around the world in ranked match play. Grab your best squad and join the competitive community in weekly tournaments or watch the best professional teams battle it out in the Rainbow Six Siege Pro League.

reviews.review: The more I play this game the more I hate myself.

Absolute nightmare. Teammates will make you angry, game breaking bugs still occur at times, matchmaking is a mess, and a lot of the maps are not good.
Also the most unique competitive fps games ever made, and when it clicks it's one of the best. Do not solo queue though because it will make you want to jump off a roof.

Got a cat here. Friends passing by can touch her by clicking Like to pet her once.
　　　　 　　 ＿＿
　　　 　　／＞　　フ
　　　 　　| 　_　 _ l
　 　　 　／` ミ＿xノ
　　 　 /　　　 　 |
　　　 /　 ヽ　　 ﾉ
　 　 │　　|　|　|
　／￣|　　 |　|　|
　| (￣ヽ＿_ヽ_)__)
　二つ

Eat my nuts Ubisoft, you are so grossly disconnected from your community. It is a true shame to watch a game that you enjoyed and loved be slowly butchered by a company that only exists to slowly drain the wallets of their fan base. I sternly believe that Ubisoft purposefully brings out stupid updates and changes to slowly kill the community so that they can let the game die and move on to other projects, while also doing crossover events to steal the money of their dedicated player base. I think ubisoft is just ashamed to come outright and say that they don't want to support or update the game anymore, and just wish to slowly kill the game along with its community.

Ubisoft, long ago, ever since they switched dev teams, have lost sight of what siege was supposed to be. Siege is unique, the original path of the game was to have it be a sort of in-between your average arcade shooter and your slow tactical shooters like Ready or Not. However, over the last several years, I feel as though this concept has been lost on Ubisoft, they even try to vilify the part of the community which disagrees by creating the character Deimos. This brings me to the story, why the hell is there one. The lore of the game was that Rainbow Six was a multi-national counter terrorist agency designed to eliminate the most dangerous of terrorist threats. Great, stellar, that is all we needed. Nighthaven was a decent concept, but it was executed so poorly. I think it would have been great to add a PMC group to the team, seems great, but then you give them ungodly advanced levels of technology, rivaling and even surpassing entire nations, that then for some reason creeps into the lore of certain gadgets. It was so unnecessary to do this, I just don't understand why it was done at all. An actual story was and is being developed, and I can't understand why, they bring in a character named Deimos who they say is the villain, yet his only flaw is his moral compass. He is objectively right about rainbow six as a whole, it being a joke and no longer the intimidating counter terrorist organization it once was. Early on in their development of the story, they transition the leader of Rainbow from some lady to some British guy named Harry. This was the start of the fall for siege, as it signified the start of this random ass story building that they wanted to do. 

Now a bad story may not necessarily mean the gameplay is bad... except it fucking blows ass. Ubisoft, in the same way they ruin the story, they bring out certain changes to slowly ruin the game. Sledge is a prime example, he was a good operator, in no way broken, he wasn't even very highly picked, yet they took away his smg 11 and made him a 1 armor, and then to add insult to injury they took away his acog later on. What was the point of this, he was never broken or over picked, he was pretty well balanced, and now he is just a worse pick than buck or ash. While not all balance changes are as bad as this, the vast majority of changes that Ubisoft decides to bring out are just bad for balancing. They also have a tendency to nerf things rather than to buff them, or if they do buff operators, they don't make an impactful change. This leads to all ops becoming worse and therefore not as fun, rather than uplifting other ops and making those more fun. The last set of changes have been things such as the UI or kill indicator. They had no reason to change any of these, especially the ubisoft overlay which barely even works and somehow still buggy despite being years after release. The kill indicator is no longer quite as satisfying and snappy as it once was, which makes kills feel less rewarding and not as fun. Continuing, the UI is just a mess. It is confusing, especially for new players, and was so unnecessary. It also plays more into the concept of this game becoming more arcady and "cartoony". Lastly, and likely one of the worst changes so far, is the ranked 2.0 system. For some reason, people fail to understand how it works, so the rundown is basically that there are two mmrs that a player has, a hidden and visible, the hidden is what actually pits players against each other, the the visible just exists as its own thing? Like who verified that this was a working system, why in gods name did they try to be innovative on a system that was tried and tested? The hidden mmr system just doesn't seem to work, pitting what would be ranked 1.0 plats against ranked 1.0 champs. Leading to imbalanced, irritating, or boring games, along with poor balancing. The visible mmr also serves no purpose, as it is criminally easy to hit higher ranks, leading to a more than 1000% increase in the amount of Champions. Why does it exist, why are players not given a ranked based off who they play with, why is it based off how well they play against their specific skill level? It leaves no incentives to improve and only the incentive to play and hit champ. The fact that a person with a 12% win loss can hit champ is disgusting. The best of the best of players are the ones meant to be hitting the highest rank in the game, yet for some unholy reason, they just invite morons into the group. If I remember correctly, take this with a pinch of salt, I believe their justification for this was to "reward players not just based off skill but also how much they play". They essentially removed the ranked part of the definition of ranked. If I played chess for 16 hours a day for the rest of my life, but remain among the worst players of the game, why in gods name should I be given the title Grandmaster when I would not be able to compete against any other legit Grandmaster? It makes no sense to reward people for play time, and grant them something that they do not deserve. The incentive to play in ranked 1.0 was to improve so that you could hit the higher rank. Without the need to improve, it leaves the community overall worse. Maybe the devs brought it out so they could finally hit a rank past gold.

No words, not even an entire essay, could describe my dissatisfaction with Ubisoft and how they have handled this game. They have failed the community, the gameplay, and somehow, the core concept of the game itself. It would take an utter buffoon to see what is happening and think to themselves, "this is perfectly fine". Take a lesson from any competitive shooter and stop focusing on your casual community. I think the view point of focusing on it to just be completely wrong. While it may bring temporary life into the game, most casual players don't really care about the game and can leave on a whim. Focusing on the ranked community, particularly those at the top bracket to ensure the longevity of a game as those are the people who tend to be the most passionate about the game. Further, the devs of this game either don't really play the game or suck ass at it, so they aren't even good at understanding balance changes. For a lot of games, the devs are actually pretty good at the game, this is because they built the game so they understand it. I would think the devs for Siege, now being the one's making it, would also understand it. Of course not that would be smart and reasonable.

I will sadly, and much to my own chagrin, keep playing the game. This is because there is no other game around like it, and frankly,  this is the only reason the game is still around. Everyone shits on EA for their crappy economy decisions in their games, yet for a lot of the games, they improve and fix this issue, and even in the case of the sports clones, it is easy to just avoid their copys. Just look at battlefront 2, it is a stellar game now but it did release to some controversy. Yet Ubisoft, rather than trying to improve their game, reward the worse parts of the community, and sacrificing everyone who actually cares about the game. They are as arrogant and foolish as Narcissus, since both Ubisoft and he fell in love with themselves.

Was good, gets worse each season.

i have to say, i'm deeply disappointed with the direction rainbow six siege has taken, especially since the release of ela. the game used to rely on strategy, communication, and careful planning. but with ela, the delicate balance that made siege stand out among other shooters has been disturbed, turning it into something more like a standard run-and-gun title.

but my biggest gripe, the real knife to the heart, is the mishandling of the character "havoc." havoc was teased in the game's e3 trailer, portrayed as this intriguing, menacing character who was supposed to bring an exciting twist to the game. the trailer did an excellent job of building hype around havoc - the character's design, menacing aura, and what appeared to be a unique gameplay mechanic.

the trailer painted a vivid picture of havoc as a new villain, a ruthless operator, who seemed to be bringing a new level of intensity and danger to siege. it suggested that his arrival would significantly shake up the game's dynamics, posing new challenges and creating fresh strategies for players to explore.

however, this was all a pipe dream. despite all the hype, despite all the anticipation built up, havoc is nowhere to be found in the actual game. it's a classic case of false advertising and has left many fans, including me, feeling betrayed. we were promised something exciting, something groundbreaking, but what we got was a no-show.

and if the mishandling of havoc wasn't enough, the writing has also gone down the drain, exemplified by the addition of "dokkaebi." her bio intro is just cringeworthy: "her fingers dance across the keyboard, the light of the lcd screen underscoring her smirk." it's a cheesy line that feels out of place and makes her character feel shallow and uninspired. it's not the level of writing one would expect from a game with the pedigree of rainbow six siege.

it's hard not to feel misled and deceived. the absence of havoc in the game is like a promising movie trailer with no actual film to follow. it's like being served a mouthwatering menu with no food to eat. it's not just about one character - it's about broken promises and shattered expectations.

the game has deviated from its roots, focusing on quick action and flashy gimmicks rather than on deep, tactical gameplay. the introduction of ela, the misleading portrayal of havoc, and the cringe-worthy writing for dokkaebi have made siege lose its identity, and it's a real shame.

in conclusion, if you loved rainbow six siege for its strategic depth, teamwork, and engaging characters, you might want to give it a miss for now. unless the developers make a U-turn and steer the game back to its roots, it's hard to see this title reclaiming its former glory. so until then, i can't recommend this game.

applist.name: Cult of the Lamb
applist.detailed_description:
Cult of the Lamb: Relics of the Old Faith



The Lamb must keep their Cult flourishing, their Followers faithful, and their power unchallenged as they crusade in this free content expansion, Relics of the Old Faith. It adds brand new ways to spread the gospel of the Cult of the Lamb with powerful new abilities, exciting new characters, and thrilling new challenges.

Delve into the shrouded history of the Lands of the Old Faith as the Lamb fights to conquer those who would question their power. New Cult buildings will appease your Followers while new combat abilities will smite opposing heretics. Uncover the secrets of the Old Faith so you can be the God you want to be in this massive content expansion!

New Combat

The expansion brings a deeper layer to dungeon crawling for new and returning players. With powerful Relic abilities, heavy attacks for each weapon class, and dozens of items to find, the Lamb will unleash delightful devastation.

New Postgame

Another challenge awaits after completing the main story. Revamped dungeons, mysterious characters and challenging boss encounters are in your new quest as the God of Death. Along the way, you can unlock Follower forms, fleeces, unchosen doctrines and more.

New Challenges

Put your skills to the test with several new challenge modes for combatively competent Cult leaders. Boss Rush, Permadeath and other unique challenges await after defeating the final boss.

Cult of the Lamb: Heretic Pack


https://store.steampowered.com/app/2331540/Cult_of_the_Lamb_Heretic_Pack/


About the Game



Cult of the Lamb casts players in the role of a possessed lamb saved from annihilation by an ominous stranger, and must repay their debt by building a loyal following in his name. Start your own cult in a land of false prophets, venturing out into diverse and mysterious regions to build a loyal community of woodland Followers and spread your Word to become the one true cult.

BUILD YOUR FLOCK

Collect and use resources to build new structures, perform dark rituals to appease the gods, and give sermons to reinforce the faith of your flock.

DESTROY THE NON-BELIEVERS

Explore a sprawling, randomly generated world, fight off hordes of enemies and defeat rival cult leaders in order to absorb their power and assert your cult's dominance.

SPREAD YOUR WORD

Train your flock and embark on a quest to explore and discover the secrets of four mysterious regions. Cleanse the non-believers, spread enlightenment, and perform mystical rituals on the journey to become the mighty lamb god.
