reviews.review:
This is like hades combined with stardew, you play it like binding of issac, but got a hollow knight vibe to it and you walk through the maps like inscryption
10/10 i love it

Cult of the Lamb is an amazing game. The best part of this game is the art style and cult management system because it helps the player really get sucked into the world and feel like a cult leader. You decided how devious or benevolent you want to be to your followers and other NPC. The base building system is mostly well done, I like the large variety of buildings, but there still could be some more automation in the later game when you have 15-20 followers. I think the soundtrack is good, and a few songs have got stuck in my head. The flaw of Cult of the Lamb is the roguelike gameplay, the enemies and bosses need more attack variety, or maybe I should have played on a harder difficulty for more challenge.

The most important thing you should know before purchasing is that Cult of the Lamb feels like two thirds base building and cult management and only one third combat. So Stardew Valley players rejoice and Binding of Isaac players might be sad and think Cult of the Lamb is over hyped and has a lack of replayability.

I didn't think I would enjoy playing as a cult leader being a lamb so much, playing around being in control of your own flock of peeps. The Controls are easy and simple, it really is addictive always something to do and it is very good for people who just want a chill time,but quite fun. You do have to repetitive tasks to do, but its a good way to waste a few hours, if your not sure on what to do. it is always quite easy to level up on and get stronger, and you can choose to be evil fully or equally generous leader, I have not come a cross any bugs through the game. you can name them what ever you like, they can even be swear words if you so choose to. a great game to have fun on would recommend anyone to try this. the only thing you can't control is the traits of your followers which is randomly generated by the game but If you don't like the traits you can sacrifice the follower later on by feasting on them, taking them to missions to find resources knowing that they will die if they fail you know normal evil things :). Please try it out for yourself.

Excellent game, works great on the steam deck but PC is good as well. Haven't been so engrossed in a game for a long time, just ate up all my free hours. The followers and their adorable little voices and animations, the cozy village, the sinister overtones of the whole setting and the satisfying combat sections, all blended perfectly by the fantastic atmospheric soundtrack.
The progression is very linear. The first 5 hours was fun, but there's too little content.
As absurd as the trailer made it out to be. 11/10; must-play.
Never posted a review before but would recommend this game 10/10. Totally addictive! Also the designs/visuals are the cutest.

If you truly believe in any god, you better skip this one. If you don't[spoiler], or you always wanted to maybe even become one [/spoiler] you're gonna love this game like me. It has a couple bugs that are getting fixed regularly, a story that was pretty much doubled and is still being worked on, simply gorgeous graphics and lots to explore. 
I didn't know I was into 2D dungeons and micromanagement until I stumbled onto this beauty.
My personal grade is a great 9/10 with lots of potential to become a 10/10 Love it! Keep up the good work, devs! <3
100% completion in 81 hours, love the game, will cult again

Beautiful art. Amazing, head-bumping, soundtrack. More fluent "Isaac" gameplay, and some nice [strike]base[/strike]cult building action.

About 30 hrs of game-play in the game currently in my opinion. Even though devs introduced some end-game recently in the dungeons but there was no updates in regards to the second part - your cult(even though you can always place more decorations and stuff), and I have to say there's better rogulites IMO if you're just looking to do some runs(Hades still on top tbh)

I can easily recommend this game if you like what you see in the trailer and screenshots - trust me you, won't be dissapointed. 

And I'm hoping for more to come in terms of the updates. Roadmap looking busy. DLCs are not necessary, only to support the devs(I bought one).

Cult of the Lamb is an amazing diverse game. Half of the game is action adventure with some RPG elements & the other half of the game is base building cult simulator. It's great how you can't play this game one half without the other half and how both are well developed & fun to do. Besides making sure that you become a powerful warrior lamb and keeping your followers fed & away from being sick, there is a ton of fun to be had with certain mini games like fishing or gambling by playing dice. Beware of cool soundtrack, cute visuals and some sinister events during the story mode! It's also amazing to see the developers giving free updates & patches on a regular basis. Anyone who has a Twitch account or enjoys games like Don't Starve or Dante's Inferno, should definitely give this game a try!
Love this game!! It’s so cute, I put many hours in very quickly, definitely recommend!

A fun and original, rogue like "build-em-up". Be a benevolent (or malevolent) little lamb crusading in the lands of the Old Faith, while rescuing (and indoctrinating) the cutest animal followers, and building a temple worthy of your power. For what is a shepard without a flock?

Don't be The One Who Waits. Get the game now! 🐑
Jack of all trades, master of none. Still had a lot of fun.

Great idea, lovely aesthetic and solid production values.
But also CotL is shallow and tedious, always with a rush (because the clock is ticking, always). And generally feels grindy.
Once the aesthetics wear off, it's a very passable action game mixed with a below-mediocre village sim. Plus some UI/UX weirdness and annoying bugs (performance dropping to a crawl inside some menus!)

Definitely overhyped.

LIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD!!!


Cult of the Lamb is a unique game to say the least, the game is about you being a leader of a cult and you gotta kill the other cults too. It has some fun features but still has some downsides. Its still a really great game and heres a few some pros and cons so lets begin:

PROS
-Progression is quick(WHICH ILL GET ONTO) and hard it depends on how many cult members you have which makes it so collecting cult members has a purpose. There are 3 progression ways, one that affects the cult in general(buildings and stuff) and Sermons which affect the battle aspect like giving for weapons or curses and finally Doctrines which affect the cult members and rituals you can peform, you may think its all to much but in reality is really satisfying to go through.

-Cult of the lamb also has some sort of customization like change your cult members animal or adding patterns and buildings to your base it gives an animal crossing vibe i enjoy. 

-The main part of the game is the crusades you can buy stuff from shops save/rescue cult members and is your main source for beating the game. The different environments are all really cool and actuallly FEEL different than each other.

-Bosses are particually well made then follow the same aspect as the orignal enemy, like a scorpion shoots small fire balls while the boss version shoots big fireballs, and the main bosses are all 3 mini bosses mixed which is so cool!(you could say they ran out of ideas but its cool either way)

-The different zones you can discover actually server a purpose, they can upgrade certain aspects like your relics or tarot cards, some NPCs give tailsman shards which can give the play fleeces(ill get on those at the cons)

ok now for some cons.

CONS
-The mos controversial one here, the new free DLC is shit. Yep im gonna admit it. If you havent seen it, its basically RE DOING the entire game again but just harder, and the main guy who you give the god tears too isnt even a boss. hes just... there.. The only good thing i like about this DLC is the inclusion of relics which saved my life a lot of times. other than pretty mid

-Fleeces suck ass. They are the worst thing you can equip. Some of them remove health, remove rolling, and remove proper damage. The only good fleeces are the DEFAULT yes the DEFAULT and the fleeces of fate(gives you 4 tarot cards but you cant get anymore) the rest of them are just bad. I guess the fleece from the one who waits is good but still.

-And a very popular arguement, the progression system IS WAY TOO FAST, if you have like 30 cult members get ready to keep upgrading and upgrading. And building stuff that does absoulutely nothing for the rest if your playthrough. Some buildings or upgrades are COMPLETEY USESLESS(crow trap, morgue II, tabernacles)
why didnt they just make tabernacles II which is actually useful. well idk and it should be improved.


CONCLUSION
I know i should be too harsh since this is an indie game. But i would say this has some great potential but just has some holes that could improved. If you like dungeon crawlers, or animal crossing type game, i would recommend this and i would say it worth the price so enjoy!!

7.5/10

(REMINDER: this game is still being in development this means updates and more are planned soon, if you see UPDATE PRO or UPDATED CON this means they are pros and cons from this new update ok bye)

Cant put this one down lol 
its Animal crossing cult edition, with a binding of Issac style of a rouge like built in as well.
make a cult do runs build up cult base. have fun

I dont want to kill the rat for all the follower forms ):

I dont wanna be a meannnnn ):

This game is the perfect combination of cute and cursed. The battle is great, the customization is great, and the followers are the cutest things. I recommend putting your friend's name to your followers so you actually question twice if you will sacrifice them lol
Not going to lie, this is a fun and addicting game, it's the ultimate mom simulator, the difference is that you can kill, eat and revive your babies again and again... YAY!

applist.name: State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition
applist.detailed_description:
Juggernaut Edition


State of Decay 2: Juggernaut Edition re-imagines the popular survival game as a brand-new experience to welcome first-time players... and those who've come back from the dead. Available on Steam for the first time, this edition is packed with new and remastered content for the ultimate zombie survival experience.

Join over 10 million existing players and discover what Juggernaut Edition has to offer:

  • The base game plus all three add-on packs released to date, including the all-new Homecoming update:
    • Homecoming: a full-size, fully remastered, open world version of Trumbull Valley for the core game, reintegrating the Mount Tanner and Fairfield regions to the map, and adding new sites to scavenge, along with new sights to behold.
    • Heartland: an massive story campaign set in a familiar town with new challenges
    • Daybreak Pack: a test of teamwork with siege-style, "survive the horde" gameplay
    • Independence Pack: a celebration of history that blows up zombies... with fireworks!
  • Remastered graphics and an upgraded engine featuring realistic fog effects
  • An expanded soundtrack with hours of new thematic musical arrangements
  • Providence Ridge: a brand-new open-world map full of forests, zombies, and mystery
  • Two-handed heavy weapons with new melee combat moves to bust zombie heads
  • A new introductory experience and improved controls to help you master the apocalypse

... and countless other improvements to the classic open-ended sandbox gameplay.


About the Game

State of Decay 2 is an open-world survival-fantasy game set just after the zombie apocalypse. Your small community of survivors seeks to rebuild a corner of civilization, and you get to make all the decisions about how that happens.

You decide who to recruit to your team, where to settle your community, how to fortify and upgrade your base, and when it’s time to move to greener pastures. You select which survivor to bring along on a scavenging run for the food and ammo you need, and who you’ll use to fight off the zombies attacking your base. You choose how you’ll deal with other people who move into your town. Will you be friendly and welcoming... or will you aggressively defend your territory?

Every player’s experience in the sandbox is unique. Each character in your community has their own special set of skills and traits, so no two communities are ever the same. The challenges you face also vary from game to game, based on who you recruit and the decisions you make along the way.

With co-op multiplayer support, you can visit your friends' communities and help them through a tough spot, bringing back rewards for your own communities later. Alternate game modes include a full 10-hour narrative campaign and a four-player zombie-slaughtering "siege defense" mode.

Undead Labs is proud to present our best-ever vision of the zombie apocalypse. Keep your eyes peeled and your weapons ready. This is one apocalypse you won't want to miss.

ACCESSIBILITY OPTIONS

Gameplay
  • Adjustable difficulty can be set to ‘Green’, ‘Standard’, ‘Dread’, ‘Nightmare’, or ‘Lethal’, and can be adjusted separately each for ‘Action’, ‘Community’, and ‘Maps’
  • Adjustable aim assist, allowing the character to automatically lock on to the nearest enemy, can be set to ‘None’, ‘Normal’, or ‘Maximum’
  • Game can be paused in single-player mode (pause is unavailable in multiplayer)

Audio
  • Volume controls can be adjusted for Music, Voice, and SFX audio
  • Adjustable audio output can be set to Surround, Stereo, Headphones or TV

Visual
  • Subtitles for spoken content can be set to On or Off
  • Subtitle text size can be scaled to 50%, 75%, 100%, 125%, or 150%
  • Gamma levels can be adjusted to increase or decrease in-game brightness, and is available prior to game start
  • Field of view can be adjusted between 40% and 100%
  • Motion blur can be set to Off, Low, or High
  • ‘Reduce auto-camera movement’ can be set to On or Off
  • HUD UI visibility can be set to On or Off
  • In-World Objective Icon visibility can be set to On or Off
  • UI prompts for Finisher Moves on zombies can be set to On or Off
  • Mini-map visibility can be set to On or Off
  • Mini-map rotation lock can be set to On or Off
  • Tooltip visibility can be set to On or Off
  • Notifications can be set to On or Off

Input
  • Input remapping for keyboard & mouse, and most controller buttons*
  • Controller vibration can be set to On or Off
  • ‘Auto Camera Tracking on Foot’ can be set to On or Off
  • ‘Auto Camera Tracking in Vehicle’ can be set to On or Off
  • ‘Use camera to target interactions’ can be set to ‘Never’, ‘Always’, or ‘Only when using mouse’
  • ‘Aim on Movement Stick’ can be set to On or Off
  • ‘Rapid Button Tap’ can be replaced with ‘Hold Button Down’
  • ‘Hold to Aim’ can be replaced with ‘Aim Toggle’
  • ‘Remember Aim Zoom Level’ can be set to On or Off
  • Reduce Auto Camera Movement can be set to On or Off
  • Adjustable sensitivity for camera movement and weapon aiming for controller joystick and mouse
  • Ability to invert camera X and Y axes for controller joystick and mouse
  • Ability to swap left and right controller joystick functionality
*For Xbox controllers: the right stick, ‘view’, and ‘menu’ buttons are not remappable. To move your character while also aiming a weapon, a mouse or controller joystick stick is required – this cannot be done with a keyboard only.

content_descriptors.notes: In State of Decay 2, the quiet stillness of the post-apocalyptic world is interrupted by gruesome horror and grisly violence. If you can't defend yourself with the guns, knives, and bats you find while scavenging, you might see your character literally ripped apart by monstrous zombies... or murdered by aggressive NPCs looking to claim your territory!

Great game . it keep you engaged and on your toes.  +  devs are awesome & listen to the community
tons of replayability

100% worth the money

When I was a child, my father never took an interest in my hobbies. He was always out, at work, or just doing ‘adult’ things. Due to this, I vowed that when I had kids, I would take an interest in their hobbies, whether they be sports, gaming, or whatever else! And that’s why I became a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am the father to my son, Alfred, who is now 14. Recently, my son downloaded this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was devastating for me, as instead of bonding over ping pong, he was locked away in his room. As a result, I decided to make a Steam account, and get this game and take an interest in his hobbies, as my father had never done. I loaded into the game, and had no clue what to do, so I asked my son for help, and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it, as he hadn’t seemed this happy since we went rock climbing together in 2018. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again, and now we spend time together on hobbies that I grew up with, such as fishing. This game reminded me that there’s fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both I and my son many happy memories.

This is one of the best open world zombie survival game out on the market. I am a big fan of Walking Dead that's why i was looking for a game which is open world zombie survival and has base building and this is it. The game has a great community with a developer team who cares about feedback. There are dev and community streams. Still getting updates in 2023. Before you think this game can do more stuffs than currently available things i just tell you it could but. The dev team have limited resources because the most of them is already left SoD2 to work on State of Decay 3 with the Gears of War devs. They use this game to get feedback on things to create a better new game (SoD3) with these new features. Unfortunately because of the limit of the engine and the capacity of the team will lower the chances of big changes or updates i just say it to keep this in mind. You can play this game however you want. There are multiple maps, bases and customizable difficulty options. You can build your base however you want there are slots and in that slots you can build different stations. There is a 4 player online coop with limitations but at least we have and there is a chance that this will get a revamp because of a multiplayer survey. I don't wanna tell you more, there is much more to discover just get it and try it out! Definitely worth 30€, but if you can't buy it for that much, then wait for the sale and buy the game.

Undead Labs keep up this great work!
One of the better zombie survival games

The Devs never stop updating the game.  They are clearly thoughtful about the changes they make with regard to balance and to difficulty.  They also seem to be really good about taking feedback from the community as a whole rather than the blowhards that complain the most.  All in all, an amazing CO-OP experience and fun as hell to play single player. 10/10

I’ll start with the cons:

- Zombies are more an annoyance than a challenge or fun. And affects the pace of the game too much in a negative way.
- Stop with the radio please.
- Quest system is poor. And it is a shame that side quests needs to pop up again every time you restart the game. Also, sometimes you lose a quest by changing characters and this is just not a good system.
- Combat against humans are bad, just bad. This game would be hugely better if exchanging gun fights were better.
- It is a sandbox, I know, but the way you interact with stories should be overhauled in the next SOD.

[code]These are problems that has been brought by the previous SOC game and I hope they address all this to the next SOD because this franchise has a huge potential.[/code]

[h1]Leaving the rant behind, let’s point out the good stuff:[/h1]

+ SOC2 is unique. It is a mix of sandbox survival and community management in a certain casual triple A experience with in depth systems and mechanics that makes this game something else. Definitely my favourite “Xbox exclusive” so far.
+ The constant updates and upgrades are a common thing nowadays, even so  it’s impressive how the devs are still adding stuff, upgrading and rebalancing the game.
+ The DLC Homecoming is an upgrade for those looking for a more story driven experience - without losing the sandbox uniqueness of the game. 
+ Replayability.

Conclusion:

The sandbox experience as a main focus is the main selling point for me. No drama and cinematographic bu11sh1t. No save the world bu11sh1t. There is no hero and death is permanent. 

Community managing is something I would like to see in other open world experiences as well. 

[code]Enough of construction simulator on survival games, please, lol. Just follow what SOC2 does, please - and improve upon that, of course.[/code] 

If you have never played give it a try - or have played before but a long time ago, give it another try. The game has its problems but it is a delicious casual experience without losing deepness for those who enjoy a bit more. 

Looking forward to SOC 3.
In my opinion, its challenging to survive on the higher difficulties and the permadeath feature kept me on edge (try not to get too attached to your characters)

Pretty fun open world zombie game you can play coop with friends. It was pretty fun helping other friendly communities or fighting hostile communities but mostly building your own community by just recruiting others you find around,
I do kinda wish you could hold multiple communities in different bases than having everyone in one place. Still it's a fun game.
However by the end when you're near completing a map it gets old really quickly as you have pretty much the same type of requests and annoying infestations building up near your camp or some far away.

State of Decay 2 while is initially pretty engaging eventually runs into mediocrity thanks to the raw repetition of things  but it'll take you quite awhile to get to that point. State of Decay 2 on the right difficulty will leave you with dramatic scrambles to deal with hordes of zombies or special zombies if you manage things poorly or do not bring the needed supplies to deal with it and absolute success with reasonable planning and patience. It's a really solid zombie open world shooter if you're into that thing.

The biggest standout feature is the community system, which is new as well as having multiple maps to play on. The character generation is fairly big with different survivors having different sets of skills that they can bring to your base, meaning that they aren't divorced completely from your base like they kinda were in the first SOD. Each base has it's ups and downs, even if it seems like a straight upgrade. Some bigger bases are just frankly utterly terrible for dispatching hordes and juggernauts, they'll flood in and everything turns into a bloodbath. The key is picking the one that has many good spots for survivors to dispatch zombies while having key faculties that help manage your community. The upgrades aren't as essential as they seem, some quests and outposts you can setup in the openworld provide for the spaces in your base development you cannot fill. It's just way way way way better than the original State of Decay, which was a very annoying system to deal with. 

Another big part is the dynamic nature of the game as a sandbox. Survivors are generated randomly, whole other communities are randomly generated too. The game invites you to make your own player driven stories through those interactions often finally peaking with a designated leader and their ultimate goal for the community. This is essentially your endgame. It's a great way of pacing the game out a little and you get bonuses for completing a "community" every time you do this. Then you can take survivors from your current playthrough and save them for future playthroughs, so if you like that mechanic guy who you saved from a juggernaut and he learnt to build all your badass cars for you and you want him to come along for another ride? You can totally do that. It's pretty flexible and adds a level of meta progression that grows stronger with you being invested emotionally and gameplay wise. It's generally a pretty fun system.

The problems with this system is repetition, you will start to see the same sort of events happen over and over around your third playthrough. The community's overall goal and that questline of sorts rarely changes. It always sorta rolls out the same way which doesn't hurt too bad because most of the time your community progression is built towards making the area you are in safer from plague hearts (essentially red zombie disease) first and foremost. Be it through allying yourself with other communities and trading for supplies or them directly assisting with dispatching them. 

The moment to moment gameplay isn't spectacular, especially as other third person shooters go but it's serviceable. There are a looooot of guns. A lot of weapons. There is a lot of loot to collect and find. If you like grabbing everything in a building that isn't nailed down, this might be your game. Zombies are fairly intense to fight as well, they aren't pushovers especially on your own. If you're on a weak character and the difficulty is high, watch your ass because it won't take much to kill you. If a feral shows up and you're low on health? Your character is dead. The game appreciates stealth chiefly of all but it has the drawback of being a slow way to play the game and frankly kinda boring even if it's a really strong way to play. Go in guns blazing, slashing everything. It's a zombie game after alll! 

A short piece of coop, it's a really flawed unfun system that i am surprised is this halfbaked. It's not good. I hope to see maybe coop communities (maybe set it up similar to stardew valley?) in a third game out of Undead Labs because the sheer amount that you are locked out of doing as a coop partner is aloooooot. It's really not great. Don't get this as a coop game.

I think there is a lot here in State of Decay 2 to enjoy, not for as long as other games but it's an immensely fun journey if you're the right person for it. The foundation here is a lot stronger than SOD1 and i can see this evolving into something really awesome if they nailed out the game's design issues. Think 7 Days to Die but you're managing a whole group of survivors, your friends included. That would be insanely awesome. Undead Labs has put a lot of effort into the post-release content and understanding what people want from this game. I can't recommend this game if you're obviously lukewarm on the genre or open world games in general but if you are then you're gonna have fun for at least 10-30 hours. That's a good sell for a game pass game.
good
Best zombie game ever made.
In my opinion this is one of the best zombie style survival-horror games out there currently.

Beautiful game!, a unique experience not found in other zombies games, One thing, you can't play the game for long hours. I think the average play is 100 hours, because later the game will be repetitive.

The game is really great for solo gameplay. The concept of finding ressource trought a world ravaged by the apocalypse is pretty fun, I recommend the game. Since there's a lot too do. Obviously it is kind of repetitive since well your pretty much always looting, fighting or destroying plague's heart. In the end the game is worth it with the daybreak mod which allow you too buy some member of the red talon team for your community. The worst thing about the game in my opinion is definietly multiplayer. If you join someone else, you basically risk your character's life for nearly no reward... as the host get most of the best (which is kind of normal but instead could just make it so both player get reward. The players that are not the host cannot walk too far away from the host... which is kind of stupid since it makes it annoying when your trying too loot a place or even run away from a horde (or any other type of threat). Basically , the multiplayer mode is kinda nice but could be WAY better in any term of optimization such as making it possible too have equal loot and not being limited in where you are going on the map. It could also be nice too add the option too let a player go trough my base's storage as when someone joins you they need too use their own ressource... adding on the fact they don't get as much ressource as they would in their own game.. so unless you just wanna play for fun (or help your friend if you already play the game or anything) then multiplayer is really not worth... so yeah. the game is really good, great concept, good looking graphic, run pretty well on my pc (it doesnt struggle much which is good), and as a lot of content which is nice. so yeah I recommend the game but avoid buying it if it's only too play with your friend (that said, it is my opinion so maybe you would love it even if it'S only to play with your friends).
Mid
This game has unlimited replayability because you advance your communities and migrate to new communities after you play for a while so you can start fresh
Zombie games are pretty cool, especially this one.
One of the most fun survival games to grind on with 1-3 friends, as long as you play on a challenging difficulty. Definitely one of the most underrated games XGS has published.

I believe this game to be one in a kind, unfortunately after a few hours it becomes kind of dull and repetitive, they need to add more content other that similar missions, there is still room to grow.

This game is alot of Fun to play. I've spent many hours playing this and they have been updating the game for many years now, we are on update 33 of me posting this review. Most updates lately have been to how the games plays / Skins / Etc. However there is still afew but not many bugs left in this game, 97% of them are fixed. So the game is playable. If you get this game make sure you get State of Decay one so you know the story !!!  Enjoy

applist.name: Resident Evil 2
applist.detailed_description:
RESIDENT EVIL 2 R.P.D. Demo


Deluxe Edition

The Deluxe Edition contains the main game and the Extra DLC Pack which includes the following items:
-Leon Costume: "Arklay Sheriff"
-Leon Costume: "Noir"
-Claire Costume: "Military"
-Claire Costume: "Noir"
-Claire Costume: "Elza Walker"
-Deluxe Weapon: "Samurai Edge - Albert Model"
-"Original Ver." Soundtrack Swap


About the Game

The genre-defining masterpiece Resident Evil 2 returns, completely rebuilt from the ground up for a deeper narrative experience. Using Capcom’s proprietary RE Engine, Resident Evil 2 offers a fresh take on the classic survival horror saga with breathtakingly realistic visuals, heart-pounding immersive audio, a new over-the-shoulder camera, and modernized controls on top of gameplay modes from the original game.

In Resident Evil 2, the classic action, tense exploration, and puzzle solving gameplay that defined the Resident Evil series returns. Players join rookie police officer Leon Kennedy and college student Claire Redfield, who are thrust together by a disastrous outbreak in Raccoon City that transformed its population into deadly zombies. Both Leon and Claire have their own separate playable campaigns, allowing players to see the story from both characters’ perspectives. The fate of these two fan favorite characters is in players hands as they work together to survive and get to the bottom of what is behind the terrifying attack on the city. Will they make it out alive?

  • A spine-chilling reimagining of a horror classic - Based on the original release in 1998, the new game has been completely rebuilt from the ground up for a deeper narrative experience.
  • A whole new perspective – New over-the-shoulder camera mode and modernized control scheme creates a more modern take on the survival horror experience and offers players a trip down memory lane with the original gameplay modes from the 1998 release.
  • Terrifyingly realistic visuals – Built on Capcom’s proprietary RE Engine, Resident Evil 2 delivers breathtakingly photorealistic visuals whilst stunning lighting creates an up-close, intense and atmospheric experience as players roam the corridors of the Raccoon City Police Department (RPD).
  • Face the grotesque hordes – Zombies are brought to life with a horrifyingly realistic wet gore effect as they react in real time taking instant visible damage, making every bullet count.
  • Iconic series defining gameplay – Engage in frenzied combat with enemies, explore dark menacing corridors, solve puzzles to access areas and collect and use items discovered around the environment in a terrifying constant fight for survival.
  • See favorite characters in a whole new light - Join rookie police officer Leon S. Kennedy on his first day in the job and college student Claire Redfield, who is searching for her brother amidst a terrifying zombie epidemic.
  • Step into the rookie shoes of both heroes - Enjoy separately playable campaigns for both Leon and Claire, allowing players to see the story from both characters’ perspective.

applist.short_description: A deadly virus engulfs the residents of Raccoon City in September of 1998, plunging the city into chaos as flesh eating zombies roam the streets for survivors. An unparalleled adrenaline rush, gripping storyline, and unimaginable horrors await you. Witness the return of Resident Evil 2.

loen s kenededy
i liked the way they made leon whimper a LOT in this game :)

[h1] Review[/h1] 
Initially I was absolutely not interested in seeing a remake of a game I already played. When I played the demo back then I was really surprised how the game turned out to be. I really liked it although I still wished that they would port the original on steam too.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
This time the perspective is switched from fixed camera angles or first-person view to a third person angle. I love change that’s neat. Especially how the controls work, your character is not moving in any way stiff anymore not that I disliked the control scheme in any RE before.

Also, the puzzle nature of the gameplay is back, you run around and find obstacles and try to overcome them, mostly by punching in codes or finding an item, like a key(card) or a valve. Although more “complex” text puzzles of the original are gone. Still this gameplay was always what I liked, coupled together with the enemies and resource management. Which fight should I pick, should I risk a health item or ammo, or reload an old save? Veteran mode is this time the only one that has limited saves via cartridges again. I like that there is a challenging but not overly difficult veteran mode, although there is no difficulty above that.

Combat is fun due to the extra challenges of manually aiming at zombies heads or other enemies that are out there.  They move unpredictable making it absolutely not an easy task. They took again the system with the personal defence weapons from RE1 remake, so the protagonist will stab someone and lose a knife if getting grabbed from the front.

You also find on your way upgrades for your weapons or completely new ones, along with a remake and improvement of the old games level design. Its very familiar but still completely different, especially in the lategame. I found the game absolutely fun from start to finish and cannot really complain much, aside maybe that the backtracking can be a bit too much and the feature that helps you highlight rooms which you completely cleared makes the game a bit too easy on the exploring. I rather wish it would only highlight either main quest items or only being on easy difficulty. S Rank will take you on highest difficulty 2 hours and 30 minutes. My first play through took me closer to 8 hours for a single character. Good length, not too short but not too long.

There are also a few challenges that unlock cosmetics (but there are barely any) or artwork and a couple of extra modes added on. Those extra modes are a minigame that brings you through mostly already seen places and is more combat focused by delivering a mini story. Neat. Sadly extra coop mode or some kind of mercenary mode the franchise is known for. Oh well.

[u]Story[/u]
As in the original you can play through the game as either Leon or Claire. They have some different story aspects but play through most of the same areas. I would say about slightly over 1/3 of their storyline and gameplay is different. You also have the A and B route again, which changes almost nothing in the whole game, I even have the assumption that it changes less than the original did. Main difference is only the new main pistol as mostly ammo for that one will spawn and the starting area of the game. Some puzzles have barely changed and just make the game a bit shorter. This is an aspect they could have just skipped and probably added only so original fanboys are not mad that it didn’t got included.

[u]Sound[/u]
A bit of a let down is the OST. They played it very save by making the OST less interesting. like the original and instead made it much more environmental, save aside a few tracks. Its definitely fine but not that memorable.

Game is available again in a ton of different dubbed languages. Also, the indoor sound design is really neat and the whole SFX they use was my highlight.

[u]Graphics[/u]
You can tweak a lot on the graphical settings. I especially love and give them kudos for actually showing pictures that resemble various effects. In literally all games I deactivate lens flares and bloom, but the pictures showed me an effect I liked so kept it. Neat stuff!

To the graphics itself, the game can run on a potato but offers scaling that you can have problems even with very modern hardware. Its great that they added this amount of customization. Its not the best looking game, but full of details and little animation quirks, like when zombies are about to grab you but you kill them in the same moment they fall against you while the protagonist pushes them off their body or they try to dodge them.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I really absolutely enjoyed my playthrough. It’s a short game with lots of replay value which I absolutely like. The remake stays somewhat true to the original but offers so many new ideas and environments making it a must play for people who liked the ps1 game. The only downsides I have are a few nitpicks which are overshadowed by the fun core gameplay loop.

Leon Leon Leon Leon, Leon Leon Leon! 

Leon out of Leon would Leon again!!

Resident Evil 2 was a project that could have fallen apart extremely easily. Remaking a 21 year old title in a genre whose popularity has been up and down, bringing back most of the story beats and even design decisions while completely remaking the visuals and how the game controls (goodbye fixed cameras). And yet, what has arrived is both a great recollection of what has always worked for horror games along with enough new to feel modern and accessible. This should end up in classrooms as an example of how to refresh old games while retaining their identity.

Drinking game: Drink every time Leon says "What the?" No, I won't pay for your liver.

applist.name: Assassin's Creed® Revelations
applist.detailed_description:
When a man has won all his battles and defeated his enemies; what is left for him to achieve? Ezio Auditore must leave his life behind in search of answers, In search of the truth.
In Assassin’s Creed® Revelations, master assassin Ezio Auditore walks in the footsteps of the legendary mentor Altair, on a journey of discovery and revelation. It is a perilous path – one that will take Ezio to Constantinople, the heart of the Ottoman Empire, where a growing army of Templars threatens to destabilize the region.
In addition to Ezio’s award-winning story, a refined and expanded online multiplayer experience returns with more modes, more maps and more characters, allowing you to test your assassin skills against others from around the world.

Key Features:

  • BECOME DEADLIER THAN EVER

    Wield the lethal skills of a wiser, more efficient and deadlier Ezio. Swiftly eliminate your adversaries by deploying a new arsenal of weapons and abilities, such as enhanced free-running and hook blade combat. Experience new levels of gameplay customization with bomb crafting, and use heightened Eagle Vision to overcome your enemies and the environment.
  • TEST YOUR SKILLS AGAINST THE BEST

    A critically acclaimed multiplayer experience gets even better, with all-new team modes and infinite replay value.
  • EXPERIENCE REVOLUTIONARY GAMEPLAY

    Explore the farthest reaches of the Animus as you uncover the mysteries of Desmond’s past while gaining insight into what the future might hold.

reviews.review:
Hey.
Sharing my walkthrough at https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL957yPFpIoy-Yd9q-z7qrIYk06oVurOJC

Summary:
Assassin's Creed Revelations is the fourth main installment in the popular action-adventure video game series, developed by Ubisoft. Released in 2011, the game serves as the final chapter in the Ezio Auditore trilogy, following Assassin's Creed II and Assassin's Creed Brotherhood. 

The story of Assassin's Creed Revelations revolves around the aging Ezio Auditore da Firenze, the Italian assassin who has become a legendary figure within the Assassin Brotherhood. The game begins with an older Ezio traveling to Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul) in search of answers and to uncover the secrets left behind by Altaïr Ibn-La'Ahad, the protagonist of the original Assassin's Creed game.

In Constantinople, Ezio becomes embroiled in a conflict between the Byzantine Templars, led by the ruthless and enigmatic Prince Ahmet, and the local Ottoman Empire, under the reign of Sultan Selim. Ezio also encounters a new love interest, a young woman named Sofia Sartor, who aids him in his quest.

Throughout the game, players control Ezio as he explores Constantinople's vast open world, scaling buildings, engaging in parkour, and using his weapons and stealth abilities to eliminate targets. The gameplay features a combination of action, stealth, and puzzle-solving elements, and includes missions that take place in both the present day and the historical setting.

One of the key gameplay mechanics introduced in Assassin's Creed Revelations is the Hookblade, an upgrade to Ezio's Hidden Blade that allows him to navigate the city more swiftly, perform aerial assassinations, and engage in thrilling zip-line traversal. The game also introduces a new Tower Defense minigame, where Ezio must defend his Mediterranean Assassin Dens against Templar attacks.

In addition to playing as Ezio, players also take control of Altaïr at various points in the game, experiencing his memories through Ezio's perspective. These sequences shed light on Altaïr's later life and his involvement with the Masyaf Keys, ancient artifacts that unlock a hidden library containing profound knowledge.

The narrative of Assassin's Creed Revelations delves deep into the personal journey of Ezio as he reflects on his life, purpose, and the legacy he will leave behind. It also reveals important revelations about the ongoing conflict between the Assassins and Templars, bridging the gap between the past and the present.

Assassin's Creed Revelations received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised its immersive setting, refined gameplay mechanics, and the conclusion of Ezio's story arc. It is regarded as a significant installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise, providing players with a satisfying culmination to Ezio's tale while setting the stage for future entries in the series.
almost teared up to the ending, god its a masterpiece
sick game, great finale for the ezio trilogy, constantinople is awesome
K

[b]6.3/10[/b]

[u]Pros[/u]
     - Much improved graphics over previous titles
     - Best gameplay to this point
     - It's Assassins creed, which are generally just fun games

[u]Cons[/u]
     - Multiple game breaking bugs (while easy to fix, they shouldn't be here and hamper the overall 
        experience)
     - Story is weak overall and feels like they just were trying to squeeze more out of Ezio
     - Game is relatively short, especially for an Assassins Creed game
     - World/City is the smallest, and generally the most boring up to this point in the series
     - Very little beside the story to do in the world, feels even peeled back a bit from Brotherhoods side 
        activities 
     - While there is movement in the "Desmond" story line, it feels relatively tacked on, there could have been 
        a lot more done with that (again the game feels more like squeezing the most out of the series rather 
        than really adding on to it)

Normally a score like that in my book would be a more in the middle kind of deal and I think that's exactly what this is. I can really only recommend in it if you're already invested into the first 3 games of the series as this of course has some pivotal story telling in relation to the overall story. It also is more AC so I guess that's a bonus for it too, even if it's the worst of the series at the point of it's release.

Overall the graphics are way improved over the first 3 titles, and the gameplay IMO feels the best here that it has up to this point in the AC games. That's pretty much where the good things end. The story is the weakest (and shortest) so far, the city it takes place in seems to be the smallest and also just the most boring with seemingly much fewer things to do than previous titles. Beyond that, I encountered 2 game breaking bugs and a slew of others that I'd consider unacceptable. The game breaking ones of course being absolutely dreadful and embarrassing. I wanted to rate the game higher, but after encoutnering the first game breaking bug within the first minute of the game (which requires deleting a random file from the install, confirmed by someone at Ubisoft nearly a decade ago and of course hasn't just been fixed), It was hard to give much more praise, then once the second game breaking bug happened at a fairly pivotal story moment it was a straw that broke the camels back (this bug required turning off any multi core running for AC Revelations and then playing the part of the story affected with sub 20 FPS due to this). These things were beyond unacceptable and with those along with just the game not being nearly as good as the previous 3 in the world/story department it just was a major let down replaying this again.

applist.name: No Man's Sky
applist.detailed_description:
Inspired by the adventure and imagination that we love from classic science-fiction, No Man's Sky presents you with a galaxy to explore, filled with unique planets and lifeforms, and constant danger and action.

In No Man's Sky, every star is the light of a distant sun, each orbited by planets filled with life, and you can go to any of them you choose. Fly smoothly from deep space to planetary surfaces, with no loading screens, and no limits. In this infinite procedurally generated universe, you'll discover places and creatures that no other players have seen before - and perhaps never will again.

Now including...

Play with all major updates since launch: Foundation, Pathfinder, Atlas Rises, NEXT, The Abyss, Visions, the 2.0 BEYOND update, Synthesis, Living Ship, Exo Mech, Desolation and the 3.0 update, ORIGINS, Next Generation, Companions, Expeditions, Prisms, Frontiers, Sentinel, Outlaws, Endurance, Waypoint (4.0), Fractal and Interceptor.

Available for PC and Mac (see recommended and minimum specs for details).

An epic voyage to the centre of a shared universe awaits, allowing you to explore, trade, fight and survive alone or with friends.

Embark on an epic voyage

At the centre of the galaxy lies a irresistible pulse which draws you on a journey towards it to learn the true nature of the cosmos. But, facing hostile creatures and fierce pirates, you'll know that death comes at a cost, and survival will be down to the choices you make over how you upgrade your ship, your weapon and suit.

Find your own destiny

Your voyage through No Man's Sky is up to you. Will you be a fighter, preying on the weak and taking their riches, or taking out pirates for their bounties? Power is yours if you upgrade your ship for speed and weaponry.


Or a trader? Find rich resources on forgotten worlds and exploit them for the highest prices. Invest in more cargo space and you'll reap huge rewards.

Or perhaps an explorer? Go beyond the known frontier and discover places and things that no one has ever seen before. Upgrade your engines to jump ever farther, and strengthen your suit for survival in toxic environments that would kill the unwary.

Share your journey

The galaxy is a living, breathing place. Trade convoys travel between stars, factions vie for territory, pirates hunt the unwary, and the police are ever watching. Every other player lives in the same galaxy, and you can choose to share your discoveries with them on a map that spans known space. Perhaps you will see the results of their actions as well as your own...

✓ Overpromised
✓ Had an abysmall launch
✓ Caused Valve to temporary change Steam refund policy
✓ Was burned to ashes by critics
✓ Did not die, did not give up
✓ Rose from the ashes with dignity 
✓ Is actually a good SpaceSim now
✓ Has some bare bones and small bugs 
✓ Is in active development, regularly updated with new meat for the bare bones 
✓ Absolutely beloved by me for its dreamy atmosphere and fourth-wall-breaking lore 🤯💥
✓ Totally recommended to at least check out, give it a few days trial
It's been like 7 years and they're still releasing free content. Wtf, thank you

So many things to do, it's like Subnautica but in space instead, and with endless side missions. It has come a long way, hard to imagine that it was a bad game when it was just released, but now it just keeps getting better and better. The devs just keep adding more and more lol

64 hours on PC - 500+ on console.
Did this game have a big poopoo launch with thousands of memes, 100% yes!
Did the developers knuckle down and work hard to update and update and update and update into one of the greatest games I've ever played since then, 300% yes!!

We all know the developers could have taken that money from launch and just ran with it, but I have huge respect for the commitment they put into the title post launch and the pride they take in the game.

This game isn't perfect, but it feels good supporting a developer that stood by and continued to grow their game for 7 years and still going and I always enjoy popping in

space
Keeps getting better and better.  Been playing since the initial release and have never needed to shell out another penny for all of the upgrades.  Good job guys!
I pirated the game in 2016, then bought it on Steam in 2019, and bought it on PS4 in 2021. They deserved every penny that I have throughout the years!!
Nobody will read my review, so I'll just say i'm gay.

Wow... Just... Wow...

I never played NMS when all the negativity was plaguing the game, but after it started taking off I dabbled here and there. I finally dove in a few months ago just to see if I would enjoy it. This is THE space survival game, no other game even comes close. If you're into survival games that is this is an absolute treasure. Not to mention the fact that they haven't done the whole Paradox thing and released 50 DLC at this point, all content has been free.

My ONE complaint, and it's probably just because I haven't spent enough time in the game. Is the whole "Expedition" mechanic. If you're familiar with Seasons from other big MMOs it's of the similar vein. I'm just not sure if "I" find them fun, doesn't mean that you wont of course.

As far as price goes, 60$ is a pretty steep cost. I personally try to buy everything on sale and rarely buy games at full price. The amount of content in this game though is easily more than your average two AAA combined, maybe even three.
u can do the star wars hyperspace traveling STONKS
The game is as wide as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle.
This is one of the best games I've ever played. If you like games where you collect resources, build a base, etc... (Ark, Rust, etc...) and you love sci-fi then this game is for you!
Only criticism i have is the unintuitive star map navigation

Buy it when it's on sale for half off to get your money's worth. It's a good time sink, but the content lacks real variety and the combat is pretty sad. It's very easy to become nearly invincible. The only point of the multiple galaxies full of planets seems to be a size contest with Elite Dangerous or something, since they get really repetitive, really fast. The main mission storyline is pretty good if a bit predictable for the attentive. The refinery is your friend - look up the recipes because they make no real world logical sense.
Fantastic game. The port to MacOS run great!

I tried running the game on my MacBook, overall it's good, but there are a couple of highly annoying issues.

Textures and objects on planets sometimes flicker, it happens randomly.
The game lacks dead zone settings for the gamepad, so my character sometimes moves forward on its own. This issue is only present in this game, as if there's no dead zone at all.
The game occasionally crashes, usually after 2-4 hours of gameplay.
For now, my rating is average, but if these issues are fixed, I will change it to positive.

applist.name: Tiny Tina's Wonderlands
applist.detailed_description:
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands: Chaotic Great Edition


THE CHAOTIC GREAT EDITION INCLUDES:

  • Full Game
  • Season Pass (Includes the Butt Stallion Pack, Blightcaller class, and 4 dungeons with new bosses, loot, and environments)
  • Dragon Lord Pack Bonus Content


About the Game

Party up with friends in cross-platform multiplayer!

Embark on an epic adventure full of whimsy, wonder, and high-powered weaponry! Bullets, magic, and broadswords collide across this chaotic fantasy world brought to life by the unpredictable Tiny Tina.
Roll your own multiclass hero and loot, shoot, slash, and cast your way through outlandish monsters and loot-filled dungeons on a quest to stop the tyrannical Dragon Lord. Everyone's welcome, so join the party, throw on your adventuring boots, and be Chaotic Great!

AN UNPREDICTABLE FANTASY WORLD

Tiny Tina is your disorderly guide through an extraordinary tabletop realm where rules rarely apply. Explore a vast overworld spanning majestic cities, dank mushroom forests, foreboding fortresses, and more!

GUNS, SPELLS, AND MORE

Blast baddies with powerful guns and devastating spells in frenetic first-person battles. Use your firepower to vanquish legions of enemies, including smack-talking skeletons, land-roaming sharks, and colossal bosses. Then delve deeper into dangerous dungeons for a shot at epic loot!

PARTY UP TO DEFEAT EVIL

Joining you at the table are headstrong captain Valentine and rule-obsessed robot Frette. During your quest to defeat the Dragon Lord, you'll meet a cast of lovable misfits like a lute-wielding Bardbarian and your very own Fairy Punchfather.

PERSONALIZE YOUR HERO

Create the perfect hero with deep customization, including a multiclass system that lets you mix and match six unique character skill trees, all with their own awesome abilities. Level up, refine your build, expand your arsenal, and become the ultimate adventurer.

BAND TOGETHER IN CHAOTIC CO-OP

Enjoy the story solo or start a party with up to three friends in seamless online multiplayer. Share the spoils or rush to get the shiniest loot—how you play is up to you!

reviews.review:
This is more a 'meh' review than an actual negative one. The presentation is fine, but the game runs quite poorly for how it looks. The overworld as a way to connect locations isn't a bad idea, but it does feel a bit too less developed. The named instances for the most part are fun to play, but the rest of the content is fighting in rather short arenas that don't differ that much throughout the game.

That's my main problem with the game: The actually written content you get is good, but it's clear that it was padded with a lot of same-ish encounters. Most quests in the overworld are 'Go to arena and get item' which gets boring very quick. For 20-30 bucks this game is okay, but not for 60. Oh and stay away from the DLC. It is not worth it at all.

This game is just not good, it's soooo boring. It could have been a solid entry in the franchise but it's just meh, the combat is unfulfilling, the enemies tedious. It's a painful experience once that I didn't bother to finish because I simply lost interest. Instead I fired up Borderlands 2, a 10 year old game crushes TTW in every way that matters. This game is just not fun.

Been going down hill since BL2. Sadly i likely wont purchase any more games in this series. The quality just keeps getting worse. Who ever had the secret formula to a fun game back then must be gone and taken it with them.

bought and played on release. Overall a really cool combination of Borderlands and Fantasy/D&D. The game by itself is very good, but with co-op it falls apart. It's connection is very unstable, no matter your internet quality. I was horrified to see that the co-op instability STILL hasnt been fixed since release, almost a year ago... Co-op is a hugeee thing for me on borderlands games, very disappointing that it doesnt function properly in this game. Regardless, still great single player fun.

This is possibly the single most underwhelming game I've ever played,
I went into this game with high hopes as I've really enjoyed the other borderlands games,
the abilities for the most part feel like re-skins from previous games, 
most of the spells and guns do less damage than a wet fart in the wind and the gun generation is extremely repetitive
the characters just don't really stand up against the other games.
and that doesn't even mention the incredible amount of game breaking bugs that me and my friends experienced whilst playing, one of us crashed 5 times in 10 minutes...
is it too much to ask for a game to be playable these days?
Might play again if it gets patched for the game breaking stuff but as it is i wont be launching this again.
There are entire comedy TV shows that never manage to be as funny as the vending machines in this game
Lots of silly fantasy fun.

[b][u]Introduction[/u][/b]
To preface this review, I haven't currently finished the main story of the game, might make an update If needed by the end. I have only played Borderlands 2 before this and I have not played the DLC this game was based on. I'm playing 3 player co-op with friends, coming out of playing BL2.

[b][u]Player Characters, Customisation[/u][/b]
Character customisation was cool, It's fun being able to make a character and pick a voice, however the options feel a bit lackluster, especially when It comes to the hair and outfit. All the player character voices seem to be British but none of those voice actors are British and yeah, It Is noticeable lol. There are 4 voices and "personalities" but they all say the same things and act the same way. Whilst making your own character Is Interesting, the fact they all act the same sucks out the personality and charm that player characters had In the other games.

[b][u]World and Setting[/u][/b]
I loved the world going Into It, and a lot of the settings are absolutely gorgeous, they feel so colourful, fun and full of creativity, I adore them. But they feel too closed off. I think If the game played like a typical Borderlands, It'd feel so much better. I know the other game was instanced, but you FEEL It more In this game, as opposed to the instances being sort of walled off by gates and such, there's just an invisible wall here, and some of the levels are EXTREMELY small, and you feel really boxed In, and they get repetitive, especially for random encounters and side quests. 

[b][u]Story and Missions with the World[/u][/b]
Anything that Isn't the main mission feels a lot more half arsed and boring, like no effort went Into that half of the game, but the main story section feels pretty well done SO FAR, with epic cutscene moments and fantastic world design, I just feel like my immersion Is ruined when I witness something amazing happen to the landscape, only to walk fourth Into It to run Into an invisible wall and get teleported to the DND board overworld. I get that the game Is a parody based on a DND board game, and It was kind of funny and cool but sometimes It just sucks you out of It, and feels a little lazy to some extent. I think If anything, DND players love immersion and getting sucked In, but that part takes you out of what's happening for a while.

[b][u]Weapons and Combat[/u][/b]
Weapons, armour, whatever, It's all okay I suppose. The design of some of the weapons are really cool, but everything feels somewhat weak. Grenades are exchanged for magic spells, which there are a variety of. I do enjoy some of the spells, they are definitely cool, but some feel weaker than others or difficult to control. Melee weapons feel TOO weak In this game, like you're getting all up In the enemies business just to do way less damage than just using a gun would do, It's like high risk anti-reward. 

The store was confusing to me at first, I ended up accidentally selling all my equipped items because they show up with everything else you sell apparently LOL. The battle also feels unsatisfying compared to the last game with all the colourful numbers showing up as you fight the enemies, It feels really lacking In this game. I know the enemies are probably repetitive In all the games, but I just FEEL It more here for some reason, I'm so bored of killing skeletons, and now we're In a new zone, we're fighting crabs, which are really annoying, they are tiny, fast and have a shell that makes ur damage look like a joke. 

Another issue with combat Is, we can never tell when someone has died In this game, we have to just say on com's that one of us died. In BL2, there'd be an indicator on your screen with a sound when someone died so you always knew, but I find myself missing It all the time In this game. Also there's small things like I swear there's enemies with explosives on their backs that don't explode when you shoot them but that might be a nitpick, It just feels lame.

[b][u]Inclusivity[/u][/b]
Something I do like about the game Is how It feels more inclusive, I thought the range of characters and voice actors of different identities and ideals was pretty neat. You can also pick from a set of pronouns for your character. 

[b][u]DLC[/u][/b]
I'm not sure If the other games did this, but the DLC also feels shoehorned In a bit, like you're shown a class that you can't use, or worlds you COULD access with the DLC even though you don't have It, and are just told to go to the store. Looking at the reviews for the DLC, I'm assuming that's not a good Idea.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
I'm probably forgetting some things I want to say right now, but It just boils down to feeling boring, boxed In and unsatisfying. You can't get immersed Into this world, It feels stringed together and like nothing connects. The concept It great and I LOVE the worlds and stuff they have In here, they could have make something Incredible here but It just fell a bit short, especially If you're comparing It to the other games In the franchise.

This game Is not worth the curiosity, even If you're a fantasy fan. The game Is WAY too expensive, even on half price It's around £30, which Is In the high price range for me and my friends, I can't even imagine having paid In full for this. I can't justify It even at the half-way mark, It sucks, now I feel guilty for getting all my friends to spend so much on It, and I'm feeling forced to keep playing It just to feel like I got my.. or "our" moneys worth. I dread having to play It, and can't wait for It to end.

The (base) game is not worth the 60€ price tag and probably not even the 30€ that I got it at. Skyrim with My Little Pony mod installed feels more Borderlands than this.

The story of the game follows the familiar Borderlands format, with two caveats: there's basically no NPCs that follow you through the story, which is incredibly short. Sure, Tiny Tina and the Bad Guy narrate your adventures, but you're not regularly interacting with any recurring NPCs and there's very few familiar faces scattered about. For example, I would've expected Roland and Mr. Torgue to play significant parts in the game, what with their relationships with Tina. NPCs, in general, are entirely forgettable, with some minor exceptions.

While the overworld map that connects all of the different zones is a neat idea and I like the various items scattered across it, I feel that it is very lacking in execution and is thoroughly undermined by the fast travel system. Either the overworld or the fast travel system should not exist. Additionally, the approximately four or five maps that are there for the so-called combat/random encounters in the overworld get incredibly boring, incredibly fast. 

Speaking of maps, they are all very generic fantasy natural-scenery maps: there's a bit of grasslands, woods, city, sea floor and pirate beach. These are all fine and dandy, but the variety is significantly lacking in comparison to prior Borderlands titles. There's no volcano or underground biomes, for example, and what maps are there are very unimpressive visually.

The maps feature four primary factions: skeletons, greenskins, fungi and coiled (naga). None of the four factions have distinct mechanics or gameplay elements; there's nothing along the lines of skeletaurs, goliaths or hyperion bots at least before whatever is the equivalent of TVHM in this game. Technically, there's also pirates and bandits, but these are barely even visually distinct from skeletons, let alone mechanically. Scattered between the forces of the main factions are some fantastical beasts, such as wyverns and dogfish, which do distinguish themselves from one another.

With the fantasy theme come spells, which replace grenades and come with an automatic recharge mechanic. While some spells are incredibly powerful and feel great to activate as they can destroy an entire wave of enemies and put a huge dent even into badasses, most spells are lackluster and usually worse than firing a gun. The variety of spells is pretty good, but I wish that anything besides fissures actually had any "oomph" at all. For example, meteors come with a significant cast delay and have _tiny_ impact areas by comparison and absurd recharge times to boot.

Alongside spells there are the class-based skills. There are exactly three interesting skills: polymorph, invisibility and reaper of bones, though ambi-hextrous deserves an honorable mention for conceding that the spells are strictly more interesting than the action skills. Everything else is of the format "press button to deal damage", which is confusing at best considering how easily many of the action skills in Borderlands titles could have been reskinned with a fantasy theme. 

Skill modifiers also do not exist, which combined with the above leads to every class feeling basically the same despite having extremely distinct themes. Your choices are to either shoot at stuff or hit them with your sword/axe/mace. None of the skill trees feel like a substantial change to how I play the game.

As there is only a single skill tree for every class, an opportunity to "multiclass" is presented. This essentially means slapping on the passives from another class to your initially chosen class. Don't forget to google the skill trees before you lock in, because the game does not actually give you any indication as to what the choice entails beyond a "this class is good at fire damage" when choosing and I don't know whether it is even possible to choose again. Nor do I really care, because why would I when there is essentially no difference?

You can freely choose your character's body shape, pronoun and voice independent of one another, which is nice, I guess, if I cared about any of that and if all of them weren't so incredibly bland. I have always enjoyed the various quips, puns and dialogue of the Borderlands player characters, but that does not materialize here.

All characters look essentially the same and outfits — the visually most distinctive part of your character — are tied to your class mod. There seems to only be a small handful of variants, all of which look the same. If you thought you could be a robot-ninja-pirate, think again. The color/pattern alterations you can make to your outfit are also incredibly bland and require you to find them as drops from enemies or from collectibles scattered around the world. If you thought Borderlands 3 had bad customization options with the ugly-ass head and body options, you really don't want to see what Wonderlands has to offer.

TL;DR: it's bland. Buying and playing the DLC again is a better use of your time and money.

TLDR; Don't pay more than $30 MAX preferably $20

Pros: guns are cool. "multi classing" is fun. good VA's
Cons: UI feels more cluttered than other Borderlands games. LOTS of dialog.

I want to like the game but I can't. There is way too much dialog that blocks you from progressing. There are so many times in this game where i just have to sit there and wait for pointless dialog to finish so i can move forward. It made the game so unenjoyable that I couldn't finish the game.

Not sure why so many people complained about this game being too short, it took me over 40 hours to finish the story with still a few side quests to do and plenty of collectables left to gather. That's plenty of game and honestly it got a bit samey after a while anyway. After about halfway through you've pretty much seen all the enemy types in the game so the combat can get repetitive. That said it is also very fun if you're just after more Borderlands. The inclusion of spells is a nice change from grenades for the franchise, though I'll admit I pretty much used only 1 or 2 different spell types because having to hold down a button for several seconds looking at the point you want to cast a spell leaves you a vulnerable so got annoying. Good variety of classes and more interesting perk upgrades than usual.

Now the bad stuff. The game is way too easy. I rarely died and if I did it was because I missed a jump or accidentally bashed an exploding barrel thinking it was a regular one. Most boss fights were over within a matter of seconds with no strategy needed to defeat them. Ammo crates are spammed every 5 metres you walk so you never run out of ammo and have to change weapon so you only do so when you get bored. The UI is pretty poor. For example, to put a way point down on the map you think it would make sense that you could just click on the map where your mouse cursor is right? Well apparently not, because you have to drag your mouse across the screen to move the map cursor to the point on the map you want the way point to be. It's really awkward. Also the characters in the game apart from Tiny Tina are really lame and annoying. Not quite as bad as in BL3 but not far off. It was cringe inducing stuff.

There's a good game to be had, but the incessant chatter from cringey dialogue and laughably easy combat makes it easy to forget that the core gun play is the only thing holding this game together.
no claptrap

I love me some borderlands. I picked up the assault on dragons keep for free and was digging the style so I snagged the game. It is embarrassingly short. I missed this when it came out and didn't read any reviews because it's borderlands. The game is beautiful, the cross with D&D is fun, the over world I thought was a nice edition. I was taking my time doing lots of side quest and such and beat the game on accident. They put a lot of effort into the game so I can't understand why you wouldn't write a better story. Sad. If this was a ten dollar game sure, but full price for the rubbish story is a big disappointment. They want you to buy all this DLC when the game is shallow is a slap in the face. Shame.

My brother and I decided to try it. 5 hours later we decided to end our trial.
We couldn't take the non-stop talkin, lamenting, joking and references. We just wanted to loot and shoot but there was so much down time between the actual shooting... 
we didn't want to find out if there will be actually more looting and shooting.
Like Borderlands but fun
mid
no tvm

The base game is good. The story is ok with a lot of the humour that you would expect and some old favorites (or hated chars...hehe) returning for some banter along a board game, its not a bad move since this has been done in BL 2 with great success. However, it is quite shallow and since it is a board game it does not really engage me in the story, but it was ok, nothing special at all but ok.

Gunplay is great as usual, builds are fun to explore etc. But.... the DLCs are so bad I do not even have words for it, next time just add more items in the game with the patch and skip the teedious quests that takes away the tempo of the game and offers zero in interesting lore. The DLCs are pure shir, sorry for the language. They are all annoying to do compared to BL content overall and there is ZERO story or rewards to care about apart from some new items. 

Late game farm is not terrible. I will for sure spend more time doing more builds etc. But keeping track of gear in the stash with no possibility to word search etc. is a bit of a joke by now. Having multiple chars with one bank with sortiing and scrolling being the only options for overview is beyond bad. Lots of bugs still but that does not matter for me, yet, since none are game breaking. 

A really good game overall for new players (i think, if they only want to go through it and maybe spend a few hours more after last boss) but for BL standards I give it 6/10 since it could have been so much better.
You might enjoy this if you liked Borderlands 3

applist.name: Stardew Valley
applist.detailed_description:
Stardew Valley is an open-ended country-life RPG!



You've inherited your grandfather's old farm plot in Stardew Valley. Armed with hand-me-down tools and a few coins, you set out to begin your new life. Can you learn to live off the land and turn these overgrown fields into a thriving home? It won't be easy. Ever since Joja Corporation came to town, the old ways of life have all but disappeared. The community center, once the town's most vibrant hub of activity, now lies in shambles. But the valley seems full of opportunity. With a little dedication, you might just be the one to restore Stardew Valley to greatness!

Features
  • Turn your overgrown field into a lively farm! Raise animals, grow crops, start an orchard, craft useful machines, and more! You'll have plenty of space to create the farm of your dreams.

  • 4 Player Farming! Invite 1-3 players to join you in the valley online! Players can work together to build a thriving farm, share resources, and improve the local community. As more hands are better than one, players have the option to scale profit margin on produce sold for a more challenging experience.

  • Improve your skills over time. As you make your way from a struggling greenhorn to a master farmer, you'll level up in 5 different areas: farming, mining, combat, fishing, and foraging. As you progress, you'll learn new cooking and crafting recipes, unlock new areas to explore, and customize your skills by choosing from a variety of professions.

  • Become part of the local community. With over 30 unique characters living in Stardew Valley, you won't have a problem finding new friends! Each person has their own daily schedule, birthday, unique mini-cutscenes, and new things to say throughout the week and year. As you make friends with them, they will open up to you, ask you for help with their personal troubles, or tell you their secrets! Take part in seasonal festivals such as the luau, haunted maze, and feast of the winter star.

  • Explore a vast, mysterious cave. As you travel deeper underground, you'll encounter new and dangerous monsters, powerful weapons, new environments, valuable gemstones, raw materials for crafting and upgrading tools, and mysteries to be uncovered.

  • Breathe new life into the valley. Since JojaMart opened, the old way of life in Stardew Valley has changed. Much of the town's infrastructure has fallen into disrepair. Help restore Stardew Valley to it's former glory by repairing the old community center, or take the alternate route and join forces with Joja Corporation.

  • Court and marry a partner to share your life on the farm with. There are 12 available bachelors and bachelorettes to woo, each with unique character progression cutscenes. Once married, your partner will live on the farm with you. Who knows, maybe you'll have kids and start a family?

  • Spend a relaxing afternoon at one of the local fishing spots. The waters are teeming with seasonal varieties of delicious fish. Craft bait, bobbers, and crab pots to help you in your journey toward catching every fish and becoming a local legend!

  • Donate artifacts and minerals to the local museum.

  • Cook delicious meals and craft useful items to help you out. With over 100 cooking and crafting recipes, you'll have a wide variety of items to create. Some dishes you cook will even give you temporary boosts to skills, running speed, or combat prowess. Craft useful objects like scarecrows, oil makers, furnaces, or even the rare and expensive crystalarium.

  • Customize the appearance of your character and house. With hundreds of decorative items to choose from, you'll have no trouble creating the home of your dreams!

  • Xbox controller support (with rumble)! (Keyboard still required for text input)

  • Over two hours of original music.

applist.name: Assassin's Creed® Unity
applist.detailed_description: Assassin’s Creed® Unity is an action/adventure game set in the city of Paris during one of its darkest hours, the French Revolution. Take ownership of the story by customising Arno's equipement to make the experience unique to you, both visually and mechanically. In addition to an epic single-player experience, Assassin’s Creed Unity delivers the excitement of playing with up to three friends through online cooperative gameplay in specific missions. Throughout the game, take part in one of the most pivotal moments of French history in a compelling storyline and a breath-taking playground that brought you the city of lights of today.

In addition to an epic single-player experience, Assassin’s Creed Unity delivers the excitement of playing with up to three friends through online cooperative gameplay in specific missions. Throughout the game, take part in one of the most pivotal moments of French history in a compelling storyline and a breath-taking playground that brought you the city of lights of today.
applist.short_description: Assassin’s Creed® Unity tells the story of Arno, a young man who embarks upon an extraordinary journey to expose the true powers behind the French Revolution. In the brand new co-op mode, you and your friends will also be thrown in the middle of a ruthless struggle for the fate of a nation.
